ITNITBI) STATESC ~ A S T AND GEODETIO SURVEY, Wa.rhington, D. C., nece~nber 8, 18.96. SIR: I u cor~forniitywith law aud the regulations of the Treasury Department I have the honor to snbmit herewith, for tranvrnissio~lto Congress, the Annual Report on tho progress of the Coast and Geodetic Survey for the fiscal year ending June 30, 1896. I N T W O PARTS-

PARTS I A N D 1.1.
PItElMTO13Y XOTE.

In this report of the fiscal year lS96 the divisioll illto two parts lias been retainetl. but both parts :we published in orie volunlc. Part I contains the historic:sl port,ior~. It presents abstracts 01' llrogresu in ficltl and oflice mork, gives estimates for future mork, aiid a statement of oxpeuditures during the tiscnl year. Thc usual lnaps and progress sketches, showiilg in detail tlle localities and scope of the field operations, accompany the report. Part I1 contains the Appendices which relate to the methods, discussions, aud results of' the Survey, with sric11illustrations as are required. The illustratiolls accompany the Appendices to which they respectively belong.

PART I.

This report prese~its n full accoutit of tlie varied operations carried on during tho fiscal year by this irnport:~r~t b r a ~ ~ cof l i the pnblic service, and also gives iu concist, tabular form colnpleto statistics relating to tho distribntiori of field parties and the results accomplished both in field aiid office. Tlio usual m:kps a11d slretclies, showing graphically the progress of the Survey and the present condition of the work, accolupany the report and will be found a t the elid of the volume. Field opercrtions.-The field operations during tlie year have included tho measurement of base lines; reco~iuaissa~~ce; triangulation; astronomical ilcterminations of tima, latitude, and azimuth; telegraphic and chronoruetric detorminatioris of longitude; topographical and hydrographical surveys and resurveys; tidal and curreut observations; determinations of n~agiietic declinntion, dip, and intensity; peudnluru observations for tleter~ninatioii of the force of gravity; geodetic leveling; Coast Pilot examinatioirs; bo~uidary-line surveys; special topographic and hydrographic oxaminatione, including tlio investigation of reported dangers to uavigation; aiid laying out and marking of naval speed trial courses. Upwartl of 5fty field parties were engaged on theso various branches of the work, and theso mere distributed aloug the Atlantic, Gulf, P;iciHc, and Alaskan coasts, and in the interior of the country. Sl~rveys or observations mere conducted within the limits or on the coasts of twenty States and Territories along the seaboards, aud in fifteen iuterior States and Territories. The special operations of importance begun, continued, or con~pleted during the year may bo enumerated as follows : Completion of the topographic and hydrographic resurvty of New Bedford Harbor and its approaches; continuation of the topographic and hydrographic resurvey of Buzzards Bay; continuation of hydrographic surveys and examinations on tlio coast of Massachusetts; continuation of hydrographic resurveys in Nantucket Sound, Block Island Souncl, iInd off nlontauk Point; continuation of the topograpliic resurvey of the sontheni -shores of Long Island; coritinuation of the Hudson Biver snrvey; extension of the main tri:~ngulatio~i eastward across tho States of Maryland and I)ela~~;bre to Capes Henry and el en lo per^ ; hytlrogrnpl~ic resurvey of the liarbor and entrance of Port ltoyal, S. C.; magnetic detorn~inations in various Eastern, Middle, Southern, and Western States; spec:ial hydrographic exltuli~lations alo~ig tlie fitlautic, Gulf, and L'acific coasts; completion of the 1lydrogr:rphic resurvey of Pensmola Bay and Entrance; coutiuuation of the primary trisugulation of the oblique arc in Alabama; contintlation of the determination of points for State surveys; progress mndo in the triailgulation of Lake l'onchartrain; col~tiuuation of the transcorltinental triangulation ill Kansas, Colorado, and Utah, including base-line measurements; coritiiiuation of the transcontiuelltal line of precise lovels in Kansas; continuation of the topographic alld llydrographic resurvey of Sari Fraticisco 13ay ancl Harbor; coutiuuatiori of the survey of T+'ashington Sound; continuatioi~of general and hydrographic surveys in souttiwst S. Alaska; coutinuation of the survey of the California and Nevada oblique bouudary line; continuation of surveys ill connectiou with the Southeast Alaska-British Columbia boundary line; m a g ~ ~ e t determinatious ic a t sixty-one stations iu varions parts of the country; telegraphic alld chronometric longitude determinations a t twenty-two stations; gravity detcrmirlatio~isa t six stations; tidal observations a t various points on the Atlantic, Gulf, and Pacific coasts, includiug Alaska. In accordance wit11 the uniform practice of the Department, requests from natioual or S t a b authorities for special surveys, or for tlie detail of oflicers for special service, have been complied with wl~eneverpracticable, and the fbllowing operations have in this way bee11 undertaken and completed: A sl>ccialhydrographic survey of the Dry Tortugas deep-water anchorage aud its approaches, a t the request of the Xavy Department; the erection of beacons on the north shore of Long Island for the Long Island Sound speetl trial course, a t the request of the l~onorahle Secretary of the Navy; cooperation with the Navy Department in the erectiou of beacons on the coasts of Maine aud Massachusetts for the speed-trial course of t l ~ e Ivtdiana arid Katahdin; cooperation with the Navy.Department in the laying out and marking of a speed-trial course in Santa Barbara Channel for the new battle ship Oregon; a special topographical survey on a large scale of the grounds of the Naval Academy a t Annapolis, for tht: Navy Departmellt; cooperation with the United States Geological Survey in the determination of the telegraphic difference of lot~gitude between San Francisco, Cal., :ind 1Sllensburg, Wash. A t the request of the oom~nissioners appointed by the United States Supreme Court, two officers of the Survey were detailed to examine and retrace a portioli of the boundary line between the States of 3lissouri aud Iowa. Special assignmcrtt8.-The assignments of two of the assistants of the Survey to special duty by appoir~tlnent of the President have been co~~tinuod, one as a lneluber of the Mississippi Itiver Colnmission and the other as a member of the Iuternational Boundary Commission organized for tlle survey and marking of that part of the United States and nfexican boundary line extending aestwa~d from El Paso. The latter officer, however, performed regular coast-survey service from the beginnir~gof the fiscal year until October 1, the date fixed for the reasselubling of the Boundary Commissiol~. Ofice work.-In tlie ofice the usual progress bas been mado in the reduction and computstion of the field results, in the drawing, engraving, ;bud preparing for publicatior~the charts of the Survey, the Coast Pilot, and the annual tide tables, and there has been no abatement of the efforts to give the public the earliest notice of iml)orta~~t changes or discoveries. The montllly issue of Notices to Mariners has been co~~tinued, and during tho year 121 000 copies mere distribissue, during the same time, of charts, Coast Pilots, aud Tide Tables has beeu uted gratis. T l ~ e as follows: Chal-ts. G4 541; Coast Pilots, 848; Tide Tabla, G SSO. Ofice o f Standard IIreiglbts and Meaeure8.-This important ofice, also under the charge of the Superintendent of the Coast and Geodetic Survey, has been collductecl as heretofore, aud notwithstanding its small force, prompt response l ~ a s been n ~ a d o to all requests for information, aud the usual amount of work in testiug, ~erifying,and standardizing weights and measures for other departments of the Government, for States, arid for private parties has been accomplished. Some progress has also been made in the acquiring of electrical standards and in the prepara. tion for undertaking the determillation aud verification of electrical units. This work is necessarily slow on n c c o u ~ of ~ t limited means, the whole annual appropriatiou for the purchase of matorial and apparatus and for incidental expenses being only $500. Among the operations carried on during the year the following may be specially mentioned as of the greatest importance: First. The construction of the 60.met1.e comparator, by means of which n higher d e g e e of precision in the determination of linear values is possible, and with a much less exl~enditure of time and labor. Second. The standardization, by means of this 60-metro comparator and a standard in ice, of the new duples base apparatus. This base apparatus mas desigued by one of the Assistants of the Survey, and was elltirely coiiutructed in the Survey instrument shop, and it id believed that it mil1 yield results far superior to any other base apl~aratus yet devised for rapid and economical

REPORT FOR 1896-PART

1.

3

fleld work. One prominelit feature of the apparatus is its yielding two simultaneous measures of a baae by rods of two diflerent metals with widely different coefficients of expalision, so that the temperatures car1 be deduced more accurately tllan by indications of thermometers. Tlie difficulty of obtaining the true temperature of the bars during a lneasure has heretofore been the greatest sourco of uncertainty in primary bases. International Geodetic Conference.-As official notification had been received that a t the General Conference of tho International Geodetic Association t o be held a t Berlin, Germally, in October, 1895,l~ropositions to modify the terms of the International Geodetic Convention of 1886 would be considered, it was deemed of the utlriost importance that tlie Coast and Geodetic Survey should bo represented by a delegate and participate in the deliberations. Accordingly Assistaut 0. H. Tittmann w:is appointed as dolegate by tho President of tlie United States, and in accordance with instructions sailed for Europe on the 17th of Sopternber, arriving in 13erli11 ill tinle to attend the opening meeting on the 30th. The llleetings of the Coiiferenco lasted until October 12. Essential modifications of tlie terms of the existing treaty were agreed upon for subluission to the several Goverl~ments concerned, the principal ones being as follows: First, a lnoro equitable distribution of votes; s e c o ~ ~ the d , abolition of the permanent Commission, and the substitution therefor of an executive board, with a consultntive comlnissio~ion which every participating country sliall be represented; allti third, an illcrease of the annual budget, with a view to establishing statiolls for observing the variation of latitude. Mr. Tittmann returned soon after the close of the meetings, and on November 4 resumed his duties as Assistalit in Chargo of the Ofice. Arrangement o f this Report.-Tlio contouts of Part 1 are arranged in the following order: Introductory statement, including notico of fidd slid ofice work, special assigi~meuts, Offico of Standard Weiglits and Measures, arrangement of this Report, and geographical order and classification of localities of field work; General statement of progross ill field and ofice worlc, including subdivisions of tho former and ~iotices of publications of the Survey during tho year; Explanations of estimates for the fiscal year 1898, and the estiulates tliemselves in detail; Abstracts of reports from field parties, including Eastern, Middle, Western, and Alaslto divisions, and special operutions; Abstracts of office aud suboffice aul~ual reports; Supplementary tables, viz, No. 1, Showing tho distribution and personnel of field parties, No. 2, Giving statistics of field and offlco work, No. 3, Giving list of informatiou furnislied during tho year in reply to official and 1)erson:il calls; Ofice annual reports, yiz, No. 1,Report of the Assista~it in Charge of tho Office, accompanied by reports of tho various chiefs of divisions, No. 2, ltcport of tho liydrogrsphic inspector, No. 3, lteport of the disbursing agent, No. 4, Report of the Assistant iu Cliargo of the Oflico of Standard Weights and Measures; List of maps and progress sketches to illustrate tl:e morlc, and the maps and sketches themselves. Part I1 co~itains the Appendices and tlieir illustrations, tlie Appendices being professional papers relating to lnethods, discussions, ancl results. and scie~itific Geograpliical classificatin)~ o f locrrlilies qf .field ~corli.--Thu samo geographical c1:~ssification of localities in use since 1591 has been retained in this lteport, viz: I. The Easter11 Division, includiug a11 States east of the n1ississipl)i ltiver. 11. and also by the branch hydrographic offices of the Navy Ilepartment, the United States customhouses, and the United States consulates in toreign ports. Bulletins.-But oue bulletin mas issued during the year, viz, No. 35, coiltaining general information in regard to certain parts of Alaska. It is, in fact, a co~npilationof the most receilt information relative to the harbors, a~lchorages,and dangers to uavigation in the vicinity of Ohatham and Peril straits and Cooks Inlet. The data iu rel:ltion to the latter locality are derived from the notes of Prof. W. H. Dall, of the U~iitetlStates Geological Survey, and those relating to Chatham and Peril straits from actual surveys by the United States Const and Geodetic Survey. As considerable time necessarily elapses before the results of a survey can be given to the navigator in chart form, and no complete or reliable Coast Pilot of the Alaskan coast exists, the early publication of valuable information in bnlletin form is tleemed of the utmost importance. Other bulletins of n similar natiire, for other Alaska11 localities, mill be issued from time to time as material for them is obtained.

REPORT FOR 1896-PART

I.

EXPLANATION OF ESTIMATES.
The estimates submitted to the Secretary of the Treasury for the fiscal year 1898 were accompanied by the followiilg explanations: U. S. COASTAND GEODETICSURVEY, OFFIUE O F THE SUPERINTENDENT, Washijtgton, D. C., October 2, 1896. SIR: I have the honor to transmit herewith estimates for the work of the United States Coast and Geodetic Survey and Office of Construction of Standard Weights aud Measures for the fiscal year encling Jnne 30, 1895. An increased amount has beeu asked for "delti expenses" to provide for urgently needed surveys and resurveys, including, among other important objects, the resurvey of Galveston Bay, for which an appropriation of $10 000 is asked, to be available until expended, and a reconnaissance along the Pacific coast from Cape Mel~docino to. tho Straits of Juan de Fuca. The item for Lbcontribution to the International Geodetic Association" has been omitted, as i t is thought that this object should he estimated for by the Department of State, and orrangemelits hove beon suggestetl to effect the change. Tho estimate for "repairs and maintenance of vesselsv has beeu increased by the amount of $10 000, to be immediately available, to provide for the construction of new boilers for the steamer Blake. The present boilers are moru out beyond repaiq. An appropriatiori of $75 000 is asked for commencing the construction of a new stealnor for service in Al'wka and tlle Aleutian island^. Such a vessel is absolutely necessary for the exploration and survey of the Aleutian Islauds and northwestern Alaska. The Survey has no vessel of either sufficient power or strength to safely engage upon that work. Under the head of uSalaries7' an addition of $1 000 is aslied in the item for salary of SuperG 000, as provided by statute. This was the amount appropri'ated until the intendent, making it $ year 1895-96, when $5 000 was appropriated. The follomilig changes in the office force are recom~ncnded:The designations "clerk to the Snljerintsndent" and '(clerlr. to the Assistant in Cllarge of tlie Office and Topography" to be abolished, and these positions to be included under tho general head of "Clerical force," a t tlie st1mo rates of pay. These positions are now in the classifieti service, from which they were formerly exceptecl. Under the liead of "Chart correctors, buoy colorists, etc.," it is proposed to promote one f r ~ m $1 200 to $1380 per annuln-n well-merited advancement-and to transfer to this designation one p1:tto printer at $1000, whose present duties relate more especially to chart corrections. Under the head of "Topographic and hydrographic draftsnien," it is proposed to promote one fyom $900 to $1 0 0 per a~inum. Of tliose classified as "astronon~ical,geodetic, tidal, and nliscellnneous computers," the promotion of two from $1 400 to $1 GOO and of one from .$l 200 to $1 400 per annum is recommended. Tlie estimates have been so modifled as to provide for these 1)roposed changes. Of the Lielectrotypors a~icl photograpliers, plate printers ;mri their helpers, instrunlent makers, etc.," it is proposed to advance four from $1 000 to $1 100 per auunnl each, and one from $700 to' 8900 per aunum, and to drop oue a t $700. Theso changes are intendoc1 in order to make the mtes of coinpensation correspond more nearly with the rates paid for ~irnilar services elsewhere. A reduction of $600 is made ill the estimate for bLoffice expenses."

I n the estimate for Office of Constructioli of Standard Weights and Measures," it is recommended to increase the force by one expert, to be c:llled a verifier, for tllc purpose of taking ixi hand the verification of electrical standards. Colipress llus taken a first step toward establisliing electrical standards by legalizirig units of electricril measure, but no provisio~lhas beeu nlade to enable the office to make verifications ill conformity mith the lam for the benefit of tlio public concerned. Tile increase in the salary of the present adjuster has bee11 recommended time axid again on accourit of hi$ efficient services, and the recommendntion of an increase from $1500 to $1800 is here repeated as more commeusurate mith tlie service rendered. The pay of an assistant messeuger, whose duties are better designated by the word " helperv than by the old title, is recomxnellded for increase from $720 to $000 per annum. These ohanges would put the Office of Weights and Measures on approximateIy the same footing on which i t wa,s prior to 1887, in which year the office of verifier was abolished. Moslr~anand G. It. Putnam, in accordance with iiistructions, 1)roceeded to Cambridge, Mass., alid Oalais, Me., respectively, for the purpose of determinii~g the diderelice of loligitude between the two points. Assista~lt hlosxna~~, accon~pa~iied by Assistant Homer 1'. Ritter, reached Cambridge mere a t on the lGth, and Assistant Putliam arrived a t Calais on the 17th. Tlle two ob~ervatories ouce erected and connected rvith the Western Uriion lines, a ~ i d observations began on the 21st. Exchanges of' tilrle sigrials took place o m the nights of August 2 1 , 5 , 2 7 , and 30, and September 1, and again, after the usual iiltercharige of observers, ou September 5,8,10,13, and 14. Assistant Putnam also made a t Calais three days' observ;itionti for the determination of tlie rnagnetic declination, dip, and intensity, and two days' p e n d ~ ~ l uobservations m for the deterruinatioli of the force of gravity. The maguetic observations \rere obtained 0x1 August 22,23, and 24, and the peiidulum observations on August 22 and 23, the observations for both being so arranged a s not to interfere with or delay the longitude work. The parties returned to Washington on September 18, and were ellgaged until October 10 ill computing the results of thi8 and previous mork, after which Messrs. l'utnani and Ritter were assigned to duty in tile Weights and Measures Office and computing divisioli, respectively, and Assistant Jlosmaii resnmed his duties as member Mexico International Boundary Commission. of the United States a~lci Bydrograp7iic surveys and e.raminations on tile coast o f .llcru.sacltziscft~.-The steamer Uacke, Lieut. Robert G. Peck, U. S. K., columanding, after erectiug beacoiis on the north shore of Long Island, as described under t h e head of " Special oper:itions," :knd carrying the Superintendent of the Coast and Geodetic Survey slid tlie Hydrographic Inspector on a tour of inspectioil to h'ew Bedford, Ilyaunis, and Bosto~i to visit t h e topographic and hydrographic parties a t mork in tllose localities, flnally reached Boston on the erenilig of July 30,1895. 9 fern days were spent in preparing the steam lauilch stored a t tlie Boston Navy-Yard for service and ill obtainil~g water after which the Uaciie proceeded to Cohassst axid began and other lieedecl supplies for the sl~il), the season's worlr. The list of naval offlcers attached to the party was as follows: Lieut. Commander H. G. 0 . Colby in comlnand, Lieut. J. A. Sheaman, Lieut. W. S. Benson, Ensign A. T. Long, Asst. Surg. B. R. Ward, and Pay Yeoman \Ir. S. Crosby. Ites~irveyo f Buzzards Bay, ~inssac1~zisetts.-A resurvey of Buzzards I3ay being urgently needed on account of the liuuerous changes reported since the 1)revious survey of fifty years ago, four topographical parties arid one hydrographic party were assigned to duty in this region just before the close of the last fiscal year. The four topographical parties were under the charge of ) . B. Wainwright, J. A. Plemer, Ste1im:in Forney, and TV. I,Vinal, respectively, arid Assistants 1 the hydrographic party under the charge of Lieut. G. C. IIanus, U. S. N., commanding the schooner Eagre. To the latter was : ~ s s i p e dtho hydrographic surveg of New Bedford Harbor and its approaches, while to the four shore parties were assigned eight topographic sheets, laid out in sequence to embrace the shores of the bay arid a strip of topography varying in width from 1to 3 miles, from the mestorli part of the entrance to Swifts Hill arid Falmouth Village; the topography and shore line on the peninsula between the latter poiiits arid Woods Hole and the outlying islands of X'aushon, I'asque, Nashawena, mid Cuttyhunk were not included in this sea80n's scheme. I t mas hoped that the n.hole of' the topograpliical worlc above outlinetl could be completed during the suurlner and autulllr~,but owing to the scanti~~ess of the appropriation, and the necessity of reserving a portio~ifor urgelit work on the Southern coast during the winter, tlie parties were obliged to disband by the end of October, leaving considerable aroas to be completed during the following year. The reports of the several chiefs of parties are noticed separately in the paragraphs imnlediately following, and the results and tabulated statistics of each are there given. Topog~upI~ical vesurvey of Bitzzards Bay, ~1Iassacl~usetts.-Nezo BeuorJ c~nd A1fattapoiset sheeta.To Assistant D. B. Wainwright were assigned the Nen- Redford and Mattal~oisetsheets, the former extending from Moshers l'oint, a t the southwest point of the entrance of Clarks Cove, to Sconticut Neck, aiid irlcluding the city of Kew Bedford and the villages of Fairhaven and Acushnet, and the latter este~iding from Sconticut Neck to Angelica Point. As mnlly of the old trigonometric points were, from various causes, not recoverable, it was necessary to execute a supplemental plane-table triangulation to determine a sufficient ~ i u ~ n b of e r ~iew'poilits to properly control the topography, and this work first received attention. Tlle wharf lilies of Yew Bedford and Fairhaven and the ~ h o r o lirle of Acuahnet River were uest delineated, as these were required for tho use of the hydrographic party operatirig in the same locality, slid afterwards the prilicipal streets of New Bedford were run out with the plane table so as to furnish the draftsmell of the party with the proper data for reducing and platting tho city map. Tho regular detailed topography was then taken up and carried from JIoshers Point to Sco~lticut Neck, thus c o u p l e t i ~ ~ tile g first sheet. The second sheet was begun early in September, and 011 this also the illterpolation of additional poiuta mas found necessary before the topography proper could be executed. The work was carried on continuously until October 30, when, in accordanc:e with instructions, field operations cea~ed, the party mas disbanded, and Mr. Wainwright returned to Washington, D. C. The second sheet was by that date completed nearly up to Mattapoiset Neck, leaving the portion betmeell that point and Angelica Point for allother season. The topographic features of this portioil of the bay are described by Mr. Wainwright as consisting of a series of narrow and shallow valleys, running normal, or ap])roximately so, to the coast line and aeparated by narrow and low ridges, the latter in some cases projecting outw:\rd

I.

ABSTRACTS O F REPORTS FROM FIELD PARTIES.

15

several miles illto the bay, forming peninsulas which :me locally termed '' necks." Onring to the sma,ll drainage area of any one valley, the streams, with tho single exception of the Acushliet River, are insignificant, alid in a dry season like the, past summer are very 111uch shruliken and withont perceptible current. l n tho vicinity of New Bedford the coulltry is divlded illto small farms, a i d these are dividetl and subdivided by stolie dikes and walls. From present indications, however, it seerus probable tlint this characteristic form of fencing will sooii disappear, ae farlners in tlio vicinity of the llem State highways now in process of construction have found i t profitable to cart the stone to tlle crushers, and t,liere dispose of i t a t so much per ton. Farther to the east~vardthe country is less open, and large, nrooded areas exist, in which the maplo and scrub oak prodominate. Alo~lgthe sl~ores, a t points esposed to current aild wave action, there are i'ohnd evidences of slow erosion, ill the existence of shingle beaches and outlyillg rocks; the illward bends and coves are skirted by salt marslies: upon which are scattered boulders transported thither from ~~eiphboring beaches by the minter ice durilig high stor111tides. The valley near the mouth of which are located the city of New Bedford and tho villages of Fairhaven and Acushnet, a,lthongli the largest in the locality, has olily a moderite drainage area and does not discharge an ercessivo alnou~it of fresh water into the liarbor, and as its streams all reaches tide water. Tlle changes in pass through orie or more lakes or ponds very little sedirne~it the liarbor fro111this sourco aro thorefore very slow and gradual. The weather during tho season mas quito favorable for field work, the rainfall being much below the average and generally occurriiig either at night or on Sunclays, but the prevailing southwest minds occasionally blew mith sucll st,rengtli that a temporary suspe~ision of field mork mas necessary. All members of the party performecl their duties very satisfactorily, but nlessrs. R. J. McAdory aud George Taylor receive especial comnieud:ttion in Mr. Wain~rright's report; the former served as fbrelnau and tho latter as recorder and draftsnian. mater ponds; eroded gravel banks; bowlders; low saud dunes; tracts of marsh, some of n-hich hatre been reclaimed for cranberry cultivation; open and village detail; summer resorts and residerices; railroads; country roads, and roads not classified as public highways; wooded hills, etc. Tlie accurate delineation of elovati011 contours was in some places quite difficult on account of the underbrush and dense second growth of deciduous timber, and conside~.ablecutting aud trimming out was necessary. Along the shores are numerous detached and outlying rocks, and as many of these aro visible only a t low water, more than ordinary care was required in surveying Clle coast line. Tho small harbors along this part of the coast afford shelter fro111wind and sea for numerous pleasure yachts, but are seldom entered by trading vessels of any considerable size; the entrance to Hog lsland (Chappaquoit) Harbor was buoyed for the first time in July of this year. Tho party remained in tho field throughout the minter, and sonlo work mas accom~lishedduring each month, excepting January and Febrnary, the hydrograplly of Now Bedford Harbor and its approaches being completed 011tho lGth of April. The patty was then engaged for a tilllo on current and tidal observations, after which tho vessel was moved to Marion, where preparations were mado for the resurvey of tho head of Buzzards Bay. Five additional current stations, and nine comparative tidal stations, were occupied, and about 150 tlignzls mere erected and determined, after which tllo regular sounding work of the head of the bay began on May 14 and \$,as continued uutil the close of the fiscal year. During January and Pebruary, when no field work mas ])ossible, tho vessel's boats mere orerhauled, the boilers of the steam la~inches mere repaired, and sncli refittiug as tlio ~ c s s e l required was attended to. Tlie aids to navigation, such as lights, buoys, ranges, and promi~lent landmarks, were also carefully deterruined, and are likewise mentioned ill det,ail in his descriptive report. For the Now Bedford Iiarbor and approaches work a primary tide gauge mas established on the sheltered side of the stone pier a t Clark Poin',, and six secondary or staff gauges mere located a t convenient places as tlio work advanced, and frequently co~upared directly with tho standard. Tozcn boundary line surcqa o f the State o f Massachusetts, co?tti?~ued under the direction o f the Topographical Survey Conm~issio?~ o f the State.-Assistaut Henry L. Whiting, during the fiscal year, continued to serve as chairman of the Topographical Survey Commission of the State of Massachusetts, and took personal charge of t h o general management of the field and office mork relating to the Town Boundary Survey. Three field parties were engaged on the work--one under the charge of Mr. James B. Tolley in executing :I secondary triangulation in the central and southern parts of tho State; the second uuder tho charge of Mr. Eugene E. l'eirce in the southeastern part of the State, mainly in Bristol and Plymouth counties, determining new bonndary lines formed by the subdivision of former townships; and the third under the charge of Mr. F. E. Bowman, on similar work in Barnstable County. The amount and detail of the work did not vary materially from those of former years, and about the same amount of offlco work was executed. As heretofore, the original descriptions of the main triangulation stations, n-it11 sketches, their geographical positions, and other. data necessary for the prosecution of the work, have been furnishexl to the State Commissioli by the Coast and Geodetic Survey Office. Assistant Whiting also continued to serve as a member of the Mississippi River Commission, and attended the various meetings of that body during the year. The first meeting took place on and the semiannual inspection of November 5, 1895, a t St. Louis, on board the U. Exa?ttinatwtt o f n reported datbger to ttavigatiott in tibe lbarbor o f Bristol, 12. I.-In Decen~ber, 1895, a notice was received a t this office fro111Mr. Nathaniel G. Herreshoft; of Bristol, 1%.I., that a scorn sloop, carrying a deck load of granite blocks, had capsized i u the east channel of the harbor and dumped about 25 tons of the rock, thus creating a serious danger to navigation. Lieut. G . C. Hauus, who mas engaged on tho hydrographic resurvey of Buzzards Bay, mas directed to investigate the matter arid locate the obstruction on the chart. He proceeded a t ouce to Bristol, taking mith him one member of his crew, and after consultation with Mr. Herreslioff, who knew the approximate location of tho accident, hired a boat, and, assisted by the keepers of the Bristol Ferry aucl Nuscle light-houses, made a careful examination. Tlie whole vicinity indicated was souuded with the lead, aud subsequeutly i t was dragged over mith a grapnel, bot no trace of the stones could be found. The bottom was found to bu very soft, imd Lieute~iar~t Hauus concluded that the heavy rocke had deeply embedded themselves in the mud; Iio recommends, however, a further examination a t a more favorable sessou of the year, as different persons with whom he afterwards conferred do not agree as to the locatio~i of the dumping. On the completion of the ex:tmination Lieutenant Hanus returned to Xem Bedford and resumed his duties as commancler of the Eagre. The topography was then executed, a strip averaging 1 mile in nriclth being surveyed on both sides of the river to the line MiltonCamelot, the southern limit of the morlr of the other party. On tlie west side of the river the topography was somewhat intricate and the contouring difficult, as vineyards covered the hillsides, and orchards to a large extent the valleys and lom areas; on the eastern side the work was simpler, tlie chief difficulties being met in the parked inclosures ancl ornamental grounds of wealthy proprietors. Coxtinztatio7t o f the topogrccplbic szwrcy o f t1~eHTL~SON River (zici)~it?/ o f Pot(gl~keeysie).-The Party of Assistant W. 0. Hodgkilis mas organized a t Pougi~lceepsie and began operations July 1. >Iany of the old trigonometric stations conlcl not be recovered, and others had become useless on accoulit of erection of buildiligs, growth of shade trees, etc., so that it was necessary to execute a subsidiary triarlgulatio~ito furnish the requisite number of points for topographic use. Blackfisli Bank, oft' Assateague Island, TTirginia: In May, 1896, Lieut. R. Q. I'eck, while en route from the Gulf Coast to New York, made a hydrographic examination of the Blackfish Bank of?' The great distance of tllis shoal from slioro niakes i t a very serious danger to navigation, :uicl prompt notice of its existencewas therefore given in our Kotices to Mariners. Progress Sketches, showing the locnlities of field work in the Middle Division, will be foiund a t the close of Part I. Tricmgulatio~r o f Lake Po?rtcI~artruin, Louisiana.-In December, 1S95, Assistant P. A. Welker was directed to proceed to l'ensacola, Fla., where the schooner Quick was laid up, ant1 orgauize a Party for the survey of Lake l'ontchartrain. Mr. Welker reached Pensacola on the Gth of January, 3896, ant1 by the 14th the vessel was 1-eadyfor see, and started for Lake Pontchartrain, reaching the morlting ground 011 January 20. The remainder of the month was spent in ~naliing a reconnaissance and ill deciding upon a practicable scheme for executing the work. Owing to the flatness of the coutltry atid the great width of the lake tho ordinary methods of triangulation mould l a v e been very expensive, as signals of great height would have been required and the opportunities for the accurate obsrrviug of such long lines would have been comparatively inl'requent. Xeither could a smaller scheule of triangles aud quadrilaterals a l o ~ ~ the g shores be resorted to on account of the immense amount of cntting required, tho cou~ltry in the vicinity of the lake being for the most part densely wooded and swampy, the cypress swamps it1 some sectiorls sstei~dingto the water's edge. Tlle cutting of innun~erablu1i11es through these heavily timbered swamps mould probably havo entailed even a greater expense than carryiug the larger scheme of figures across the lake. It was decided, therefore, to build signals from 1s to 40 feet in height a t suitable intervals along the shores and to erect temporary signals in the shallow waters, from 2 to 3 miles from shore. The shore signals mere occupied and obsorved from in the usual manner, the angles a t tho water stations being all concluded. In this way triangulation, suficiently accurate for the future topographic and hydrogra.phic survey&, was obtained a t a reasonable cost. The season's work began a t the l'ontchartrain Light-House, that being the only determined point of the old triaugulation of the eastern.end of the lake that could be found. A base line 733.28 metres ill length was measured a t West End, a subarb of New Orleans, about 4 miles west of the above-mentioned light-house, and the azimuth of tho line n7as determined astronomically. This base lirio and azimuth and tho determined latitude and longitude of the light-house constituted the data upon which the trigoaometric survey is based. Satisfactory progress mas made vith the work, notwitstanding tho difficulties arising from the unstable foundations on which the observing tripods and scaffolds were built, which llecessitated the suspensiot~ of observations whenever the wind blew with auy consiclerable gtrengtl~. The scheme of triangulation mas laid out a11 the way round the lake to Raggedy Point, the juuction point with the old work, but tho observations were orlly cornpletecl to Shanty Point, or a little more thau half tho distance reconnoitred. Observations mere also made for magnetic declination whenever practicable without delaying the trigonometric work. Assistant John Nelson, Aid Charles C. Yates, and Recorder G. W. Nelson were attached to the party during the season and rendered valuable and efficient service. Work closed on the 17th of April, and after disbanding party aud lnaking suitable provision for tho care of the vessel, Assistant Welker and Messrs. Nelson, Yates, aud Nelson returned to Washington.

Mr. IVellrer states in liis report that the country surrounding Lake Poutchartrain is almost entirely of a marshy or swampy character; along the southern shore there is a belt from 1 to 3 lniles \vide of soft marsh covered with grass and weeds 10 to 12 feet lligli and mitli scattering willows from 10 to 40 feet high; back of this belt are imxueusu cypress swamps. On the northwest and northern shores, as far as Chefuncte River, the cypress swiinlps estelid nearly or quite to the shore line, and in this locality water rlavigation ~ ~ i t h 2 in miles of uhore is dangerous on account of the numerous snags and sunlren trees. He also experienced sonic difficulty on accounl, of the 11envy seas produced by t l ~ e prevailing easterly minds. These minds have a clear, uninterrupted sweep of 40 miles, and when fresh or strong render Iauclings on the west shore impracticable. Orleane, La., and incidental magnetic and gravity determinations.-At the close of the last fiscal year tlie parties engaged in the telegraphic determinations of longitudes in various Southwestern States had reached Austin, Tex., and New Orleans, La., respectively, and 11ad obtained three ~iights' observations and exchanges of time signals. Work was then tem1)orarily susl)eudeti, pending the arrival of Assistant A. T. bfosman, wl~ohad been detailed to relieve Assistant Eclwiu Smlth, whose counectiou with tho Survey ceased on June 30. Assistant lllosmnn arrived a t New Orleans on July 2, and was joined thero by Assistaut I'utnalu on the 4th. After readjusting the iustrun~e:its observations were made for personal equ:~tionthe same night, and 3Ir. Putnam returned on the following day to Austin. Exchanges of signals betmeeu Kern Orleans and Austin wore obtained on the nights of July 8,13,14, and 15,and again after thb usual interchange of observers on tho nights of July 23,24,26, and 28. The weather a t New Orleans mas very unfavorable, seven anti preventi~~g observatioils, while the sky a t Austin was clear consecutive nights being clo~tdy on all of them save one. Mr. G. A. Pairfield, extra observer, was assigned to Assistant Mosman's party, and arrived a t New Orleans on July 14. H e reulained with Mr. hIosmaii to the close of the work, and mas subsequently trtxusferred to Assistant Perkin's party in Slabama. Magnetic observations mere made by Assistant I'utnam a t Kew Orloa~is on July 19,23, and 24, and pendulum observations for the determiuation of gravity on the 24th unc2 25t11,the observations beilig so arranged as not to interfere with or delay tho Longitude morlr. Their work there belonging geogrnpliically to the Eastern Division, will bc treated of under that head. Tidal record a t Port Eads, La.-Through the courtesy of the TJnited States ei~gineerofficers stationed a t Port Eads, La., we have been enabled to secure from the nutonlatic tidal record of that station a tabulation of the l~ourly ordir~ates for the calendar jear 1896. Zstablishment o f a tidal station nt I'oi7~tIsabel, Texas.-Early ill MarcL, 1896, Assistant E. B. L a t h a ~in , accordance wit11 instructions, proceeded to l'oiut Isabel, Texas, for tho purpose of establishing there a tidal station. A Stierle self-registering gauge mas set up in tlio lZraaos Island Light-House, and a staff gauge was also located. Thesemerc referred to permanent bench marks, three of mhich mere located on Padre Island and four on the mainland. A tidal observer was e~rgaged, and after fully instructing hiin ill his duties blr. lJathau~proceeded, on Marc11 19, to Port Royal, S. C. The establishmerit of a tidal station a t the latter 1)oint has been mentioned in a previous part of this report, under the proper geographical heading. Transcontinental geodetic zco~k.-Xxu?)~ inatiolb o f a 11ropow"dbae liine in 11Nssouri.-In May,1896, Assistant A. 'L. Baldwin, in accordance with instructiolis, proceeded to Versailles, Mo., for tho purpose of examining the base line previously selected iu that vicinity, with a view to deteril~ilii~~g its practicability. This base line was ono of those intended for verification of the transcontinenti~l triangulation, a l ~ d its ends had already been connected therewith, but the actual lneasuremel~t had been postpo~~ed fronl time to tinic for various reasolls, chiefly on account of insufficier~tn1q)ropriations. Mr. Baldwin found the terminal marks undisturbed, and ran over tlie base \vit11 a Icrel, but found that three barns llacl been constructed directly on the line. Owing to tliis circuntstanco ant1 tlie existence of other difficulties, which i t was thought would nwke the measure of the base unduly espensive, i t was decided to abandon the line, and Mr. Baldwin was notified to that ed'ect by telegraph. He mas then directed to proceed to Salins, Kans., and report to Assistant F. D. Granger for duty in the transcontinental geodetic party operating in that locality, and nrrivcld there on the 3d of June. His services in this party have already been mentioiled in tho preceding paragraph. f precise levels, Kunsas.--Under the Superiute~~cle~rt's Continuation o f the transcontinental line o instructioxls of June 24, 1S95, Assistant Isaac Winston proceeded to Lawrerrce, J<anu., reaching that point July 9, and organized a party for the continuation of the transcontinental line of ? . Weld, J. R. Chase, and F. S. C . Hunter, who had been assigned to geodetic leveling. Messrs. I the party by the Office, reported the same clay, and on the lot11 two additional me11 mere secured and the instruction of the various members in their respective dutles began. Mr. Guy Rainey also reported for duty in the party July 20. The actual leveling commeucetl on tho l l t h , the starting point of the season beiug a t Holliday, Kans., where two permanent bench marks had beer1 previously established (in 1891). Thesa bench marks mere found undisturbed and in good condition. The route followed was along tlle roadbed of tlle Atcliison, Topeka aud Santa F e Railroad to Topeka, a t which point a crossing of the I<ansas River was made, aud work closed a t tlie latter point thence along the Union Pacific Railroad to Salina. Tho ~eason's October 26,1895. Two simultaneous liues were run over the whole distauce, and the running mas continuously in one direction; geodetic level No. 5 aud the new parafined \vooden rods P. & Q. were used throughout the season. Permanent bench marks were established a t all towns and villages along the route where suitable stone or brick buildings could be found on which to place them, and on stone piers and abutments of railroad bridges, and tem1)orary bench marks were placod a t intervals of about I kilometre. Tlic latter served the double purpose of furiiisiiiiig frequent checks on the correctness of tlie work by means of tlie comparisons of tho two liues, and of minimizing tho a~nouut of rerueasurement required when discrepancies developed. As an indicatioli of the care with wllich tlie work as osocuted, it lnay be lierc stated that but few remeasuremerits were found necessary during the season. Railtvay trains furnished the means of daily trnnsportation of the party until Topoka mas reached, but west of that point, t l ~ e trains being infrequent and not suitably timed, the hire of a wag011a i ~ ttea111 l of horses was found necessary. Tlie ~elocipedo cars, successf~illy used elsewhere by thc loveling party, could have beeu advantageo~~sly employed iu this section, and in future will be utilized wherever practicable, when the consent of the railmay officials can be obtained. No special dificulties mere encountered during the season, escept those arising froin tlie previiiling strong winds. Tho minds in this region blow drnost coutinnously (luring many rnoutlie of tlle year, and on some days caused an entire cessatiori of work, while on many others the progress observation ~g was was seriously delayed. A resort to wire or rope guys to snpport tho rods t l r ~ r i ~ unavoidable, aud tlio securing of tlie rerlnisite stability of the leveling instruments ~ r aamatter ~ of considerable diiliculty. Mr. Wil~storilias since had co~~strncteci an observing tent, to the open base of n7llicll arc e track. The c a ~ ~ vsupported as on n light detacliable frnrne attached paper wheels fitting t l ~ railway furnishes complete protection from botli sun and wind, and can be opened i r k :LIIY desired direction for observiilg. One Inan can easily trundle this car tent along tho track fiom station to et:~tion, and two me11can readily remove it fro111the track on the appro;rcli of a tr:till. This device will be used next season, and will doubtless mucll facilitate and expedite the work in windy weather.

Gilbert assisted in the investig:itio~~s conliected with the proposed transfer of the Lafayette Park Astronomical Observatory to a more suitable location, preparecl plans and specifications for the new building, and co~inected the new station trigonometrically with the old, arid with the triangulation of San Francisco Bay. On June 16, ill accordance with instructions, he proceeded to Utah and reported to Assistant Willianl Eirnbeck for duty under his direction on tlie transcontinental geodotic work. Geor7etic zcor1i.-Continuatiolt o f the transcontinental triai~yulntiolt i u Colorado.-At tho close of the last fiscal year Assistant F. U. Granger mas engaged on the occupation of Big Springs, a primary station of the great transcontinental sclieme of triangulation, and had just completed a reconnaissance for the location of a secorldary point between Big Springs and I'lateau, resulting in the selection of Dry Camp. The observations a t Rig Springs were finished by Jnly 13, and determinecl tho horizontal directions :~nd elevations of four primary, one secondary, and a number of tertiary points, tlie primary stations beiug Cramera Gulch, Plateau, Pikes Peak, aud Divide, and the secondary station the newly selectccl point, Dry Camp. The instruments and camp Irere the11 trarisferretl to Divide Station, located in El Paso County, about 3 miles east of Eastonville, a small town on the Gulf Railroad. Tlie proparatioris for occupation were completed by July 24, and tlio observations mere begun or1 the following day and finished on August 23. Three primary stations (Big Springs, Pikes Peak, and Bison Peal;), two seco~idaries (Mounts Rlorrison and Table), ancl twenty-five tertiaries mere thus determined, both as to horizontal direction and elevation. The line to llount Morrison, mliich is represented on the published sltetch of tho Colorado recorinaissance as unobstracted, \vas founcl to be cut o b by trees on interveni~ig ridges, but fortun:ltely, after an examiriati~n of tho line by the recorder of the party, Mr. J. 13. Boutelle, the cutting of an avenue tlirougli the timber mas found to be practicable, and the visibility of tlis station wax thus secured. Observations on this l~oint were of great importauce, iriasmucli as tlio'trigonometric connectioll with tlie Chamberlin Observatory :tt Denver mas in a loeasure dependent thereon. On t l ~ cornpletiol~ e of tlie observations a t Divirle, Assistant Granger stored a portion of Ilia camp equipage a t Enstonville, and with a reclnced party, cor~sistingof Foreman E. E. Torrey, 11 driver, a cook, and two hands, and a limited outfit, proceeded to Cramers Gulch, arrivilig there on the evening of September 3. Tile preparation8 for occupation, including tlle erectioii of a 20 foot observing tripod arid scaffold, mere finished by September' 6, and the observations, which were begun on the following day, mere completecl on the 17th. The party and outfit mere then transferred to Station Platean, where observations mere begun on the 24th of September and concluded on the Gth of October. A t Cramera Gulch arid Plateau two primaries and five tertiaries and three primaries and two tertiat ies, respectively, mere observed, and the horizontal direction of the secondary station, Dry Camp, mas determined.

Coj~tinuatioao f I~yd~ograpl~ic and general surveys i u A1asku.-At the close of the last fiscal year the party on the steamer l'atterson, under the commalid of Lieut. Commttnder E. li. Moore, G. S, N., mas engaged in the survey of Chatham and Peril straita and the adjacent bays and inlets, and had made excellent progress. The survey was continued uninterruptedly during the present year until October 2, and a large amount of worlr was accomplished, the \?arious branches being assigned to different oilicers of the party. The general assignment of duty mas as follows: To Lieut. A. G. Itogers, the tidal observatio~is and base-line measurements; to Lieut. It. F. Lopez, the astronomical observations; to Lieut. Hugh ltodman, in charge of the steamer Cosntos, the maill triangulation; to Ensign W. B. Hoggatt, with the ste;im l a u ~ ~ cTixen, ll subsidiary triangulation and hydrography; to Ensign H. I<. Benharu, with the steal11 launch Reyjtard, subsidiary triangulation, hydrography, photography, and part of the shore line; to Yeoman H. Ford, the topography a ~ l d the computi~~g a ~ platting ~ d of the maill triangulation; to Yeoman Mr. G. Appleton and Rli~ster-at-Arlns Hugh Rodman, the recording and platting of the hydrography and subsidiary trianguliition. This detail mas :idhered to as closoly as was practicable, and all b r a ~ ~ c h of e s tho field work were carried on simultaneously, the triangulatiou, however, being always kept in advance. If for ally reason any bralich occavionally fell behind, force mas concentrated on i t t o bring it up, so 2 1 s to keep all the work withill easy reach of the vessel, and the Patterson's anchorages \rere shifted from time to time as the work progressed, so as to be always as near as possible to the field of operations. The season's work embraces the whole of Peril Strait, from its connection with Chatham Strait to the head of Hooniah Souud on the west and Fish Poiut OIL tho south, with the adjacent bays and passages, and that portiori of Chathaui Strait lying betkeen Peril Strait and Point Gardner, including Kelp, MThitemater, Clla ik, Takatz, ancl Hootz bays and I~ootzuahoo Inlet. Two bases were measured, ono of 700 metres a t Hootz Bay, as ~nentioned in last year's report, and one of 1350 metres 11ear l'ogibshi Point, ill Peril Strait; astronolnical observations mere made a t Kenasuow Island :ind a t one end of the Pogibshi base; luagnet~c (leclination, dip, and illtensity determinations a t the Ke~lasllom Island astronomical station; the UWessary tidal observations a t Pogibshi Point, Bear Ray, ant1 ICillisnoo, and current observatious a t Bulldry localities. The no st important current observations mere those sin~ultaneously taken a t Sergius Narrows, I3ig Island, Adams Narrows, and nlidcharlnel 00. Poverotui Islaud, as fro111 then1 was determilled the point of meeting of the iiood tides entering Peril Strait through Salisbury Sound on the mest and Cllatham Strait on the east. It was found to be to the ~lorthmard of Poverotui Island, in the broad part of the strait. Good alichorages were foulld in Peril Strtlit a t Pogibshi Point and Rodman Bay, aud ill Chathaul Strait at Cha-ik Bay, lielp Bay, aud Tu Katz Bay, the latter being completely lalldlocked ; ~ n d protected from mind and sea in every direction. Kelp Bay is an extensive basin with three branches, the north olie of which has a portage across to Peril Strait; canoes cell pass across a t ordinary high water, and boats drawing 3 or 4 feet call Pass a t high spring tides. The anchorago was found on the south side of the basin, in 25 fathoms

44

UNITED S'I'ATEB COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY.

of water, but the arnis are deep, except a t their heads, where they terminate rather abruptly in sand flats. The hills surrou~lding Kelp Bay are high and steep and covered with perpetual suow, except on the upper side of the north arm, and black bears abound. W a r 1 Spring Bay, on the west side of Chatham Strait, and about 12 miles south of Kelp Bay, also furnislies an anchorage, but it is not a good one for large vessels, as it is entirely open to easterly 8torms, but small craft can find a secure harbor in 'eithcr of the small arms on its south side. A t the head of this bay i~ a large cascade fed by a lake located about 200 feet above sea level, and in the same vicinity, arid a t a still higher level, there are hot sulphur springs, which are occasionally resorted to by the Killisnoo Indians for medicinal baths. The weather during the season mas for the most part cloudy and rainy, with occasioual fogs and high wincle, until A u g u ~ t 20, mheli a period of very fine weather set in. Kotwitlistanding the unfavorable conditions, however, there were only two working days when no field work wau accoml)lished. The season's work closed 011 October 2, and the Patterson proceeded to Sitka, where the Gosntos and other boats not belonging to the ship's outfit proper were utored, and tl~ence to Mary Island and Port Sinipson, arriving a t the latter place on tlie morning of the 8th and taking on board the Alaska boundary parties of Assistants 15. F. Dickins and P. A. Welker, who had finished their work a month earlier and were awaiting the vessel's arrival. The steamer 3'q"lta and the schooner Earnest mere taken in tow, and by 3 p. m. of the smile day tho homeward jourxley was resumed and Seattle was reaclie(1 by October 1G. Tlie Fuca and Earnest were taken to the Puget Sound naval station a t Port Orchard and laid up there, after whicli the I'atterson returned to Seattle and was placed in the hands of the Puget Sound Dry Ilock Company for quartered ou the extensive reljairs. During the winter the party of the P(itterson, ten~porarily Hassler a t Port Orchard, mas engaged on the office work pertaining to the Alaska Survey. The report of Lieut. Commander E. 1<. Moore furnishes much valuable inform:ttion in relation to southeast Alaska generally and in particular to.the portions snrveyeti by his party. Tho general features of the region operated in arc, simi1:tr to those of southeast A1:iska generally, the country being nioulitainous, rugged, and thickly nlooded to a height of 2 000 to 3 500 feet. On Strait and 011 the north side of Peril Strait the niountains rise abruptly the west side of Chatl~am out of the water to a height of 2 000 to 5 000 feet, the water being very deep close up to the shores, and there nre very few outlying dangers, while 011 tlie eastern and southern sides of Chatham and Peril straits, respectively, the shores are less abrupt and more irregular and slioaler water is found, with some outlying rocks a ~ reefs. ~ d Tlle sonthern portion of Peril Strait, known as <&The Itapids," is quite dangerous and requires tho most carefill navigation. Several good anchorages not previously known were discovered arid surveyed, some of which will prove very useful to navigators. The depths through tho middle of Chatham Strait range from 300 to 400 fatho~ns, :lnd tlio bottom is comparatively even, while that of Peril Strait is more irregular. On the shores of both the tirnbei is lnaiuly llemlock and epruce with some cedar and alder, but moat of i t is not valuable; in lnidsulnmer the vegetation is rank wherever there is soil enough for roots, ancl flotvers are abundant wl~erever the rays of tlie sun call penetrate. Game mas scarce owing to tho serer0 winter of 1503-04, but fish mere plentiful, especially salniou trout, dog and humpback salmon, and halibut; every arm, bight, and hay haa a strealn a t its head, where early in tlie summer salmorl and speckle(1 trout abound, while later in the season these streams are literally teeming with both varieties of the former. within the area of the season's work are Killisnoo, 011 the The only permanent settlemer~ts e a ~ end t of Kenasnow Isliind, anti the Indian village of Angoon, 2 rniles nortli of the entrance of l<ootznalloo Inlet, other villages being occupied orlly a t the seasons for potato planting and d i ~ ging. There are no whites a t Angooll, and only from teu to forty, according to circumstances, a t Ilillisnoo, while tlie Incliau population of the two settlements amounts to about 800. Killis1100 has a post-office, and its mail1 il~tlnstry a t the present time is the maliilfacture of herring oil and of herring. Tho Alaska Oil arid Guano Colnpany usually employs about fertilizer and the saltir~g forty whits men and sixty Iudians, but owing to the depression in the mnrlret tlioy operated this aeasoll a t about one-third of their capacity. Their catch this year mas 3 200 tons of fish, ancl their output was 102 000 gallons of oil, 500 tons of fertilizer, and 1000 half barrels of salted herring;

The party being still in the field and all branches of the work as yet incomplete, no tabular statistics can now be given, but the full results of the season mill be duly set forth in my uext annual report. Lake Tul~oe to the Colorado .River.-The resuniptiol~ of the reuurvey of tho oblique boull(irtry lilie between the States of California wid Xevada in May, lS95, by Assista~its C. H. Sinclair aud W. B. The continuabetweell July 1 tion of the resurvey dlrriug tho 1,resolit fisca,l year, autl tlio results accoml~lisl~ed November 20, 18!)5, form the subject of :L report by Assistant Sinclair, tlated March 30, 1896. UNITED STATES COAST AND GEODETIC SURVET.

Mountain Range, which was crossed obliquely, and across Fish Lake Valley, numerous points were interpolated, as far as T79,on the Sylvania Mouotains, about 40 miles distant. Tg4mas completed July 4, and the party moved forward across Fish Lake Valley the next day. Beyond the Sylvsnia Mountains is a region difficult to operate in on account of tlie scarcity of water and provender. Assistant Baldmiu started on July 7 to explore this region, and reached the summit of the Grapevine Mountains on the l l t h , and communicated by heliotrope with Assistant Sinclair, who had meanwhile moved to TfB. The point on Grapevine Molintains was not located until the lSth, owing to delays incident to the difaculties already ~lleutioned,but iu the meantime Mr. Sinclair lined in nearer points and made some reconnaissance and erected signals for the triangulation. On the return of Assistant Baldwin, July 19, i t was decided to suspend temporarily the ranging-out work and unite all sections of the party in bringing the triangulation up to the point reached by the ranging party. This was accomplished by August 10, and meanwhile arrangements had been made for sending hay and grain to the southeast, an extra six-horse team being hired for the pnrpose, while the party teams were utilized in distributing the feed to the different mountain stations or temporary camps. The grain and hay had to be hauled from Fish Lake Valley and other supplies from the railroad station a t Bi~liop. The party then proceeded to the southeast, carrying on the different branches of the work simultaneously, and reached the Grapevine Mountains via the head of Deatli Valley and Sand Springs. A t the latter point, owing to the extremely high temperature and the total absence of shade, the party suffered severely. The nest water station beyond Sand Spring is a t Staininger's Ranch, and this for e time was the base of operations. From here to the next water is less than a day's travel by trail, but to get the teams there required three days, and a distance of 65 miles mas traversed. The party reached the latter spring September 5, and the ranging out of the line was thence continued to the southeast end of the Great Amargosa Desert. From T92)a very commanding station, points were lined in across the desert to T,,,, on the mountain range north of Pahrump Valley, a distance of 62 miles. The next move was to Franklin Well, a distance of 40 miles, most of the road being through heavy sand. It was decided to close the ranging-out work a t this point, and the party, after measuring a check base line aud au azimuth, took up the triangulation remaining, to counect with that being executed by Assistant Fairfield. This mas completed by October 10, and the combined party reached Bishop on October SO. Here arrangements were made for the care of the auimals during the winter, the wagons were repaired and stored, and the rest of the outfit shipped to Carson City for overhauling. Tlio party reached Oarsoii City October 23, and as of the men as could be spared were then discharged. Mr. Pairfield then reoccupied certain of tlie triangulation stations on Lake Tahoe, while Mr. Sinclair made necessary magnetic observations a t tho station near the Lake Side Tavern, a t the southeast end of Lake Tahoe, and a t a new etation a t Oarson City. The latter station is in the pavilion grounds, and is located about 50 metres east of the station of 1894. An azimuth was also observed and a meridian line was laid out and permanently marked. The party was theu disbanded, aud the offlcers returned to Washington, and were engaged there on their computations and reductions until again ordered to the field. Assistant Sinclair highly commends Assistants Fairfield and Baldwin for their zeal and the intelligent interest taken by them in the work, and attributes much of the success of the season to their hearty cooperation. A sketch sliowirlg the progress of the work and the relative positions of the determined points accompanies Mr. Slnclair's report, and the following table of statistics furnished by him shows in concise form the results accomplished :

Telqraplbie deterlnination o f the diference o f longitude betzceen Sun Francisco, Gal., nwd Ellensburg, Wasl~.-The Director of the United States Geological Survey having, under (late of July G, 1895, requested tho cooperation of the Coast and Geodetic Survey, ill the determination of the longitude of Ellensburg, Wash., by telegraphic interchange of time signals between that point and San Fralicisco, Ual., Assistant Fremont Morse was directed to make tlie necessary observations a t the LaByette Park Observatory, whilo Mr. S. S. Gannett of tho Geological Survey similarly observed a t Ellensburg. The first interchange of signals took plwe on July 26, but after that date foggy and cloudy weather prevented observations until July 30. July 31 and August 1vero also favorable, but were followed by another period of unfavorable weather conditions lasting until August 5, when the fifth night's observations were obtained. ,4s the observers did not exchange stations, it was necessary for them to observe together for persolla1 equation, and Mr. Garlnott accordingly proceeded to Sat1 Francisco for that purpose. No opportunity for observing, l~omever, presented until August 15, and after that date another spell of bad weather set in, aud Mr. Gannett was compelled by the pressure of other duties to return to Ellensburg on the 17th. Another ]light's observation for personal equation mas much desired, but the project had to be abandoned for laclc of further time, especially as there appeared to be no prospect of an early change in the weather. On the conclusio~l of this work Assistant Morse, in accordance with iustructions, reported to Assistant A. F. Rodgers for duty under his direction in connection with tho resurvey of San Prancisco Bay and Harbor. His services in this locality and subsequently in Urlalaska are noticed under the proper geographical headings. X~~minatio o fn a portion o f the boundary line between the States o f Jiissouri u ? ~ d Iowa.-The nortliern bounilary line of Missouri lias bcen more or less n matter of co~itroversy ever since the admission of that State into tho Union, and iu fact even prior to that date, and numerous surveys have froln time to ti1110been made by State or United States autl~ority. Without going into the rather interestir~ghistory of the matter froin the beginning, suffice i t to say that the Suprerno Court by decree of January 3, 1551, decided that t l ~ line e surveyed arid mnrked during thoprovious Year by tlleir order, and lrnown as the Hendershott-Minor line, should bo regarded as the true boundary. Unfortunately this line, which mas supposed to be straight, contains many bends and changes of direction, and the courses given in the notebooks do not by any means correspond With tile line as marked 011 the grouud. For nearly forty years, hon~over, this line was accepted by all parties, but eventually soiiio of the marks became obliterated and disputes again aroso coucerning a portion of tho line, first between individual laud owners and finally butween the States of Missouri aud Iowa. The matter was again referred to the Supreme Court of tlie Tjnitcd States in ]kcember, 1895, and on February 3, 1596, a decree was issued again defining the boundary as the line m n and marked by Hendorshott and Minor in 1850, and appointing three commissiol~ers to relocate end marl< witli durable monutuents tho obliterated portion which lay between tho fiftieth and fifty-fifth mileposts, reclconed eastward from tho old northwest corner. The Commissioners, Uwight C, Morgan, of Illinois; James Hardiug, of Missouri, and Peter A. Dey, of Iowa, after eraminiug tho disputed part of the line, found that i t would be necessary to resurvey from the fortieth to tho sixtieth mileposts, as the fiftieth, vhicll was also fouud standing, was alleged to be moved out of its proper position, and most of the intervening wooden ones had disappeared. They then decided to apply to tho Superintendent of tho Coast and Geodetic Survey for the detail of an officer to oxecnte a survey, and accordiiigly Assista~it W. C. Hodglrins mas directed to report to the commissioners a t 1)avis City, Toma, and retrace the line under their direction. Assistant A. L. Baldwin was also assigned to tho party to assist in the work. Messrs. Hotlgkius nud Baldmin left Washington on tho Gth of April and met tlle comlnissioners at Davis City OIL the 5th. An

Edmonds also attended to the drafting and clerical duties ;lutl :lssistetl in tho voluminous correspondence and the preparation of data and infor~nation furnished in response to special calls.. ?11-. Einmet Gray served as tidal observer a t the Sausalito station until April 1,when he was ~ucceetlccl by Mr. H. S. Ballard. The Plliladelphia suboffice mas cliswntir~ued a t tho close of the previoua fiscal year, not being deemed longer essential on account of its proximity to the main office at Washington.

SIR: I beg leave to submit herewith the annual reports of the chiefs of tke divisions of this Office, which was placed under my charge a t tho beginning of tlie fiscal year. Mr. E. 1 ) .Preston was Acting Assistant in Cliarge froill tlio nliddle of September to tlle end of October, during my absence in 1Surope while attending the meetings of the I~iternatio~ial Geodctic Association as United States delegate by appointment of the President. The computing division has been colltinued under the able directioli of Assistant 0.A. Schott. I beg leavo to call especial attention to the f'dct that the computations relating to the transcontinental arc have beeu advanced as far as practicable. Among the uumerous reports submitted is a 11ew discussioli of the secular variation of the magnetic force in the United States and adjacent parts which has appeared as Appendix No. 1of the Annual lteport for 1895. He also corupleted the collection of observed magnetic declinations with a view to publishing a new isogonic chart for the epoch January 1900. Tllo tidal division was under the charge of Mr. L. P. Shidy until the middle of July when was relieved in February aud was succeeded Assistant E. B. Latliam was p11t in charge. The ll~tter by Assistant H. L. Marindin who had charge from March 5 to tlie end of the fiscal year. I beg lcave to refer to the report of Mr. Blariudin for the details of the highly important work accomplished in this division through tho zealous labors of its members. Great i~ttention has beell paid to perfecting the tide tables, mliich in their present form reflect credit, not only on the 1. b or8 of this Office, but, owing to tlieir general lisefi~lness to nlariners ongaged in the world's commerce, on the country a t large. The tidal division ackiiomledges its indebtedness to tlie Corps of Engineers, United States Army, for their cooperation ill securing tidal data, and also to foreig~i tidal offices. The dmn~ing and oilgraving division was under tlie efiicie~itdirection of Assistant Mr. W. Duffield during the wl~oleof the fiscal year. Tho consolidat.ion of the two divisions uucier 0110 head lias relieved the Assistant i11 Charge of the Ofilce of the ~iecessityof coordiuating tho labors of two separate divisions, and has therefore simplified the Offlco routine. Attention is called to the unusually large output of charts. The chart division has remained under the systematic and energetic admiuistration of Assistant Gershom Bradford, who has, iu addition to the regular duties of his offlcu, inudo Inany valuable suggestions to the chart board i11 preparing schemes for the publicatiou of charts. The instrume~it diviaion has beeu under tho charge of Assistant J. F. Pratt. The construction tidal d indicator, provided for by act of Congress, mas intrusted to Mr. Pratt, of the Reedy I s l s ~ ~ wlio ~ ~only o t personally directed its constructioii but its erection on the sits seleoted for it. He also designed and superinteuded the coustruction of a photographic enlargiug appamtuSThe miscellaneous division was under tlie charge of Mr. W. P. Ramsey. In additioll to tile

1896'.

SIR: In co~iformity with the regulations of the Survey, I Iiave the honor to submit herewith the annual report of the work done in the compntiug division of the Oflice during the fiscal year ending June 30, 1896. The charge of .the division has remained with the undersigned, the nurnbcr of computers is the same as in the past year, and tlie computing divisiorl ~eceivedtemporary assistance duririg part of the year as follows: The services of J. Boutelle reported for duty in the divisioi~September 12, 1895, and remained to the close of the fiscal year; 1 ) . Hurley \v:.as attached to the division up to February 4, 1896. Granger between January 24 and April 10, 1896; aild I., Winston between May 1and June 10, 1896. There mas also temporarily attached to the division 13. A. Lynch between October 2 and 26,1895. The duties devolved upon me as chief of the division include the direction of the work and distributiiig the same among the computers according to their special qualifications, and the tinling of it to secure cooperation; also the examination and reporting of tlle results and tlie proparation of data or irlforinatiori required by official correspondence and relating to this division, also the supplying the charts n-it11 notes respecting names of observers and magnetic data. These duties were promptly attended to, and time was found to collect allc1 t:ibul;~tethe results of gravity researches from pendulum observations made by the Survey during the interval 1873-1805 for. transmission to the Tilternntional Geodetic Association in response to a call made; also to prepare for the same association a colored map showing the s t a h of the work of trialigulation in the United States up to date. I have also submitted the manuscript of a new discussion of tho secular vnriation of the magnetic force in the TTnited States arid adjacent parts, forming Appendix No. 1in the Annual Report for 1895, aud completed the collection of observed magnetic declirlatious with o view of publishing a new isogonic chart for the epoch January, 1900. REPORT O F THE TIDAL DIVISION, OOAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY OFFICE, FOR THE FISCAL YEAR ENDING JUNE 30, 1806. TLDU DIVISION, June 30,1896. SIR: I have the honor to submit the fbllowing report of the t.idal division for the fiscal year ending June 30,1806 : The Tide Tables for 1896 were read aud revised in proof. The corresponding volume for 1897, which is similar in form to that of the preceding year, was prepared for publiclttion, and all but 31 pages of it was read and revised in proof within tlie year. The predictions for 1897 have been strengthened a t a riurnber of stations by extending the analysis of observations wherever l>racticable, and several hundred new stations were added to the list of subordinate points. Full predictions were made for the first time tbr Willets Point, N. y., where the tides have an average range of more than 7 feet, and which, from its position a t the entrance to the East River, seemed a desirable addition. The full predictions for Marseilles, France, mere discontiuued because, having a tide of only about half a foot mean range, it was considered of uo practical importance to ~lavigation. The predictions tbr Sctvnn~lah Entrance, Georgia, which mere formerly given for Fort Pnlaski, are now given for Tybee Island Light, because we have better observations there. The predictions for San Francisco, Cal., mllich were formerly given for North Beach, are now given for Fort Point, in the Goldell Gate, as being nearer the bar, and because our tidal observations mere made there. The table of sunrise and souset has been extended so as to contain 81 degrees instead of 63 degrees of latitude in each hemisphere, and the times of rising and setting are given for every fifth instead of every seventh day. The work of preparing the tide tables for 1898 mas taken up as soon as the tables for 1897 mere out of the way, and predictions have'been made for 28 stations. Har~uonicanalyses have been made from a year each of hourly ordinates a t Willets Point, N. Y.; Biloxi, Miss.; Port Eads, La.; Mazatlan, Mexico; Sheerness, England, and Cepe Town, Africa. At.Baltimore, Md., a year of high and low waters has been analyzed. For St. Johns, ordiuates were Newfoundland; Vera Oruz, Mexico, and St. Michael, Alaska, short series of l~ourly redbced. The total work done on the harmouic analyses during the year is the equivalent of the complete analysis of about eight years of continuous records. The nonharmoiiic reductions completed daring the year consist of 32 series, the equivalent of about three years of conti~iuous observations. A table of the coeflicients for correcting the uneliminated effect of one harmonic component upon another has been computed for series of 16 difl'erent lengths, varying from about a month up to one year. These coefflcients will be of more especial use for ~ h o r series, t but will improve the results from even a whole year of harmonic analysis. The proof of sheets of Appendix No. 7, Beport for 1894, constituting Part I 1 1 of a Msnud of Tides, was read and revised. The preparation of Parts I and I1 of this M:~nualhas been continued. It is expected that these two parts mill be completed in time to constitnte an appendix to the lieport for 189G. l he location of all tidal stations, where rt year or more of observations has been obtained, was indicated upon a base chart by symbols denoting series of various 1engtJ~s. Tide notes have been prepared and furnished for 183 stations on GO charts. 5.DOC.8 / 3 6

82

UNITED STATES COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY.

Requisitiolis from 4G field 1)arties have bee11 filled, requiriug the description of 61 beuch marks and tidal data for 17 statious. Tidal information has been called for by 53 persons not connected with the Survey, the response to which required the pre1)aration of 33 descriptions of bench marks, current tables for 6 stations, and tidal data for 106 stations, together with technical letters explaining tidal phenomena. An aggregate of about eight and one-half years of record frow automatic tide gauges has been received, examined, and registered. There were 1 1 1origiual and 104 duplicate volumes of tidal observations made by hydrographic parties with staft' uud box gauges received, examined, and registered during the year. About two years of tabulated hourly heights of the sea, high and datd wcre received. low waters, temperature and density of the sea, and ~neteorologicsl Continuation o f the tidal record at the auto~natic gauge station a t T17illets Point, Long Island, AT. Y.-The automatic tide gauge established July 1, 1891, a t Willets Point, Long Island, N. Y., has been kept in successful operation by the kind supervision of officers of the Corps of Engineers, U. S. A., stationed a t that point. The record for March, 1896, mas lost because of ice, and a t the request of theofficer in charge tho series was cliscontinued early in June, 1896. The observers were Lieuts. R. R. ltaymonci and M7illiam H. Brown, U. S. A. Azcto?~tat.io tide gauge and tide indicator maintained in operation a t F o ~Hamilton, t TIM Narrows, Xelc York Harbor.-The automatic tide gauge and tide indicator established in December, 1592, aud iu May, 1893, on the wharf of Fort Hamilton, New York Harbor, by the permissiop of the commanding officer of the fort, have beeu kept in successful operation during the fiscal year. The gauge and indicator have been in charge of Mr. J. G. Spaulding throughout the year. Automatic tide gauge a?ld tide indicator establislted a t Reedy Island Quarantine Station, Delawure.-An automatic tide gauge and tide indicator more established a t lteedy Island Quarantine Station, I)elaw&re, in January, 1896, and continued in successful operation to the close of the fiscal year. The gauge and indicator are under the direction of Dr. A. H. Glennan, surgeon Marine-Hos. pita1 Service, with lfr. Harry Hehl as observer. The tide irldicator is similar to the one a t The Narrows, New York Harbor, described in Notice to Mariners, KO. 177, for February, 1894. The gauge has been kept in operation by members of the tidal division of tho Office, Assistaut Heury L. Marindin, chief of the division. Cot~ti~iuution o f the tidal record a t Port Sumter, Cl~arleston Harbor, Sout?~ Curo1ina.-The automatic tide gauge established in March, 1894, a t Fort Sumter, Charlestou Harbor, South Carolina, has been kept in successful operation by the supervision of officers of the Corps of Engineers, U. S. A., stationed a t tho fort. The iecord is geuerally kept by the officer in charge nutil tabulated for use in the harbor improvements, and the11 the original is sent to this Ofice to keep. During the fiscal year we have received the record from March 17,1894, to March 1, 1896.
