66 202

The forco of engravers has remained as reported in the Annnnl Report, June 30, 1895. The old or expert engravers have beeu employed, as heretofore stated, on the branches of work which they have made specialties, with the exception of sucll interruption'as was necessary through the corrections arising from resurveys, and work necessary to prepare the plates for publication. Thie fiscal year has been an exception in this cllaracter of work, for most of the important charts have been corrected from snrveys made by the United States Engineers, involving a great deal of change, not only in the work itself but also in notes to give the necessary credit for the work. IIL this particular it has been of great advantage to the engraving division, for where a reduction of new work has been needed to advance a plate for publication, the work or reduction has been made with the least l~ossibledelay, and as a coneequence wo have saved time and been enabled to give the latest information on the charts before they wore published. There is n o , question that, for the good of the service, the consolidation of the two divisions was just what mas needed to enhance the value of our work and improve the general condition of the charts. Contracts were awarded to R. F. Bartle & Co., June 28,1895, for engraving outlines, hydrography, topography, etc., on 10 charts, as follows, the work to be completed FFithin two years:

They also completed eight sheets of tlie topographical map of the District of Columbia, in all 32 plates; also progress sketch No. 10, Nevada and Utah, scale 1 1 000 000. Although the requisitions for printing from the chart division during the latter part of the fiscal year decreased to such an extent that the presses did not have more thari half the work to keep them up to full time, yet the average through the gear \was by far in excess of any previous years, vie, by about 14 000 copies for tho chart division. This is mainly due to the management of 31r. D. N. Hoover, the foremarl ill charge. The personnel of the printing Iboomswas changed during the year for the good of the service, as follows: Richard S . Bright, printer, was transferred to the Bureau of Engraving and Printing September 12, 1895, and James L. Smith, printer, was transferred from that Bureau to the Office September 13, 1895, in place of Mr. Bright. W. M. Conn was appointed as a printer's help July 16, 1895. Williarn H. Waddington, printer's help, was dismissed January 31, 1896, for cause, and Charles Buckingham, employed on temporary roll, was appointed in his place. Richard J. Fondrou mas appointed February 7,1896, as a laborer, and detailed to printing rooms as a help during the time when there mas a great deal of work to be done. Tho electrotype and photograph rooms, under the management of Mr. Louis P. Hey ser, havo been very properly carried on and ]lave been very successful in the development of all kinds of work that required intelligent and businesslike capacity. The general work of the divisions has been performed by Mr. John 13;. S~noot, clerk, in his usual acceptable manner. The correspondence and detail work connected with photolithographing was perform& by Mr. John H. Hobgood in a very satisfactory manner until he was transferred to the General YostOffice Department March 20,1896. He was succeeded by Mr. Arthur H. Bailey on the 16th of April, 1896, who was duly certified by the Civil Service Commission, and has displayed fine ability i n conductiljg the business assigned to him, and in a manner highly acceptable to the Office. It gives me much pleasure to testify to the general interest taken iu the work in both divisions by the employees, and to their close attention to their respective duties. Respectfully submitted. WILL WARD DUFFIELD, Assistant in Gltarge of t b Drawing and Engraving Divisiova. Mr. 0. H. TITTMANN, Assistant in Olbarge of the Oflce.

The total issue is 23 per cent larger than that of last year and 20 per cent larger than the average of tlie previons seven years. The net sales (gross sales less copies returned by sales agents) liave increased 9 per cent in copies and 8 per cent in value as compared with the previous year, aud are 4 per cent less in copies and value than the average of the previous seven years. The net sales show a steady (1ecre:ise from 1890 to 1594, and have illcreased since a t about the same ratio. Tlie distribution of cliarts to libraries has been continued, and the large number sent accounts to a considerable degree for the esceptioii:~llylarge total issue this year. The new edition of the chart catalogue has been prepared, and its publication is expected in the near filtnre. The edition of 1894 is exhausted, about 1000 copies having beell clistributed during tho ycar. The corresponclenco for the year amounted to 2 719 letters written. REPORT O F T H E MISCELLANEOUS DIVISION, COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY OFFICE, FOR T H E FISCAL YEAlt ENDING JUNE 30,1890.

MISOELLANEOUS DIVISION, June 30, 2896.
B n z : I have the honor to submit the following report of the miscellaneous division for the fiscal year ending June 30,1896: The duties of the division include the correspondence with sales agents relating to the supply and sale of charts, Coast l'ilots, and Tide Tables, and keeping the accounts connected therewith; the purchase, custody, and issue of stati~nery used in the Office and by the field parties, and all lniscellaueous supplies for the Offlce, and the keeping of accounts of all expenditures for those purposes; the printing aud issue of the Annual Reports and all other publications of the Offlce, including all record books, blank forms, etc., used in the transaction of the work of tho Office and field part,ies; the care and general supervision of the Ofice buildings, and other duties character. of a miscella~~eous Tho following statement partially shows the work done in the division during the year:

SIR: I have the honor to submit the followiug report of the work of the instrument division Juilo 30, 1896. for the year e~ldiug repairs to instruments, plan and co~lstruct new apparatus This division has to make the ~ieeded and illstruments, doternline their c'onstants so far as i t is practicable to do so a t the Oflice, purchase new instruine~lts, send out, receive, an51 accouiit for all iiistruments and general property used in the field and tlie various dirisious of tho Office, and select all new instrtlments and material required for carrying 011 its varieties of work. The following-named persons were employed in the divisioll during the year: William 0.Manpiu, clerk. E. G. Fischer, chief instrument m;lker. Otto Storm, mechanician. Clement Jncolnini, instrulnont ~nakor. Mr. It. Whitnian, i ~ ~ s t r ~ i mmalter. ent S. A. l<e:~rneg, instrulueiit maker. C. E. Regennas, instrument maker. M. Lauxluann, instrunlent maker. H. 0. French, carpenter. G. Mr. Clarvoe, carpenter. 0.N. Darnall, carpeuter. J. W. Huntor, messenger. One hundred and eighty requisitions have been received from field parties aud from the Officc. The filling of many of these has required several days' work of the entire working force. This nrorlr and the repair and construction of carrying and packing cases for field iustrumeuts is uot sliown i11 tho foregoing tables. The construction of a 50-~uetre compsrator and protecting shod, with the necessary adjusting ti, insure successful operation, hav extensively drawn on tho resources of tho division, 3334 working days of the various members of tlie skilled forco having been devoted to it. A photographic enlarging and reducing apparatus has been designed and completed for the photographic house. This apparatus is vory comprehensive in design and sufficiently large for map purposes. Negatives up to 24 inches can be nsed in it, enlnrge~uents can be mado up to 4 by 5 feet, and reductions domu to lantern slides or cven less size. The design and working drawings for, nlid also the constructioli of all tho mechanical parts for : L tidal indicator with a dial 30 feet i11 diameter were lnado iu tho division, after which it was erected a t Reedy Islalid quarantine pier, Dolawaro River, under the directiorl of the chief of the tiivisio~t. This indicator ha^ IIOW been in succossful operatioil for six months. Detailed drawings for a tide-predicting machine, from data furnished by the tidal division, havo been made, an? tho work of co~lstructingthe rilachine in the shops is as well advanced as tho Inore importaut work would por~nit, about 400 of tlie working parts having beeu completed. I have t ocall your attenti011to tlio very poor ancl trying light ill the instrument shop during the winter months. Tho books and zlccou~~ts of tho division and tlio inventories of the field parties are in n very satisfactory condition. A detailed account of each day's work of each employee is kept 011 file ill tllo division. It is with pleasure that I havo to state that thero is a hearty a11d c01isciontio~ls ixlterest shown by tho various employees of tliv division in their respective duties. ltespec tfully, yours, J. F. PRATT, Assistant i ? Charge ~ of the I?tst~u?~&eut Division. Mr. 0. B. TITTMANN, Assistant i n CAarge of the Oflee. 8.Doc. 33-7

UNITED STATES COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY.

REPORT O F THE LIBltARY AXD ARClIIVES DlVISION, COAST AND GEODETIO SUBVEY OFFICE, FOR THE FISCAL YEAR EXDED JUNE 30,189G.

SIR: I have the honor to submit the following report of the library and archives division for the fiscal year ended June 30, 1896 :
The card catalogne has been brought up to date. I n accordance with the recorn~nendation made in my report last year the shelves in the library have been numbered consecutively, fro1111 to 875, the numbers placed on the title pages of the books thereon and entered on the cat:dogue cards, so that now the location of any book in the library can be ascertained by consulting the cart1 catalogue. The library is becomirlg overcrowded and more shelf room is needed. I ~voultlrecommeucl that the two rooins on the second floor, over those nom occupied by the library, be fitted up with cases and shelviug for the use of the library. A large number of United States Coast and Geodetic Survey chart&,turned over to the library by the chart division, has been filed aud arranged on shelves in the front room .on fourth floor of " fireproof" for future reference. Only 72 volumes have been added by purchase to the library dnring the fiscal year, as against 202 volumes purchased last year. Many new works recently publisheci 8lionld be addetl to the library. Summary of books, maps, serials, etc., added to the library during tho fiscal year ceded dune 30,189G:
Books purchased (volur~~es). ............................................--..-............... 72 Books obtained by eschnngo, presented, and published (volumes)............................ 421 Serials and pamphlets purchasud ............................................--.............. 734 Seriala and pamphlets obtained by exchange, presentetl, ~inil ~ ~ i ~ \ > l i s .-.................... hetl 1 878 Maps purchased .....................................................-.-.-..--.............. 1 Maps and charts received by exchange ancl piiblished ...................----.-.............. 878

Books and periodicals sent to binciery to be bound, 172. These mere not returned during tho fiscal year.
ARCHIVES.

Nothing has been clone this fiscal year in preparing original records and computations for billding, as Mr. E. H. Coortcney coultl not bo spared from the computing division for that purpose. This mork should be resumed as soon as ~~ractioable. The work of preparing original sounding records for binding, suspended last year, has not been taken up agaiu for lack of proper Ilelp. This mork, however, I think should be done in the hydrographic division, in the same may as the tidal records have bee11'prepared for binding in the tidal division. No tidal records have been prepared for binding for sorne years in consequence of the tidal division not having any available force to put ou that mork. The collection of log books has been removed fro~ritlio back room of fourth story of "fireproof" to the front room of third story. The back rooln of fourth story is still vory much crowded, and I would recommend that the hall rooms on third ant1 fourth floors of 'bfireproof" be fitted up with cases and shelving so that the back room of fourth floor can be relieved of a, part of its contents. If these roonis mere properly supplied with cases and shelving the boxes of "bottom specimens" could be placed on shelves ant1 thus become accessible. There should also be put in some cases suitable for liolding charts, as those in front room of fourth floor are ahout filled up. More rack room i~ needed for filing tubes containing original sheets, and I mould recommend that the racks now in nse be extended upward to the ceiling.

FORCE OF TIIE DIVISION.

Mr. Arternas ;Martin mas employed in this division as clerk during the whole fiscal year. Mr. John Dale resigried September 16,1805, to practice medicine in his native State. I deeply of Mr. Ihtle, as lie was an oflicielit aud useful clerk. regret tlie resiguatiol~ Mr. Edward 1 " Lopez mas appointed to the vacancy caused by the resignation of Mr. John Dele, ;tnd reported for duty Octobcr 3,1805, arid has been on duty in this divieioii siuce that time. His duties have been various. He finished the uncompleted work of filing aud listing the charts in front room on fourth floor of LiBreproof;":tnsmered calls for charts and maps; assisted in nuniberiug the shelves and books in the library and in entering tho llurnbers on the catalogue cards, a ~ made ~ d out cards for new books as they came in. He has performed his d u t i e ~ efficiently and satisfactorily. Mr. William Li. Mr. Buford A. Lynch mas assigned to this division October 26, 1895, and was employed therein from tliat dato to June 30, 1893, when ho mas assigned to Beld duty. Mr. Lynch assisted in nulubering the shelves, books, etc., in the library, alld mas also engaged in typervritiug. Mr. James A. Williams v a s tenlporarily assigned to this divisioil April 20,1896. He reported sick May 20, and did uot report to this division thereafter. Mr. Dorsey and Mr. Williams wore employed in moving the collection of log books froin back room of fourth floor of "fireproof" to front room on third floor and arranging them on shelves; also in shifting sounding books in cases in back room on second floor of LLfireproof." Respectfully, yours, U. SIDNEY KING, Chief of Library and Archives Uivicrion. Mr. 0. H. TITTMANN, Assistant in Ukarge of the Ofice.

HI'DEOGRAPHY-ATLANTIC COAST.

A t the beginning of the fiscal year the steamer Blake was undergoing repairs a t Jersey City, which were completed on July 15, 1895. On tho smue day Lieut. Colmua~~der H. G . 0. Colby, U. S. N., Assistant, Coast a,nd Geodetic Survey, assumed command of the vessel, and on July 20 sailed for Hyannis, Mass., arriving on July 23, and immediately prepared to carry out your i~istructio~is of May 17, co~nmencing work on July 23. Tlie worlc assig~led to t l ~ e Blalie consisted of the hydrography north of Pollock Ilip Slough; exa~r~inatiori of certain reported shoals in the vicinity of Pollock Rip; the resurvey of the eastern entrance of Nantucket Sound, between Monomoy Point aud Great Point, Nantucket, and specid developrne~~ts of dangers iu the approach to Hyaunis Harbor. The hydrograplly in the entrance to Nantucket Somid includecl a close dovelopmont of the greater part of Handkercllief Shoal, t l ~ passage e bettveell this shoal and nIorloluoy Point, a general survey of Butlers Hole, and the area. lying soutll of these localities i11ld extending to Great Point, Nantucket. The latter work presel~tedueriouv difficulties. The conflicting tidal dnr~.ents, t,lm sc:~rcityof signals, the utter lack of r,zuges, tho prevailing southwest winds with accompanying very rough weather, made the worlr daugcrous as well as diflicult. 111 tllo open passage tho limits of the working ground l~ecessitatedthe ruuning of a series of short lines, with frequent turlli~lgs in a strong tideway amol~globster pots n ~ ~lets, ~ d and directly in the path of an immense number of coastwise vessels of every description, besides numerous sm:bll craft and fislling boats. In face of these difficulties tile results of this survey have been Very satisfactory, and settling, as they did, many doubtful points, were a t once introduced on all charts. The closing up of this gap completes the resurvey of Nantucket and Vineyard souuda and their various approaches. A t odd times durillg the seasou the Blake's party was engi~ged in looking for rocks and shoals in the vicinity of Hyarl~iis n~ld West Chop. Careful seerchcs, both wit11 lead and drag, mere made in all cases finally determilled. Bad weather aetting in in October and contiuui~~g durillg the first ag t New Bedford part of November, the season's work was closed on November 7. After o b t a i n i ~ ~

HYDltOGltAPRT-PACIFIC COAST.

The mork on tho l'acific Coast has, with the oxcoption of the Pattwso?t7s survoys in southeast Alaska, consisted aluiost entirely of the resurvey of San Fraucisco Bay anrl its n1)proaches. A t the beginning of the fiscal year the steamer Patters011 and her party, under the com~uand of Lieut. Commander Xi. I<. Moore, U. S. X., Assistant Coast and Geodetic Survey, was actively engaged iii tho 8urvey of southeast Alaska, tho season havilig beguti on May 13. Tho area covored duriug the season of' 1895 embraced that portioil of Ohuthalu Strait betweeu l'oint Augusta and Peril Strait, Peril Strait from its junctioll with Chatham Strait to Suloria Point, and I-Iooninh Sound. A t tho close of tlio sensou, October 6, 1895,ll hydrographic sl~eets, on various scales, had been finished, and these show the Iiydrographic survey of the area covered. The work, as in former seasons, cotnprised astro~lol~iical observations, measuremeuts of base lines, triaugulation, topography, and hydrography, iucludiug vory complete tidal and occasional current obsorvatious. 1hxdrographic sheets, 5 Tho results obtained are very satisfactory, the records iucludiug 1 topograpl~ic sheets, ant1 tho tidal and curroiit data referred to above. The topographic work has been largely increased and materially improved by the additioli of contour lilies to the sheets. Ackno~vledgment is clue LieuteuantCommauder Afooro for the t.horoughliess of this mork and for tho oxhaustive reports upon the territory covered. A synopsis of these reports has been published as Bulletiti No. 36. On October G the Puttersot&left S i t k ; ~ and proceeded to Fort Simpson. Having taken on board two civilian parties engaged in the boundary survey, she left Fort Simpson, towing the Puca and Eartzest, on October 8, and on October 16 arrived a t Seattle, Wash., having touclled a t Departure Bay and Victoria, British Columbia, on her way. Upon arrival a t Soattle repairs on hull and tilachiuory mere begun. During the progress of oflice the data. obtaincd during the season repairs tho patsty was engaged in preparing for t l ~ e The vessel is now ready for the noxt season's morli. The steamer Gedney remaitled ill charge of Lieut. Lucian P l y ~ ~ uU. e , S. N., Assistslit Coast and Geodetic Survey, until July 23, wlien Lieut. A. 1'. Osborn, U. S. N., Asvistalit Const and Goedetic Survey, assumed colnruand of tlie party. During the fiscal year she has, together with tho steali~er Mcrlrti~ur, been ct~gaged it1 the resurvey of Sau Francisco Bay :~nd its approaches. I n the resurvey of this bay-the most iniportant harbor of the Pacific Coast of America-it is aimed to make tlie mork as accurate a i ~ d colupleto as our present nietllods at~rl liieatis admit. It bas been plauued to includo the ontire bay, its approaches, Sau l'ablo Bay, and all headwaters; tliu work to bo done, as far as prikcticable, on tlle siinle scale, usiug a nuiform, ructangular system of lines, with special develo1)ments of rocks, shoals, arid city water ikonts. During the year work llas been prosecuted by tlto Geciltey on three sheets, two of which have been couipletod. These last cover that part of tile bay lying bet~veellFort Point,West Berkeley, and l'oint Izt~bel, includiug ltichardson Bay and lIaccoon Strait. Oolisiderable progress has been made on tlio third slleot, which lies to the ~iortliwitrd of the couil)leted work. Progross on the Fort Point sheet mas unavoidably slow on accou~itof tides aiid uufavorable weather, but when work was prcvontod by sucli conditions in otle locality i t mas prosecuted ill another, thus utilizitlg the resources of the party to tlio greatest advantage. The work was closed on Decenlber 4,1895, on account of' t~ufavorabloweatlier, the Gedp~ey proceediiig to Oakland, Cal., to prosecute tlio office work aud propare the vessel for tlie contiiluatiori of the \\-ork. 011 April 1, 18'36, the Qcdncy resumed and carried on tho worlc till A],ril 10, \\?hell she Jj'as ordered to Sauta Barbara Ullaliuel to establish the course for the speed trial of' tho U. S .

UNITED STATES COABT AND GEODETIC! SURVEY.

Oregon. The duty connected mith the trial was finished on May 18, and she proceeded to San Miguel Island, California, to make an examination of Cuylers Harbor. Having completed this mork on May 20, the Bedney returned to Sail Fraiicisco and resumed her work in the bay. To meet the wishes of the Navy Department, which greatly desired a resurvey of Mare Islalid Strait, Lieutenant Osborn took 11p that part of the work on June 9, and snccessfully completed it on June 18. He then resumed work where lefh off', ant1 is still engaged in its prosecution a t the encl of tho year. The finished sheets sliow every sign of the accuracy desired, arid tho results are in every way satisfactory. The steamer &Arthur, coinn~andeilby Lieut. James H. Sears, U. S. N., Assistant, Coast and Geodetic Survey, lias been engagetl during the entire fiscal year, with the exception of tliirteen days, in tlie resurvey of San Francisco Bay and its approaches. The work dono by this party is comprised in sheets covering the Golden Gate and Bonita Channel aud the area, lying between San Francisco, Yerba Buena Island, aaid Oakland, and extending southward nearly to Point Avisadero. Separate sheets show work done alorig the water front of San Francisco, Missioli Bay, and Sonoma Roclr, the last named being 011 a, scale of 1-10 000. The party is now eerigtlged on the hydrography between West Berkeley : ~ n d San Prancisco. The work has been greatly irlterferetl mith by the prevalence of high winds ant1 fogs during the middle of the day; this necessitates beginning work a t daylight. COAST PILOT PARTY.

From January 12 to May 21, 1S9G, tlie party was engaged in work in the field covering tho coast of the Gulf of Mexico between Key West alld Xew Orleans, in the scl~oonerT~n?isit. The report of the party submitted by Ensign Tarbox suggests the preparation of a second edition of the United States Coast Pilot, Part VI, mbich 1earnestly recommend. I beg to esprees my appreciatio~iof the services of Ensign Tarbox mhile iu charge of this party. REPORT O F THE HYDROGRAPHIC DIVISION F O E T H E FISCAL YEAR EXDISG J U N E 30, 1896. SURVEY, UNITED STATESCOASTA N D GEODETIC Wasliin,yton, D. C., J.line 30, 18!11;. SIR: I hare tlie honor to submit the follon~ing report of tlie work of tlie hydrographic division during the fiscal year ending June 30,1806: November 7, 1805. I Lieut. Walter McLean, U. S. N., was in charge until his cletaclimei~t, assumed charge on reporting for duty on December 20, 1895, the Hydrogral~liic Inspector personally stipervising during tlie interval. The general rontiue rand methods of previous years have been followetl, with the cultivatio~i of more iutirnate relations with the Corps of Engineers, United State Army, whereby our charts Iiave been vastly benefited by the addition of numerous and valuablo ilnproverne~ltsand surveys made by them. The following synopsis mill sliom briefly the amount of worlt dolle by tlie ciivisiori: Sumber of volume8 plattctl ............................................................... 255 Nuntber of nngles platted.. ............................................................... 94 794 Number of sounclinge platted ............................................................. 37-3 493 Number of 111i1ev platted .................................................................. 8 854 h'nmber of sheete platted ................................................................. 52 Iu addition t o this there has beeu rnucli miscell:ineous work, i ~ i c l ~ ~ d verification iilg and revision of proofs, drn\vings, and charts; tracings ant1 projections rliade and verified; tidal clats reduced and platted; comparisons of l~ytlrography sritl lnpograpliy, ant1 otlier work too liumerous to rnention. I n the one item alone of keeping the charts corrccteil over '700 corrections have bee11 added, xxecessitatil~g over 2 000 corrections to our standard charts. Notico to Mariners has beeu revised and the iterus given :it greater length. I t s The mo~~tlily publication has been prompt. Owing to tl~c? zeal and efficiency of a11 the employees the work of tliedivision has beell in every may satisfhctory, and has beer1 kept u p to (late. The chief tlrnftsnlnn of this division, Mr. W. C. Willenbncher, is invnluable; he is pronq)t, reliable, anil efficient in all lie undertakes. The work of Rlr. F. O . Donu ancl Mr. J. T.~ a t k i n is s all that could be desired, and shows thoroughness a t all times. I mould earnestly rccoini~ienclthat tho salary of Mr. Watlrins be increnseil to $1 300, for tlie reasoli that much tlifficulty has been experienced in retainitig a good draftsinan here in consequence of insufficie~itsalary. The work required of hiui calls for special knowledge and esperience in this particular line, and he has proven himself very eflicient in every particular. On Mr. E. H. Wyvill devolves the important work of correcting the standard charts of the

I.

REPORT OF THE HYDROGRAPHIC INSPECTOR.

109

office, and, ill my opinion, no one could be better fitted for the place. The position can only be filled by a11 intelligent man ~ h has o had a training both a t sea and on shore. It requires a imutical experience as well as a knowledge of drawing geodesy, in all of which Mr. Wyvill is well posted. I would suggest that his title be changed to nautical expert, and that his salary be increased to $1 800. Very respectfully, HUGH I~ODMAK, Lieutotaitt, U. S. AT., Chief o f Hydrograplbic Divisiosl. Lieut. Commander H. G. 0. COLBY, U. S. N., HydroyruplLic Inspector Coast a d Geodetic Survey, Vrask.i?~gto,t, D. C.

ICEPOBT O F THE COAST PILOT PARTY FOlt THE lW3CAL YEAR EX1)lNG J U N E 30, IS0G. UNITEDSTATESCOASTAXD GEODETIC SUEVEY, Wccslringto?~, 11. C., Jzc7ce 30, 1896. SIR: I 1i;~vc tho honor to suhmit the following report of tho work of the Coast Pilot party for tlie fibcal year elidilig June 30, 1896. Under the general direction of the Superintendent and the supel.vision of the Hydrographic Inspector, the duties of this party involve the execution of work in the field and in the office. The party was under tho charge of Lieut. Walter McLean, U. S. N., from July 1 to October 21, 1805, and sinco tho latter date I have had charge of tho work. A t tho beginning of tho fiscal year the party was engaged in reading proof of United States Coast Pilot, Atlantic Coast, Part VII, froin Chesapeake Bay Entrance to Key West; in compiling and reading proof of a suppleme~~t (containing rules of the road) for Coast Pilot volurnes already published, and in preparing ;ind selidilig i~lterrogatoriesco~rering the coast of tlie United States bordering on the Gulf of Mexico. On September 20, 1895, tlie last proofs of United States Uoast Pilot, Part VII, were s e l ~ to t tho printer, and on October 26, 1805, the first bound copies of this volumo were received for issue. After the last proofs of United States Coast Pilot, P a r t VII, liad been sent to the printer the party was engaged in compiling nianuscript for United States Coast l'ilot, Atlantic Coast, Part V111, wliich ill include the coast of the United States bordering the Gulf of Mexico between ICey West and the Rio Grando. This work was continued until January 12, 1896, when, u d e r instructions fi.0111 the Superilltendcut, I, accompauiecl by Mr. Johu Ross, roported on board the Coast and Geodetic Survey stealiier Bache, and on tho arrival of that vessel a t Pensacola, Fla., organized a party on board tlie Coast and (feodetic Surrey schooner Transit for Coast Pilot work afloat. TJuder the Superintendent's instructions, aclcompanied by Mr. Itoss, 1 rotunlod to the OWCG ou May 81, 1896, and contiuued the compil&ion of United States Coast Pilot, Part TTIII. Tho report coveriiig tho work of tho Coast Pilot party while in the field ~v;is iubniittod to the Superirltondent on May 39, 1806. 111 this connection I would stato that some of tlie principal in their entrances, if not in deptli a t anchorages visited shorn marked cliangos in tlio cha~inels least in direction, eiilce Uiu last surveys. Among these I mould ~nontionEast Pass (into St. Georgos Sound), St. Androws Bay, Borii Island Auchorngo, and Ship Island Auchorage. I11 my opinion, a resurvey of these ontrances would enable tlie buoys t d b e more advantageously located :nld more correctly plotted on the charts, the usefulness of which would be greatly increased thoreby. Besides the preparation of manuscript for new Coast Pilot voluines and reading proof of tho same, tlie party has corrected to dato of issue all Coast Pilot volu~i~os issued from this Office. This important and necessary work involvos considc?rublolabor, and has been increasing steadily in amount. The reduction of the price of Coast Pilot vol~unesto 50 cents each has more thull doubled the issue of volnmes froill this Offico nnd has correspondi~iglyillcreased tho work of correction. The routille work of the party in keeping records of clianges, reported dangers,

110

UNITED STATES COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY.

hydrographic examini~tions, new information :tvailable, and otlier tlata which may be llsetl in t l ~ e compilation or correctioii of Coast Pilot volumes is very considerable and cw~lstant. I mould call attention to the necessity for a new (second) edition of United States Coast Pilot, Atlantic Coast, P a r t VI, Chesapeake Bay and Tributaries. The first edition was publisl~ecl in ISSO, and is therefore 7 years old. Since its publication, changes agecting tlre volume, a m o n i i t i ~ ~ to g are h now inserted ill e:tcll several hundred, have occurrecl. Those necessitated corrections, ~ v l ~ i c vollime issued. They detract greatly fro111 the appearnilce arid usefhll~essof the book, :111d in many cases elltirely chango tlie text. Of the first edition, 1 5 0 0 copies were printed and (iG7 copies issued, leaving 843 copies on hand a t the end of tlie fiscal year J u n e 30: 1896. I mould suggest that, when the manuscript for United States Coast Pilot, P a r t TTIII,lias been sent to tho printer, lrliinuscript for a' second edition of (iOO volumes of P a r t T T I be prepared, a11'1 t h a t mheu the volume is prirlted the unsold copies of the first edition be caiiceled. Mr. John Ross, 11:tutical espert of the party, has bee11 employed, partly in the ofice and partly in the field, cluriug the entire fiscal ye;lr in the collection of data and the compilation of ~nanuscript for the new edition of Port Y I I I of tlie Coast Pilot. It gives me great ple:~suruto testify to t l ~ e valuable services lie has rendered the \vork, both in the oEce and in t h e field. Nr. Talbot Pulizzi lias been employed d~iririgthe entire fiscal year in copying nlanuscript, entering corrections in Coast Pilot volumes, and keeping postecl the files of the party, all to my entire fiatisfaction. Very respectfully, GLENNIETan~os, Eneigw, U. S. A'., I n Cliarge o f Coast Pilot Party. COLI~Y, U. S. N., Lieut. Commander H. G . 0. OFFICE REPORT NO. 3-1896.
REPORT O F THE DISBURSING AGENT POlt THE FISCAL YEAR ESDING JUNE 30, 1896. UNITEDSTATESCOASTAND GEODETIO SURVEY, OFP~CE O F THE DISBURSING AGENT, l~aslri?tgton, D . C., June 30, 189G. SIR: I have the honor to submit tile follomiug report of the disbursing office for the fiscal year ending June 30,1896: The aggregate of advances to chiefs of field parties during the year mas $113 516.83. The total disbursements on adjusted sccouiits were $410 961.52. The number of vouchers, bills, etc., adjusted and paid mas 16 057. Additional statistics of the work accomplished mill be fouud on file in this ofrice. The annual report of expenditures of tllc Uuited States Coast and Geodetic Survey for the fiscal year ending June 30, 1895, mas forwarded to the Snperintenclelit on J:~nunry1, 1896. The report for the fiscal year just ended is boirig compiled, and mill be ready for tranrluissiou to Congress early in the coming calendar year. Tllo adjustment and settlement of the accou~its of this Bureau during the year have been kept, as far as circumstances mould permit, llearly up to date. I would also state that all accounts nuditetl and paid in this office have been promptly forwarded to the Auditor for the Treasury Ilepartment for his action thereon, aud his l~romptness in settling the same, and that, too, mitliout the disnllon7anceof n siugle cent duriug the entire fiscal year, continues to be a source of much gratification to this office. The force of the office for tlio fiscal year llus bcen as follo\vs: Mr. N. (3. Henry, clerk and cashier; Miss Ida Af. Peck, typewriter aud clerk; Mru. Jennie H. Fitch, clerk. ltespectfi~lly, yours, R. J. GRIFFIN, D i s b t t r l i ~ Ageut. ~ Qen. W. W. DUFPIELI), Suprivalendent United States Coast a ~ Qeodetic ~ d Snrvcy, l l r ~ l ~ i t r g t o D. n, C .

EXPENDITURES, COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY, 1S9G. UNITEDSTATESCOASTAND GEODETIUSURVEY, OFFIOE OF THE DISBURSINGAGENT, IBmhington, I). C., Aroz1e7nber 16, 1836. SIR: I have tho l~onor to transmit herewith the anuual report of expendit.urea xnade by this office for the fiscal year ending June 30, 1896. Respectfully, yours, R. J. GRIFFIN,Dis1)~~rsing Agent. Gen. W. W. I~UFFIELD, Superintendent United States Ooast and Qeodetic Surt:ey, Tlruakiwgton, I ) . 0 . s. Doc. 3 5 s

UNITED STATES COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY.

OFFICE REPORT NO. 4-1896.
REPORT O F THE ASSISTAKT I N CHARGE OF THE OFFICE O F STANDARD WEIGHTS AND MEASUltES FOR THE FISCAL YEAR ENDIFG JUNE 30,lsOG. UNITED STATESCOASTAXD GEODETIC SURVEY, OFFICE O F STANDARD ITEIGHTSAND MBASUBES, lVnski~zgto~t, B. C., June 30, 189G. SIB: I have the honor t o submit &lie annual report of the Office of Standard Weights and Measures for the fiscal year ending June 30,189G. The usual operations of vcrification aiid adjustment of weights, capacity measures, standards of lengtoli,etc., for other Departments of the Government, States, institutions of learning, engineers and surveyors, manufacturers aiid private parties, have bee11 carried on duri~lgthe year, and, notwithstanding the limited force of the Officc, prompt respollse llas been made to all calls for information. Messrs. L. A. Pisclier and C. A. Herbang11 have, as heretofore, efficiently performed tho various duties devolving up011 tl~em, and have served continuously tllrougl~out the year. Mr. Fischer, in additioii to his regular duties, prepared the weights alid nlcnsures exhibit for G to the Atlanta Exposition and installed i t there, being absent for that purpose from August 2 September 9. He mas again called to Atlanta, in connection with the Treasury De1)artnient exhibit, on December 2 aud remained until the 10th. He also rendered valuable, assistance ill tlie important special observations arid investigations me~~tioried farther on, viz, the determillation of Metre hi terms of-the international prototype, the co~lstruction of the the value of the Corn~nittee SO-metre comparator, the verification of the lengths and constants of the secondary base bars Nos. 13 and 14, nud the standardization and determination of coristants of the new duplex base bars, Nos. 15 and 1G. Mr. Hnrbaugh'~ duties have been of a miscellaneous character, including the comparison of alcol~olometers, etching of steel tapes, assisting in tape com~)arisons, indexing records, typewriting, etc. In addition to attending to the clerical work of the Weights and Aleaeures Office, he has also done a11 the typemritilig for the Superintendent's Annual Report. The nicchanician, Mr. Otto Storm, lias, for the greater part of the year, been detailed to the instrument division, his services not being continuously required in the Weights and Measures 1 1 the otller hand, n-hen ernergei~cies required the perfbrrnance of considerable work-as Office. 0 tlio construction of apparatus in a li~nited time-the instrument division has reciprocated by temporarily putting 011 i t as maily mechanicians as mere necessary. I n this way the new cut-off apparatus a ~ i d the new rnicl.oscopes for the 50-metrecomparator mere constructed, and the arrangement hiis proved inutually beneficial. Laborer R. 13. Crutchfield was :issigned to t.lie Oflice on May 15 and served for the remainder of the year. He assisted in the examillation of specimens of sea water and performed miscellaneous duty. Electrical qcnits.-Assistant G. 12. Putnani mas assigned to duty under my direction ou October 21, and so continued until January, rendering valuable service, especially in tho matter of prepara11d ~ g testing of electrical standards. He constructeif, in accordaiice with the ing for the ~ i i a k i ~ specifications published by t l ~ c National Academy of Sciences under date of February 20,1895, six standard Clarlc Cells, a r ~ d subsequently compared them with each other and with tlie standard Carl~art Cell in the possession of this Office, and discussed and computed the observations. As a preliminary to the testing of tho Clark Cells tho Resistance boxes t o be used were c:irefully investigated and intercompared, and their resistances determined in terms of the standard No. 75; the

REPORT FOR 1896-PART

I .

OFFICE OF STANDARD WEIGHTS AND MEASURES.

137

also assisted various galvanometers used were also subjcctod to a rigid examinatio~i. Mr. Put~iam in the observations for the determination of the relation between the Committee Metre and the Prototype Netre Sc. 21. Some progress has bee11made in the acquiring of other electrical standards, but its the annual appropriation for the purchase of material and apparatus, and for iucidental expenses, is o~ily $500, the work riecessarily proceeds slowly, aud some tilno will elapse before we can hope to liave a reasonably complcto outfit for the determi~iatio~~ and verification of electrical units. Co?wnzitteeh1etre.-The International l'rototype Metre being liow regarded as our fui~dameiital standard of length, tlie determination of the relation of tlie old Committeo Metre thereto is a macter of great importauce, slid several series of obsert-ations have from time to time been made. Tlie direct comparisoris mado d n r i ~ ~ the g previous year by Mr. L. A. Fischer, whilc, very nccortiant among tl~emselves, gave a value sligl~tly different frorii what mas expected, and it was deemed advisable to further test the matter by mearis of i t neth hod not depending on the reflection of threads in t l ~ o ends of tlie Committee Metre. Accordingly, as stated in tlie lteport for IS%, two auxiliary abuttlng pieces wero iriarle, each with n fine lilio drawn upon it. These were used during the observations of this year, being lield in coutact with tlio ends of the metre by means of light spriugs, and the lines obsorved in direct comparison with those oil Prototype Metro No. 21, tlius obviatiug thc possible uncertainties of estimating tho midway point between a thread or spider line and its reflection. Tlie value of tlie abuttirig pieces was a t different tiines carefully determilled by bringing their abutting surfaces together and tlieli xiieasuril~g the distance between their lines by means of a microscope micrometer. Coniparisor~s betacen the Coniiiiittec Metre :ii~d l'rototypc Metro So. 21 were made by Messrs. Fischer, Potnaxu, and myself, during January and February, 1896, the abutting pieces being frequently shifted iii positioii and occ:lsionally iiiterchauged. I t mas fonnd that for any given position tlio results by tlie three observers more l)ractically idelltical, bnt that the interchange of abutting pieces, and sornotimes their mere reversal without interchauge, l>r&luced a variation, tho rauge of observations being about 4 microns. Uufortuiiately the cuds of tho Coiiixnittee Metre aro not now truo plai~es, and defects and irregularities of surface are plai111yvisible. The variation of results is doubtless due to this fact, and I am of the opinion, as stated in my February report, that a further multiplication of observatious will bo useless and that a closer approxiination of the true original value of the Committee Metro can not now be obtained. Taking the mean of all observations by tho various methods, howover, tho resultiug error of tho Coinmittee Metro does not appear to esceed one micron. 50-;lfetre conipurator.-Occasioll haviug arisen for the verification of the lengths aud constitnts of secondary base bars h'os. 13 and 14 on accouiit of their having bee11 in a, railway accident, aiid also for tho standardizatioi~ of tho new duplex burs desigl~ecl by Assistauit William Eimbeck and recently constructed by the instruinent division, i t becanie necessary to cousider the best and most cxpeditioiis metliods of accomplishi~~g tho work, and as ~ ~ o iof i e the apparatus and facilities available wero entirely satisfactory, i t was decided to recornmer;d the construction of a permai~ont 50-metre caomparator. 'i'his, by euablil~g US to l~iake wit11 ally set of bars repeated rueasures of a known distance determined by means of a standilrd ill melting ice and consequently a t s constant teniperature, it was belioved \trould afford t l ~ e most accurate results, and with a not unreasonable espenditure of timo nnci labor. Tho recommeridation liaving bee11 approved by you, the necessary plans and drawings mere a t once propared by Mr. 1 , . A. Fischer, and tlie construction mas begun in November, and by Ihe cooperation of tlie iustriuuent division con11)letediii J:iiiusry. As tlie comptbrator was esse~~tinlly of tho samo design as the toulporary 100-nletreone used in connectioii mitli tho measurenielit of tlie Holton Base in 1592, slid wliicli lias been fully described by Assistaut R. S. TJToodwardiii A ~ p e n d i xNo. 8 of lieport for 1893, it is unnecessary to enter hero into details. Tlio followilig particulars, however, shonld bo stated: The terxni~~al piers, DO ruetres apart, are of brick, solidly built, and resting on 4 by 4 feet concrete Souudatioi~s extending to n depth of 5 feet below tho surface of tho ground. Each conorete fonndatioii weighs approximately 5 to11.s. Tile micror~ietor~iiicroscopcs~nountecl on tliese piers were specially niade for the pni'pose, and hnvo each a magnifying power of about 50 diameters; one turn of the n~icrometer =75 microns, and consequently each division =04"7. The intermediate microscanes liave
C

138

UNITED STATES COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY.

a somewhat smaller power, and mere so constructed as to have :L value of 1micron per division of micrometer; they are supported on cedar posts, firrnly set in the ground to a depth of 3 to 33 feet, :it intervals of 5 metres, and carefully aligned. I n the concrete bases of the terrninal piers are set bronze bolts, baving spherical heads, which fit iuto tlle conical aperture of the cot-off apl>aratus (also described in Assistant 'ifroodward's report above referred to), and tho centres of tl~ese spheres define the termini of tho 30-metre base. The pier microscopes, by means of the cut-off apparatus, can be accurately referred a t ally tiilie to the ground marks, obserr:btions in the direct and reversed position of' the cut-off scale being always t:llte~l and the attached level readiligs recorded. A s first constrnctecl tlie vooclen base, c:lrrying the tracks for the movement of the carriages of tlie iced bar al)paratus, was continuous from e ~ io ~ d end, tlie rails of the tracks only being so separateel as to provide roo111 for expansion, but after using it a short tilllo it mas found necessary to divide the wooden frartic into sections to eliminate the cumulative effects of its expausion or contraction, as dnri~lgmeasures with t11e secondary barb tlteir trestles rested on tliie base. it imlnersetl in melting The standard 5-metre bar, designated as B,:, the trough for snp~orting ice, and the nccomp:~nying carriages for trnndli~ig i t along the track of the comparator, are the same ones used a t Holton, arld the gerieral method of use is also tho same as describecl by Assistant Woodward. 111 March, after colnpletiug :I rlulnber of lncasures with the secondary bars, the annoying discovery mas made that tlie 1)ic.rfbundatior~s were not as stable as had becn e~pectetl, aricl that the distance between the terrnirlal n~arl;sof the base line did not remain constant. The cl1:mges in distance \\'ere qnite pe~.ceptible in mnount, and for a time mcre continuous in one clirection, but snbsequel~tly the clirection was reversed, : 1 1 1 d tllc line gradually more tllwl regained its originallengtli. These changes cor~siderably increased tho amoulit of morlr required to clerivc nccurato lengths fbr tlte bars ui~tler exstl~i~iation, as i t became riecessnry that eacli set of measures should bc ilnrnedintely preccdetl :t~rd followed by s new iced bar cletermination of the lengt11 of t h o base. The varying lengths of tlie base line are ~vcll shown by tlle following tabulatiori of the 38 iced bar measures, tho amount by h hi ell tlie base exceedeel or fell short of 50 metres being given in niicrons wit11the npprolbrinte sign. In tl~cse results all corrections for iced bar length, micrometer readings, cut-off ilicliriation, grade, alignment, etc., have bee11 applied.

six iridependerit measures were made, and i t mill be seen that their extreme range is only 52 microns, and that in all tile subsequent observations tlie daily range was even smaller, in some cases not exceeding 10 microrls. The marlied shortening of the base by ne;~rly 1200 microns, as shon7n by the observations of March 31, therefore staodu out prornine~itly,as does also the progressive length was reached. W u have, from lengthening froxu that clate to May 7, when the ~n;~sirnum the daily lneans for the extreme range of lengths observed, the diKerence between -1 24Sp arid +609ji, or 1947p, equal to nearly 2 millimetres. We have conclusive proof that the shortening occurred ufter Jfarch 20 and before March 31: and that i t must therefore have been a comparatively sudden one, but n-e (lo not kllow that the results of March 31 represent the actual minimum length, :is the systematic lengthening may have been already in progress a t that clate. Observations by means of levels snitably mounted on the piers and their bases, andoccasional cut-off readiags, show that the movements still continue, but apparently to a less extent than formerly. It is hoped that after the lapse of a year from the date of construction a more permanent and stable condition will be reached. B(tse bar conq)ctrisons.-Tho redetermination of tho lengths and constants of seco~ldarybase bars Nos. 13 and 14, arid the standardization of the 11ew Duples bars Nos. 15 and 1 G have already been referred to under the head of the 50-metre comparator. The comparisons of tho former vere duly completed in April,,and gave results practically irlentical witli those previously obtained, showing that the bars had not been injured by the jarring received in the railway accident. The resulting combined length of bars No. 13 aud 14, a t a tern1)eraturo of 00.0 C., was 10.000003 metrcs + 3.Zjr. Subsequently speci:il niglit and day observations mere mails to determine the "lag" of thermolneters, the result being tliat under the conditions the11 existing the L61ng" mas 0-10, the 8igr1 depending upcii wlietlier the temperature mas rlslng or falling. This difl'ers slightly from the xirear1 value derived :it Holton, viz, + 00.35, but i t must be borne in mind that special conditions necessarily nftbct the result, as the "lag', clopends not only on the actual but also 011 their rapidity. amount of cliallges of tel~iporature Tho nenT duplex base bars Xos. 15 arid 16 each colisist of two components, tho prominent feature of the apparatus being its yielding two simriltaneous measures of a base by two dift'erent metals having widely differel~t coeficients of expansion, so that tlie tenlperatures during a measure call be deduced more accurately than by indications of' thermometers. I n the standardization observations, Ilomever, thermometers were nsed, three for each bar, but the record furnishes the means of co1nl)uting results ilitlependently of them. The behavior of tho whole appar;~tos during tlle various lnoasuros and tests mas excellent, and I am Inore thau ever conviuced that wit11 proper handlir~g i t mill yield results far superior to ally otlier base apparatus yet devised. Tlie difficulty of obtaining the true temperature of tlie bars during a measure in the field lias heretofore bcen tho greatest source of uncertai~ityin prinlary bases, and I believe that the introduction of tho To be snre the measurement of duplex principle will mark an era in accur:lte base ~neasure~nent. but the dificula base throughout by means of a stalldard bar in ice mould be the ideal metllocl~ ties i n tho way of its practical 11sc in the field ant1 the greet espense involved in preparing the line nyould necessarily forbid its adoption. Tlio temperatures ri~nged from 03.0 to 200.0 C., nlld 32 determin:~tionsof the value of 10 bar lengtlls (for each component) mere obtained. REPORT FOR 1896-PAKT

1 1 .

A P P E N D I X NO. 1-1896.

DISTRIBUTIOX OF THE MAGNET10 DEOLINATION IN T H E UNITED STATE8 FOR THE EPOCH JANUARY 1, 1900.
[Third edition, with throe charts.]

By CHARLES A. ~CROTT, As8idtai~t. Submitted for publioation October 17, 1896.

-

Introduction.-Since the last puljlication by the Survey of a paper showing for a given date the distribution of the magnetic declination within the area of the6United States nearly eight years have elapsed, an interval sufficiently long to have produced marked changes in the values of the declination as well as in the delineation of the isogonic curves from their aspect in tho year 1890. A new edition, based up011 a llem discussion of the material on hand, and a chart exhibiting the results for an epoch nearer to the present time were thus callod for. It is well known that the changes of the delineation, and consequently also its geographic distribution, are caused by the operation of the secular variation, the lams of which, while fairly made out for &ations located on the coasts, are yet but imperfectly understood for the interior of the country; and this is particularly true for the more recently settled parts. Hence a first and indispensable step toward improved results mas :I new discussion of the secular variation. This was sccordingly made, and is contained in the Annual Report of the Survoy of last year. (Vide Ap1)endix No. 1,1896, pp. 16'7320.) The study of this subject, es yet obscuro in its origin, has been steadily pursued by the Survey, and the increased demaud for its results may be judged of by the fact that seven editions have been exhausted. The improvements introduced in the present paper on the distribution of the declination, for , has been selected, consist ofwhich the epoch J a n u ~ r y1900, (1)The introduction of additional observations made since the publication of 1889 and the additions to the collection of data other than those directly contributed by the Survey. (2) The ex tension and increase of our knowledge of the secular variation, thus giving increased precision to the "reduction to el~och;" that is, to the sign and amount of correction to be applied to the obeerved value to produce what i t mould be should the observation be made in January, 1900. I n spite of the very limited means a t the disposal of the Survey,' the progress in our knowledge of the distribution of magnetism within our borders though slow has been steady, as may be seen from the historical account give11 in the introduction to the second edition of the paper; yet west of the Missiseippi River, and particularly in the Northwestern States, there are vast regions
--

'For the 0eortl year 18QS96the amount appropriated for magnetio researoh was but one-fiftieth part of that given for the general tleld work of the Survey, and in ooneeqnenoe the maintenanoe of the lnagnetio obrrervatory near Snn Antonio, Tex., where eelf-regietering inetrumente had been at work during five years, had to be given up in Marob, 1895.

148

UNITED STATES COAS'I' AND GEODETIC SURVEY.

which for the present have to be covered by interpolated values. Moreover, the recognition of disturbed regions and the exposition of the disturbances by means of lines of equal anomaly have so far received little consideration, but in the future will demand a large share of attention as s desirable, interesting, and fruitful study, for which i t is hoped the necessary means will be forthcoming. I n judging thus of the a~iiountand character of the work in terrestrial magnetism accomplished so far by the Survey, the fact of its very limited resources should be borne in mind. Looking to future expal~siollof activity and in part explanatory of the method pursued in bringing out the results of this paper, a fen- words bearir~g on the manner of conductiug magnetic surveys may find a proper place here. lteferriug to surveys on land and of limited area, such.as that of one of our States of average size, one or two field parties observing a t each station declination, dip, and intensity, and operating, say, for one, two, or maybe more years, according to facilities for travel and depending ou tlie density of distribution of stations, may secure a fair knowledge of the magnetic force within the border lines. Should a magnetic observatory, centrally located and provided with automatically registering instruments, be available during the t,iliie of tile survey, all field results could be differentially corrected for diurnal variation and for clisturbal~ces, as well as for annual change, simply by comparisons of simulta~~eous valnes found by t,lre traveling party and as recorded a t the base station. The assumption that the character of disturbances changes but slowly with distance can safely be made. The analysis of local disturbances may be followed out to any desired extent. Such surveys may be repeated a t certain intervd~j, say one-fourth of a century.' *Foran area forming a co~isiderable part of the earth's surface, such as that presented by the United States, the above method becomes impracticable by reason of its great expense iu providing for R multitude of ilrstruluents a r ~ d observers; hence a different niethod has to be followed, and is the oile adopted by the Survey. It consists in gaining as accurate a kuowldge of the laws of the secular variation as possible by selectiug a series of well-distributed so-called secular-variation stations, particularly those for which we possess a number of old observations, and supplementing these by modern observations repeated every few years (say five or ten or more years, according to circumsta~ices). If, then, the Survey directs its observers to places where their work will tell to beat adva~itage, its, for iustauce, in the central part of a region destitute of magnetic statious, and a t the same time collects all other results within its boundaries, no matter when or by whom observed, we can refer all to any epoch we choose2 and discuss and chart them as in the first method. This paper, being restricted to the consideration of declinations, colltairls a collection of observed and reduced (to epoch 1900.0) values a t over 3 500 places, while the uuluber of secnlarvariation stations (in Appeudix No. 1, Report for 1895)was 11S, witli au aggregate of niore than 1430 observatiolls (annual values). Magnetic surveys conducted a t 8ea of necessity gather their material from cruises, and these researches are generally isolated rather than partaking of a systeniatic and completo character. Intensities, when expres8ed in absolute measure, l~lust depend on obselevations a t base stations on land, and the disturbing influences on magnetic obserrations made 011 board ship must be investigated under the various conditions of a cruise and the results be corrected accordingly. The secular variation is ascertained from a discussion of results obtained on islandi and a t coast stations. Isomagnetic curves thrown over the oceanic expanse of the survey will be greatly st.rengthened in their proper location by joining .and merging iuto the trend of any corresponding system of curves covering adjacent coasts. lsomagnetic lines may be constructed gre,phically or by application of analysis. The latter mathematical process of interpolation, for instance, was applied in case of the
Ae examples of thie method of oonduoting eurveye, we may refer to the following publicationa: "A mngnetio eurrey of tho British Isles for the epoch Jnnuary 1,18813," by A. W.Riicker and T. E. Thorpe, Phil. Trane. Roy. 86c.' vol. 181, London 1890; "D6terminntion dee 616menta magnBtiques en France," par M. Th. Moureaux, Paris, 1886; nl~d "A magnetio eurvey of the Nethorlande for the epoch January 1, 1891," by Dr. Van Rijckevoreel, Kieuwe Verhondelingen van hot Bntaafmch Genootachap der Proefondervindelijke Wijebogeerte te Rotterdam, 1896. The maguotic survey of the State of Mieeouri, made between 1878 and 1882 by Prof. F. E. Nipher, approximatee to thie eyeteni, but for thorough analyele of local dieturba~lceea greater number of etatione for dip and inteneity would be deeirnble. 2Provided it be within the limits of our knowledge of the eeculnr variation.

TABLE OF THE 3fOSl' RECENT XAGNETIC DECLINATlONS OBSERVED IN THE UNITED STATES AND ADJACENT REGIONS.

'It is hardly necessary t o etate t h a t such a collection cnn not claim to be in any degree exhtanrrtire, ns i t is only through cool~erntionof those who may enjoy epecial faoilitiee or have ~ c c o a st o old reoordn that thin etate oan be approaohed.

The arrangement of the tabulation of the declinations collected1 to date, but giving only the latest observation :kt each place, is the samo as that of the preceding edition of 1889, viz, for each State, Territory, arid geographical subdivision two groups are formed, the first composed wholly of stations occupied by Coast and Geodetic Survey observers, the second of stations occupied by other observers. There nro n few exceptiolls to this for special reasons. The stations are arranged according to their latitudes, beginning with the lowest ihnd ending with the highest, which renders it quito easy to find i l l what localities magnetic observations have been made. I n this edition all special references to the source whence the obeervntions were derived are omitted in order to relieve tlie paper from unnecessary heaviness; this romurk, however, does not apply to newly added data. Footnotes relating to index corrections of compasses or to improvements of geographical positions are likewise omitted, all of which special ii~forrnation can be found in the preceding edition. Some concentration has also been effected, omitting the results a t stations closely crowded together, say within a square mile, or demanding condensation for other reasons, and substituting for them a mean value. The conteuts of the first, second, and third columns of the general table are sufficiently indicated by tlie respective headings; the next two columr~sgive the date (the year and fraction) of observatio~iuiid the observed decli~iation (iu degrees and fraction), a + sign indicating west, n ~ign east)declination. The column headed n D contains the reduction of the observed value to tlie adopted epoch 1900.0, which is clerivecl directly from the discussion of the secular'variation a t suitably selected sts~tioiis as given in last year's Annual lteport; a + indicates increasilig west (or decreasing east) declination, a - sign the reverse motion of the north end of the magnetic needle. To fmilitzte the evaluation (in time and space) of n D, a special set of secular ohange tables was prepared. These give for overy secular variation station and for every even year between 1830 and 1900, the reduction directly, together with its proper sign. If for any reason the change is

THE ISOGONIC CHART OF THE TTNITED STATES FOR THE EPOCH JANUARY, ~ ~ ~ ~ . - C ! O N S ~ ' R U ( I TION O F THE LINES OF ICQITAL DECLINATION.

Having thus obtained our material, ready to hand for chartillg, an accour~t of this process tho isogonic d u s t next be given. First, we have to remark that a graphical method for clrawi~lg curves mas preferred to an analytical one, since theil. general curvature was sufficielitly well known and no very Isrge upaces barren of maguetic stations mere encountered. Such, however, was not the case with Alaska and adjacent parts of the ocean, whero the use of a mathe~natical expression, mith its cumbersome adjunct, the lllethod of least squares, had to be resorted to in order to secure definiteness of location. Theso curves are here reprodnced, mith the eff'ect of the secular change during five years applied to refer them to the year 1900 (see chart No. 3). The curves are necessarily smooth, as, depending onc the roots of au equation mhich is s steady fu~lction of the latitude and longitude, they do not take cognizance of local dist~~rba~lces, whicl~, however, are supposed to be less frequent ovor sea than on land areas. When speaking here of ~llagl~otic disturbancoa we do not mean temporary ones, occurrir~g during observations, but refer to regiol~s perl~lai~ently disturbed, i. e., showing an irregular and anomalous distribution as conlpared mith regions. These disturbed areas ofteri present difficulty an equable distribution over surroundi~~g in attempting to recognize and represer~tthern, on account of their variation in extent and the amount of deviatiol~. If the latter is uinall i t may inix itself up with observing error; on tile other )laud, if the uxteilt be restricted, say to a fern square kilometres or to n few square miles, they may entirely escape recognition from want of observation withill the area. Theso irregulard s time^ as great, in mhioli case they can be properly ities may be spread over areas h u ~ ~ d r e of represented even on a chart of srnall scale. 1)iaturbances in distributiol~are shown by the distor- --------- . . - - . -- . . . 1They are given to tho nearest tenth of n degree (i. e., within & 3'), an accuracy c o n i r ~ ~ e ~ ~ s t with ~ r c l tor u osceeding t h a t which t h e d a t a thernselvoa may posreaa.

APPENDIX NO. 1.

151

tions of the isomagnetic curves traversing the disturbed region; ,if of small extent they are but no sharp known as disturbances; if of wide range they have been termed uregional,77 distinction betweeu them is possible. The older observations and all those made by meaxls of the coxripass are subject to large probable errors, which may be roughly estimated as between &B/ and 415' or more (those made a t sea as 430/ or more), whereas the results obtained by means of the magnetometer, which instrument is aluiost exclusively employed by the Burvey, may be depended up011 generally within &1/ to 43/. Errors iutroduced through the reduction to epoch will, czteris paribus, be proportional t o the elapsed time. Thus, in following the observed values too closely, there is danger that our ifiomagnetic curves represent by their sinuosities observing errors rather than abnormal distribution of magnetism. On this accouut the tabular values were divided into 'two groups of results of greater and of less reliability, and when plotted this division mas recog'nized as a help toward the xnost probable positioxi aud form of tho curves. I n many cases the geological formatioxi of the region, particularly if consisting of igneous rock, vill of itself point out probable limits of the disturbed region. It reed hardly be remarked that the employment of a graphical process of interpolation does not esclude the use of analytical treatment; on the contrary, the two methods may be applied together with advantage, as supplementary to oue another, but just how far to follow minute deflections and how nluch to generalize must, in a large measure, remain a matter of judgment and experieiice. I n places on tho chart where, from want of adequate information, the position of the isogonic ,curves are doubtft~l or indeterminate tlie fact is indicated by broken lines. The use of the accompanying chart No. 1is quite simple. The doclinatioxi for any place wit,hin its borders is either liad by inspection or by sixnple inter1)olation between the two adjacont curves; the value fou~ldis for 1900.0; for ally other year (and fraction) a reduction for secular , change between the epoch and given date must be applied. The contents of Appendix No. 1 Report for 1895, supply this reductioxl for the past time as well as up to the year 1900 and roughly for a few years beyond. For convenience, however, a lliap (No. 2) is appended to this paper, which shows the annual change of the declination durix~g the period 1890-1000, expressed in minutes of arc, for ix~creasiugwest or decreasing east declination and -for the reverse motion. The amount varios in time, but not sufficient,ly during the brief interval of tell years to cause any serious inaccuracy; its variation with geographical positioli must be estimated frolu the map. I t gives me pleasure to acknowledge the effective services of Mr. D. L. Hazard for applying the tabular reduction to epoch, axid of Mr. F. W. Clay for plotting the position of the stations on the chart. The plotting and the running in of the curves were done on a chartof scale 115 000 000 and the latter were then transferred to the more convenient chart of scale 117 000 000.

APPENDIX NO.2-1896.

ItESCJLTINQ. HEIGHTS FROM SPIRIT LEVELINQ BETWEEN OLD POINT COMFORT AN11 RICHNOND, VA., FROM OBSERVATIONS MADE BY J. B. WEIB, SUBASSISTAK'I!, BETWEEN SEPTElbfBER AND NOVEMBER, 1884; AND BY I. WINSTON, ASSISTANT, BETWEEN DEOEMBES, 1891, AND FEBRUARY, 1892.*

Submittod by the chief of the oomputing division for publication April 29, 1896.

I have the honor to submit herewith the results of the line of spirit levels between Old Point Comfort and ltichmond, Va., as revised by Mr. 0.13. French iu February last. The line was leveled ill 1884 by Subassistant J. B. Weir, and releveled in 1591-92 by ~ s s i s t a n t I. Winstan. Field and offloe reductions were mnde in due time. The releveling became necossnry in consequence of too great a discrepancy in the levels hetween Hagerstown, Md., as determined from Sandy Hook, N. J., and from Old Point Comfort, Va. A t Old Point; Comfort Light-House, the starting point of the levels, no lesss thau three primary bench marks (aud a t least one subsidiary one) were established. The one to which the tidal observations mere referred is known as the "Old Tidal bench mark." It was established by Lieut. W. R. Palmer in August, 1853, and is an irregularly shaped cut, about one-fourth of an inch deep, in the southwest face of the light-house, slid about 14 feet from the ground. The spirit levels are referred to the primary mark c L U," a copper bolt leaded in a stoue of the southwest side of the light-house. I t s center defines the starting level. I t was established in 1884 by Subassistant Weir. The other marks need not conceru us here. According to Weir, bench mark "U7'is 0.2478" or 00813 foot Below the Old Tidal bench mark. The two marks were fouud undisturbed by Assistant Winston in December, 1801. Oonnection of the line of lecela w i t h the average or half-tide level of the bay (and wMol~ ia taken ae identical with that of the ocean outside). The average sea level watl ascertained fiom observation~ of high and low waters between the years 1863 and 1878. Tho following results for one-half (H L) were obtained by the tidal division of the 0Bce.t For the period 1853-1869 the reduction is by J. Domnes; for the period 1870-1878 certain corrections were applied by.J. B. Boutelle for changes in the relation of the pencil of the tide gauges with reference to the mark on the light-house.

+

'With diegreln showing route line and position of bench mrke. - tRereduued and oomruunioated by L. P. Skidy.

As a rough verification of the relation of this average level with the Old Tidal mark i n 1888 (Se t.), we have reading of avera e levef 9.43 ft., and again in 1891 PAug.) the reading 9'50 ft. I n December, 1891, the marks on the light-house were found undisturbed.

Mean. 9.63 C 0.04 or 2.9353 9" c 0'012 911. Hence bench mark " U " above t h e half tide level, 2'6875 m r+ 0'012 u r .

The primary reference bench marks established a t Richmond, Va., in 1884, are the following: "07' on the granite doorsill of the freight depot of the Richmond, Fredericksburg and Potomac Railroad. '*PV on the granite doorsill of the east front of Richmond College. A third mark mas established in 1891 by Mr. Winston a t the new city hall to the left of the steps a t the mestarn entrance. It mas made a t the request of the city engineer and for special preservation. The mark "PV is 4.5516 m. above and the city hall mark 8.1541 m. below tho mark b'O." The line of levels follows the Chesapeake and Ohio Railroad, aud all the bench marks on the line determined in 1884 that could be fmnd were included in the verification work of 1591-92, thus furnishing the means for the computation of the probable error for the heights of the terminal marks a t Richmond. The condition of the line mas not favorable, since a great part of the roadbed mas made ground, with underlying swamp. The Weir line from September to Noveniber, 1884, mas run with spirit level No. 1as a simultaneous double line.* This, as experience has shown, can count only for a single line, siuce the physical and iustrumental conditions for the two lines mere essentially the same. The collar inecluality for level No. 1mas object end sinaller 2/'.30; the angular value for the telemeter threads mas 34' 04"-7. The lengths of the metric brass scales of the rods E and F a t given temperatures, as well as their index errors, are given in Appendix No. 7, Ooast and Geodetic Survey, Report for 1587 (p. 186). Tho Winston line of December, 1891, to February, 1898, mas run with spirit levels Nos. 5 and 6, as a single line in parts where the result agreed with that of bhe older measure, but with a repetition of thp measure, using the other instrument in cases of cliscoril with Weir's result. The -- - - - - . - . - . - -- -----" For explanation of method and description of instrl~ment Appendix No. 10, Coast and Geodetic Surrey Report
for 1888, and No.,Y, Report for 1887, may be consulted. The former given an account of levels run in 1884, t h e latter in 1885-86, by the same obeerrer and with the same instrument.

RESULTING HEIGHTS FROM SPIRIT LEVELING BETWEEN LIICHMONI), VA., AND WASHINGTON, D. C., FROM OBSERVATIOXS MADE BY J. B. WEIR, SUBASSISTANT, I N SEPTEMBER AND OCTOBER, 1853, AND SEPTEMBER AND OCTOBER, 1884, WITH RELEVELING BY J. B. WEIR BETWEEN RIUHXOND AND PltED'ERICKSBURG, VA., IX MAY AND JUNE, 18SG, AND VERIFIOATION LEVELING BETWEEN THE TWO CITIES BY I. m r ~ ASSISTANT, ~ ~ BETWEEN ~ ~ ~APRIL , AND JUNE, 1895."

Submitted for publication by Cllarlee A. Schott, Assistnnt, in aharge of Computing Division, September 17, 1896.

The following report on tbe resultii~gheights from spirit leveling between Itichmoi~d, Ira., and Washiugton, I). C., is herewith resyectfully submitted. The heights are taken up from tho bench mark a t the freight depot of tlle Richmond, Fredericksburg aud Potolunc Railroad, and known as bench illarli "0,"which is the startiiig point of the line. Tllu lieiglit of this mark above the nvcrago 1evc.l of tlie ocean becamo known by spirit leveling from Old Point Colnfort to Richlnolid and fro111tidal observations carried 011 for iuany years on Chesapealro Bay ne;lr Fort Illonroe. I t s heiglit is 58.1957 m.,or 100.030 feet. (Seo precediug appendix in this volume.) The line was flrst run in 1883-54 by Snbi~ssistant J. B. Weir, and repeated by him in l8S6 over about onehalf' of the distance, i. e., from Richmond to Fredericlrsburg, As mill bo seen from tho result when compared with tho average level of tlle Potomm a t Washington, D. C., the operatioil did not prove as satisfactory as was expected, and Assistant I. Wi~istou was directed in 1895 to rel-nn the whole line wit11 the viow of socuring a result which should be physically true and be within accepttable limits of accnmcy. The results are thus presented in three abstracts; the computations wero ~ n a d o in dnplicate, 0118 by the observers, the other lllainly by t118 ofnce coull)uters, A. S. Christie and J. Nelson. Tlle abstracts tlieiiiselres are duo to Mr. Winston. Route line.-It fbllows the tmclr of the Hichmoud, Fredericksburg aud Poto~linc Railroad via Ashlaud, Bovling Green, Fredericlcsb~~rg, and Alexandria, Va., wheiice it enters the District of diagram.) Total developine~itof line 185.6 kilometres, 01- 115.3 Columbia. (See accornl>aiiyi~~g statute miles. OBserz,ers and dates.-Tho first lovoling was executed by J. B. Weir between Septeiuber 1 1 ancl October 20, 1583, and resumed September 26 and completed October 4, 1SS4. The same observer rat1 over tlie southern half of tile line between May 28 and June 23, 1586. I. mTillsto~i following t l ~ same e tracks and tying oil to all of the former bench marks that had remailled ulldis. turbod, leveled over the line between April G and June 28, 1895. 1nstrziments.-Spirit level KO. 1and I i o d ~ E nnd F wero used in 1883-84. The metric graduations of the brass scales 011 rods E and F are correct a t tlie temperatul.es 160.7 0.and 180.9 C., respectivelg, nud their index corrections or projections beyond the zero line are 6.33 cm. (May G and November 17,1884) %nil6 . O G cm. (JIay G and Xovember 17,1884), respectively. P and Q are wooden rods, mado a t the office i n 1894-96; they are saturated mith paraffin; the metric graduations are marked by brass pins. Theso rods require no temperature correction, of tl~emsee Appeudix No. 8, Report their length being almost invariable; for a full descriptio~~ for 1895. All rods are provided with movable targets. Nicrorneter spirit lerel No. 1is describeci in-Appendix No. 1 1 ,Report for 1880 (illustrated on plates Nos. P G and 67),micrometer spirit level Xo. 3 is described in Appendix No. 15, Report for 1879 (illustratecl on plate No. 52); micrometer spirit level No. 5 was constructed a t the Survey Offico in 1888 and differs ouly in solno unessential details from No. 1. The method of observin,q.-It was as follows: In 1883-54 two parallel lines were run simnltaneously and in the same direction, but mith alternate ~ections (from 10 to 15 miles) run in opposite directions. On one of the lines rod E mas used, on the other rod I?, the rods being placed a t different distances from tlie instrnmeut; the long sights mere observed first during one day ancl t l ~ e short sights during the next day. Iu the verification work of 1886 only a single lino was run, but with its alternate sections (7 to 16 miles long) in opposite directions. In 1895 a ~imultaneous double line mas m u in one direction. The length of the sight line (instrument to rod) varies, ordinarily, between 75 and 125 m. for Weir observer, and esteuds to a somewhat greater distnnce for Winston observer.

Now the following consideratioris show that the results of 1883-84 call not possibly be correct and that they are affected by a cumulative error. Iu tlie first place we would remark that the 1 statute miles ~ilaltes i t safe to assume its width of the entrance of Chesapeake Bay of nearly 1 half tide or average level to be identical with that of the acljjacent oceitu, and the same nlay be said of the bay up to its Ilead; further, i t is apparent that the ascendiug slol)e of the Potolnac can not be great and may even be difficult to measure directly; the mouth of the river is 68 miles in width and the aspect of its course resembles more that of a brallch of' the bay than that of a steady flowiug river. Forcomparisou, we may cite the slope of the Jlississippi River during 333 statute miles of its lower course (mouth of the Red River to che gnlf), and daring a tiiiie wheu a t its lowest stage, the differeuce in height of the river level and gulf wax found to be 5.2 feet, ml~icl~ gives an ascendi~~g slope of 0-2 illch per mile very nearly; if we take for the l'otomac slope one-half of this, the cliffereuce iu height a t the bay and a t Wasllington, a distance of 100 miles nearly, would amount to b ~ l 10 t iuches or 0.254 m. Now by direct tidal observations, exteudil~gover five years (August, 1801, to August, 1896), a t the navy-yard a t Washiugton, arld by spirit leveling tlieuce to the Capitol beilch mark, tlie lleight of this mark above the half-tide level of the Poto~liaca t .the yard becomes * 27.612 4 0.015 m., and this is the rninilnum height above tlie sea level i t could liave, but adding to this for assumed slope of the river 0.254 m., or if this is deemed too much, say 0.160 IU., we get for the lleight of the Capitol B. M. 27.772 m. This result is corroborated by the line of levels from A~lnapolia,Md., of 1875, I?. W. Perkins, observer, and extended in 1880 a11c1 18SP by J. 13. Weir,t wl~ich gives for the ntinimutn height above the sea level 27.618 IU. k0.035 IU. Takiug n.nleau value, as most probable, we rnag adopt 87-70 m. 40.07 m. where the probable error is estimated. Comparing this with the value found in 1883-84 (viz, 27.043 m.)me find that tlie line of 1883-84 requires a correction here of + 0.66 m. A bimilar comparison betweell the mean tidal level and the reeults of spirit levels a t Fredericksburg leads to the following result: Reading of half-tide level 011 staff of U~iitedStates engineers, 1.5 feet. and bench mark H above staff reading 4.3 feet, 12.381 m.; heuce ~nil~irnulu height of H above sea level 12.281 m. + 0.914 iu.= 13.195 m. Comparing this with the value found in 1883-84 (viz, 12.803 m.), the c~rrection to the line here amounts to + 0.392 m. Now, Prederioksburg is approxilnately midw:~ybetween Itichlllo~id and Washington, and we may expect the correction to be about one half of what was deduced for Washthat ington. This is found to be so, roughly speaking, and groves the correctness of tlie state~nunt the levels of 1883-84 betweeu ltichinond and Wasliiugtou developed a cnmulativo error and 11eed proportional corrections. Suppose proceed southward, since gravity diminishes :~n(l the leveling profile projected on a meridian plarls passing between two cities, and let the average ordinate be h =30 metres; also take the latitude of Wasllington, = 380 52/, and that of Richmond, 370 32', hence A = 10 20f,arid tlie effect dne to the divergence will be d h =-0.0054 11. A cy sin. 2 cy =-0.0035 m, or about 33 mm. This is so small a quantity, particularly when comparetl with the corrections tli:~thail to be applied to our results, that we may dispense with any further cousitleration of it.
