RESULTING HEIGHTS FROM SPIRIT LEVELING BETWEEN WASHINGTOX, 11. C., AND HAGERSTOWN, Mu., FROM OBSERVATIONS MADE BY J. B. WEIR, SUBASSISTANT, BETWEEN JULY AND SEPTEMBER, 1883."

Submitted for pi~blicationby Charles A. Schott, Assistant in charge Computing Division, September 18, 1896.

Tlie following report on the resulting heights from spirit leveling between Washington, 1). C., and Hagerstown, Rld., is herewith respectfully submitted. The line connects with tide matex a t 3), Old l'oi~it Colnfort, a t Washington, and a t Annapolis (see preceding Appendices Nos. 2 a ~ i d whence mas obtained the height of tho West Washington (Georgetown) bench mark a t the Aqueduct Bridge, the starting point of the present line. At Hagerstown a junction is Inado with the line of levels brought over from Sandy Hook, N. J., via Easton and Harrisburg, Pa., of which an accourit is given i11 Appendix No. 11, Report for 1888. t Tho length of this loop is, between Sencly Hook and Hagerstown court-house, 441.37 km., thence to Washington, Capitol, 120.02; total, 551.3 km. A necessary check on the height of tlie Hagerstown bench mark is thus secured; from this place, hornever, to St. Louis, Mo., no check lines have'as yet been provided. Tho computation was mado in duplicate, one by the observer and the other by A. S. Christie, oftice computer; the final abstract is due to Assistant I. Wiuston. Rozcte line.-From West Was11ing;ton the line follows the towpath of tho Chesapeake and Ohio C;~nal as far as mTevertou,Md.; thence it follows tho branch of tho Baltimore and Ohio ltailroad to Hagerstown. Observer njzd c7ates.-Tpe observations are by Sub.assistant J. 13. Weir, and they comprise tho period July 24 to September 10, 1583. I~tstrl~?,le~tt.-S~,irit level Xo. 1 and metric rods A and B were used. Tho constunts for this i~istrumeutaro given iu the preceding appel~clis,but the collar inequality adopted, -3".12, is tlio mean of tile observnlions of July slid October, 18&3. Tho moodell rods with brass scales are 3 m. i 1 1 le~igtli,n ~ the ~ d scales are of standard \-due a t tt temperature of 660 F., nearly. Tho abutt i ~ ends ~ g of the rotls project 7.83 cm. below the zero of graduation. iliethotl oj'observi,ty.-It was tho same as stated in the preceding appentlis 011 the Ricllnloud\lTashingtou branch of levels, viz, two pnmllel lines run si~nultancously and in the same direction, olie by rod -ia ~ ( tho 1 other by rod 13, placed a t diB'erent distances tkom the instrun~ent. The long sigllt mas'obaerved f i r ~during t one day, but the short sight on the second clay. Acljacent sections of the lino were run in opposite direotions. On the average the leugth of tho sight line is less than 100 m.

APPENDIX NO. 8.-1896.
RESULTINQ HEIGHTS FROM SPIlLlT LEVELING BETWEEN JEFFERSON CITY, MO., A S D HOLLIDAY, ICANS., FROM OBSERVATIOWS BY I. WINSTON, ASSISTANT, AND F. A. YOUXG, AID, BETWEEN APRIL 21 A S D OCTOBER 13, 1891.e

Submitted for publication by Chaa. A. Schott, Assistant in oharge of Computing Division, October 1, 1896.

I have the honor to submit herewith rt report on the resulting heights from spirit loveling of rt line commencing 8 kilometres (5 statute miles) east of Jefferson City, Mo., and extending to Hollidrty, Kans., about 2 kilometres (14 statute miles) westerly of lcansas City, Mo. I t is a continuation of the line of levels which starts from tlie bencll mark on the bridgo across tlie -Mississippi a t St. Louis, known as bellch mark K,, and is published as Appendix KO. 2, Report for 1893, part 2, pages 1936. In that appendix the resulting levels are carried as far as tho vicinity of Jefferson City; in the present report the distances and heights relative to K, will bo continued. This Inark is ou the snme level as the so-called &'CityI)irectrixn a t St. Louis, aud was used as reference mark .by the Missouri ltiver Colnluission in its leveling betweell that city and Kansas City and beyoiii1.t Tlle line \\-as rull tjvicn, one observer leveling in o forward direction, the other in the opposite direction, and each observer using his own instrument, bnt tlie same rods. noz~te line.-Tho liue follo~vs the Missouri Pacific Railway as far as ' ICansas City, whence it follo~rs the Atchison, Topeko and Sauta P e Itailway to Holliday, Kans. Observers crnd dates oj' lere1i)tg.-The observers were I. \17inston and I?. A. Young. Thoy worked a t alternate poriods attelidi~lgto observing and computing. Tho loveling was done between April 21 aud October 13, 1891. I~utrz~a2e)rts and yoas.-The micrometer spirit levels Nos. 5 and G mero coiistructed a t the Survey O a c e in 1885, after the patter11 of spirit level No. 1,for which see Appondix No. 11, lieport for 1880. They differ from No. 1ouly in some lni~ior detail*; one of these is the perfect balancing of the weight of the telescope resting on tlie two collars during observation, i. e., when the focal edjustment is inade ,zad \\.hen the shade cover is in place. nfetl~odo f observing.-The method adopted this season was the same as that followed or1 the pl.eceding part of the line between Etlah aud Jefferson City (Appendix No. 2 , Report for 1593, part 2, 1). 38), viz, two independent uleasures are made, one in tile forward or westerly direction by one of the observers and the other in the oppos~te or easterly direction by the aecoud observer, but ou different days, aud each observer using his own instrument, TVinston, No. 5, aud Young, No. G, but the same rods, N and 0, and toward the end of tho season Rods I aucl K. The liue was divided of?' in convenient stretches of' about 10 km. in lengtli, the observers being olig;igcd alternately in field work and in cornputring work; in case their two measures of such a subdivisiori when compared proved riot quite satisfactory, a third ~neasure was made. The average distance between alld the rod was about 95 In. the itlstru~ne~lt Con~putntions.-The Aeld colnputation is by the observers, the office compukttion by 8. F. Flynu, aided by L. Pikeand li. G. Ogdeu; the cornparisoti and final results are due to Mr. wins to^^. B. M. XXV.--1888

AND

1891.

Established byAssistantG. Bradford,in 1888. See his description of bench marks, New Hav'el~, Mo.. to Jefferson City, Mo., 1888. When visited in April, 1891, the B. M. was found undisturbed. It is on the abutment to the first trestle east of mile post 119, instead of zoest, as stated in the description, and is on the end of the wing mall to the west abutment, south of the track. I t is very indistinctly marked.

B. M. XXVI.-1888

AND

1891.

Established by Assistant G. Bradford, in 1858. See his description of bench marks, New Haven, Mo., to Jefferson City, Mo., 1888. When visitecl in April, 1891, the bottom of the square hole was found so uneven that i t was not used in tho work. B. M. 90 (85). Established by the Missouri River Commission. The pamphlet published by thern in Mag, 1885, entitled "Descriptions and Elevations of Bench Marks on the Missouri River," gives the following description: ~'IIorizontalfurrow in head of copper bolt, leaded into rock of riverward cut b c c of Capitol IIill, Jefferson City, Mo." The hill 011 thu liortl~ side has been cut away to permit the constructioll of the Missouri Pacific Railroad and presents about 30 feet of rock above the B. M. The bolt is about 36 feet above the ground and 35 paces west of east end of rock cut. It projects 1inch outside the face of the bluff, and is bent slightly downward. It is not firmly fixed in position, as i t can be moved a little up and dowu with the fingcrs. The connection is certainly rnado within half an inch. Two and n half feet above and a little to the left of the B. M., the slnooth surface of the rock is marked as follows:

A P P E N D I X NO. 6.-1896.
ESTABLISHMENT OF THE UNITED STATES NAVAL OBSERVATORY CIRCLE, AKD THE DETERRIISATION OF THE GEOGRAPHICAL POSITlOS O F THE CESTElt OF THE CLOCK ROOM.
B y E. D. PI~ESTOS, Assistant.

On the 1st day of August, 1594, a joint resolution of Congress mas approved, which provided for the establishment of a circle around tho United States Naval Observatory. The said act \\-as embodied iu public resolution No. 3G, and was entitled:
8 provision for guarding the clolicnto nstronomicnl instruJoint reeolution t o establish an observatory circle nletits at tho United Stntee Narnl Obscrvntory sgainst emolio or currents of heated air in their neighborhood, nnd untlne vibrations from trafflc upou the extension of publio thoroughfaree in the vicinity, trnd for other purposes.

Section 10, of the act just cited, reads as follows:
That the snid appraisers nre horeby nuthorized to call upon the Superintendent of tho Coast and Geodetic Survey to make such surveys ne ]nay be necessary to carry into effect the provisions of this act, and the snid Superintendent is anthorized and requirod to make such survey8 under the directiou of the said Commi~sionem.

The appraisers named by the honorable Secretary of the Navy, and under whom the survey mas undertaken aud carried out, mere Eon. John W. Itoss, chairinau of the commission el.^ of the District of Columbia; Mr. T. 13. TlTaggaman, and Capt. I". V. BlcSair, U. S. I S . , Superintendelit of the Naval Observatory, I mas most offieieutly aided in the field and office work by Messrs. J. B. Boutelle and C. C.Plttes, of the Coast and Geodetic Survey. Tho provisions of the joint resolution, briefly stated, were as folloms: A circlo with tho centre coiilcidii~gmith the centro of the clock room and with a radius of 1000 feet mas to be establislied and described ou tho gronnd. All that portion of the original Naval Observatory property lying outside tho said circlo 1ras to be sold, aud all that land lying within the said circle and uot then belonging to the United States 1vas to be acquired by purchase. The methods by mhicll these transfers mere to be made, asmell as the steps to be taken in case of uonagreement as to price between purch:tsers and sellers, and other possible contingeucies, are well clefined in the act of Congress. They form, liowever, no part of the work ~uldortaBen by tlle Coast and Geodetic Survey, and are outirely without tho provirlce of this service. The present paper, therefore, has for its object a briefaccouut of the method employed in 1;tying out the circle, a statement of the :kccuracy attailled in the filial results, and, as incident thereto, a new determination of t-lioposition of tho centre of the clock room, which is the initial point of longitudes for the United States. Several methods mere suggested for the establishment of the circlo. The first ono was simply circle which lay over the most level part of the grounds, doterselect that radius of the prol~osod mine One point of the circulnference by direct measurement, and run in the entire circle by the ordinary method of tangents, as olnployed by railroad engineers. This did not appear feasible, or a t least did not seem capable of giving a high degree of accuracy in the results, without extraordinary care, on account of the extremely abrupt nature of the topography of some parts of the circle. Moreover, this method had alrertdy been employed by some surveyors a fenr years ago, and
85

286

UNITED STATES COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY.

the closing error mas given as 1foot. It was desirable to mark the boundaries luore closely than this. Besides, a cliffere~it method of getting a t the same results would check tlle previous deter111illation aud give increased confidence in the work. The second method proposed mas that of using a \tapeline of 100 feet length as a telemeter and determining its distance by nleasuring the angle subtended a t tho centre of the circle. Pour such clistarlces mere to be fixed, and the intervening quadrants were to be established by the ordinary way, already mentioned. This plan, although elegant in conception, mheu examined closely did not turn out to be practicable. In the first place, because i t mould have involved cutting a number of lines through the beautiful groves of the Observatory, and secondly, because i t required a very high degree of accuracy for the measure of the angles a t the contre. A simple geometrical construction shows that the uncertainty in the length of one of the radii is about twenty times that of the angular measures a t tho ceutre: or, using the formula for finite differences,
Ab=

- a sill n C sin ( C + n C )

.

it appears that an error of 1 ~ e c o n d in the angle ( C ) a t the centre mould imply an error of abont one-tenth of a foot in the distance ( b ) from the centre; a is taken as 1 000 feet, the radius of the circle; the value of C for this particular Cat30 is 20 61' 6'i1'.5, this being half the angle subtended by a chord of 100 feet on a circle of the dimensions given. Besides, sinco 1second on the circumference of a circle of this radius is in the neighborhood of one-sixteenth of an inch, the pointiugs mith the telescope must define the limiting lines of the telemeter to this degree of accuracy, mhich mould require an instrument capable of supporting a power greater than mas then available. Moreover, i t would have been a difficult matter to keep the tapeline a t a known length within one-sixteenth of an inch. Although quite easy under favorable conditions, in the present case the precautio~ls necessary as regards temperature, tension, inclination, etc., mould have made the and unsatisfactory one. It mas therefore evident that by this method operation a tro~iblesome the uncertairity of the length of the radii of the circle mould be abont a quarter of a foot. The third method (see PI. I),mhich mas adopted, consisted in inscribirig a decagon within the proposed circle, making the apices of the angles a t the centre coincident mith the centre of the clock room, and the exterior sides as near to the circumference as the configuration of the grouucl wonld admit. I t mas desirable to have all the corners of the decagon near and within the circle; in two cases, however, in order to get intervisibility, i t was necessary to place the stations a short distance outside the circle, and in others, to avoid building exceptionally high signals, the points mere located cousiderably inside the circumference. But these distances mere not so great that their measurement involved errors greater than would necessarily ensue from the instruments and methods employed in the triangulation. One of the exterior sides of the decagon was measured as a b a e line. Three augles mere measured in each triangle, and the triangulation mas carried around to close on the original line. Owing to the fact that two of the exterior points jH and I ) were not intervisible, the point I mas detern~ined in two mays, mhich supplied a check equal in point of accuracy to that accordbd any of the other stations. The station a t tho centre mas on a scaffold 20 feet high, built over the clock room, and having the point of occupation vertically over the centre of the room. By t h i ~ procedure the greatest uncertainty in the lengths of the radii did not exceed three-hundredths of a foot. The following were the angle^ a t the centre adjusted for station error:

The above table slloms that any one of the five measures is sufflciently accura,te for the triangulation which i t was intended to construct upon the base line. It is, however, but a reassertion of o fact many times established that i t is much easier to attain high accuracy in linear meaaurement than i t is to preserve i t in the angular measurement of geodetic work. The followil~g were the resulting lines in the different triangles:
nadinl sides. Exterior sides.

Tho average correction to on augl? a t the center to close the horizon was 0"-16, while the average correction to an angle to close tho triangles was 3".1. It should be stated here that diti'erent instruments mere employed in the two cases. The angles a t the center mere measured with theodolite KO. 140 (8" diam.), reading to 2 seconds. The exterior poilits were occupied with tlieodolite KO.156 (611diam.), reading to 5 seconds; moreover, the measures mere not made by the m~ne observer. Since one of t h o sides is about 330 feet in length, an error of 211 in a11 adjacent augle would imply an inaccuracy of centering and pointing not greater than one-twenty-fifth of RIL illch. There are few signal poles used in triangulation' that mill give the same centre to this degree of precision when observed from different sides, so that an error of a few seconds mas quite within unavoidable discrepancies. The averpge length of a radial line is 953 feet; the average exterior side is 742 feet long. The side of n triangle is then, say, approximately 850 feet. Two seconds being about 1-100000 part of the radius, me might expect in each new base an error of less than oue one-hundredth of a foot from angular errors in it8 own triangle; but there wo~tldbe some compensation of errors in the continuous development of the scheme of figures.

288

UNITED STATES COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY.

As a matter of fact, we may readily calculate the error to be expected in the last or closing aide from the known probable errors of the base and measured angles. Applying the usual formula

where a and b are the length^ of the last side and base, and where A indicates angles opposite the required sides and B those opposite the given sides, and v-here r , and rz stand for the probable error of the base and of an angle, respectively, me fin11 a resulting probable error of 0.02 feet from both base line and angle measures. That of the base line is, homever, without significance when compared with tlie uncertainties in the angle measures. Tlle actual discrepancy found agrees sufficiently well mith this, and me may therefore conclude tliat an accuracy has been attained in the final result commensurate with the precision of the instruments employed and in reasonable accord with the method of observing. If we start from the nleasured base A B with leugth of 4W-SO feet, and carry the computation around the d ~ a g o to n close again in the same line, we derivs a value for 11 B of 444.70 feet. This circuit i~ by the most direct may, and ignores for our presellt purpose the poi~lt I,as well as the figures l i T 0 I and A 0 I. If, homever, me carry tlle computatiou by tlie sarue route around to the l i ~ l I< e 0 and then set out from the base agaill anci proceed iu the opposite direction, meeting the previoris computation on the line K 0, get a discrepancy of 0.03 feet. This might have been expected, since the probable error of the last side, as me see fro111the formula, is a function of its length. If we calculate the error to be expected in this line from the known probable errors of the base line and the angular measures, we get 0.04 feet, which is also practicslly the discrepanoy fouild. A s the computation was carried to tlle tliird decimal place only, a diflerence in results of one unit in the second place may occur through loss by decimals. We may t,herefore give 0.03 feet as the greatest uncertainty of any of the radii of the circle. With the establishment of the Observatory Circle arose t l ~ e necessity for an accurate survey of the original property. This was done in October, 1804, all the original points being recovered, and tlie astronomical azimuth of the sides being determined by conllectiou with the side 0 0 of the triangulation. A t the request of the Navy Department, Plot I, lying north and east of Massachusetts avenue, was subdivided illto 31 lots, as shown in PI. I. The approximate dimensions were furuished by Capt. P. V. McSair, :md the boundaries were traced on the ground and permanently marked by heavy stakes. This plot was subseqnently rearran'ged by tho Department into three subdivisions. The bearings and distances of the two arrangements are on file in the archives of the Survey. As a n ~ a t t e r of curiosity it may be stated that in disposing of this land the Department was forced to name the price of one of the subdivisions t o eight decimal places. The two conditions ilnposed were that Subdivision B, together with Lots X I to XVIII, i. e., 4-25 acres, should be sold for 30 cents per foot, and to satisfy certaiu other conditio~isthe total ares of 14.43 acres should be sold for $141 454.27. These conditions being rigid, the remaining 10.20 acres had to be disposed of a t $0.19336765 per square foot.
THE DETERJIINATION OF THE POSITION OF THE NAVAL OUSERVATORY.

The occupation of the center of the clock room mads i t possible to make an independent for longitudes in the United Btates. Three prominent triangudeterminatiou of the initial l~oint lation points of the Coast and Geodetic Survey were visible from this station, which enabled us to fix the position by the three-l)oi~it problem with a very short series of observations. Each pointing a t the center was n ~ a d e in three positio~is of tlie circle 1200 apart with two series in each position; oue series consists of a pointing with tolescope direct, and one with telcscope reversed, so tlint each angle was given twelve independent measures. Tlie facility with wllich tliis last determiiiatio~i was mndo, as well as the accuracy of the results, seems to warrant a statement 11ereof tlie difterent determinations.

I n July, 1SS1, Mr. F. 0. Donn: under the direction of Mr. Charles Junken, of the United States Coast and Geodetic Survey, made a triangulation to determillo tlie prol~osed site of tho ~ i e w Naval Observatory. I t was based on the known points, Reugley, Colambiau Oollege, and Qeorgetown College, as shown by the following sltetcli:

No. I

The adjustment of this work gave two angle equations and ouu side equation, from which the position of the cupola on the old house standing a t the time near the present Observatory was

By subsequent linear measurements, Prof. William Harkness connected the position of this cupola with the center of the clock room. These give as the result of Junken's triangulation:

I n 1803 Prof. William Harkness determined the position of the new Naval Observatory, by means of a small 4-inch theodolite, reading to 20 ~econds of arc. The follomii~gstations mere occupied : New Naval Observatory, center of 8inall dome. Old Naval Observatory, center of small dome. Soldiers' Home, center of southwest turret of tower. The following sketch (No. 2) shows the relative poitions: Professor Harkness kindly furnished a copy of his observations to the Superintendeut of the Coast and Geodetic Survey, and from them Mr. Schott has deduced the position of the new Naval Observatory, employing in the adjustment one angle equation and four side equations. A NEW SOLUTION O F A PRINCIPAL QGODETIO PROBLEM.

By C r u s . H. KUMXELL,Computer.

I n u y article in No. 3671 Astr. Nachr. " On the determination of the shortest distance bet\veeu two points on a spheroid," I stated on page 105 that the inverse problem could not advantageously be solved by the forms given. A closer study, however, has gradually developed new forms well adapted to its lnost comprehensive solution. This geodetic problem can properly only occur between intervisible points, since one of its data is the astronomical azimuth al from the first to the second point. This must, however, first be reduced to the a,zimuth of the geodetic line or brachisthode a 1 by a formula first (leveloped by Bessel and given by Helmert in the forrn:

< y and new amplitudes all, all AD', which leads to a moro convergent series. Such Y'=~a series is given by Helmert, Vol. I, page 221, etc. Or we may descend still further in the modular scale until the modulus vanishes, as I have done in my article mentioned above. The best device

The agreement with the results by the Coast Survey formulw is alac satisfactory, only the longitude A2 is greater by OU.002. I come now to the consideration of tho third class of geodetic problems, when the distance is fio As small that the convergence of the series depends almost entirely on the small quantity The

.,

effect on my solution would consist in the omission of the reduction of astron-mica1 to geodetic azimuth, the computation of A c in one term, and in passing directly from tan & dj:. to tan 3 dg,by the approximate relation : b' tan 4 Aq= zoos 2(e,ql)'tan& A+ (m) With all these eimpIi0cations7 however, it is easily seen that the unnecessary rigor of my forms does not very well suit this class. I t is much more convenient to compute rlp, AA, and A a from a few terms of the series given by Helmert, page 2G8. We find this plan followed in the convenient tables published by Prof. R. S. Woodward, pages 70-77 of Smithsonian Oeogra,l)hical Tables. He uses for each of the required quantities two terms and checks by Dalby's Theorem. Thus he has in our notation :+ A?=--

- p" 2R7j; tan q1ds2sin2 n, + m Pi' A l = -- As sin a, - "i sin pl As2ain a j cos +XI N,

and tabulates the factors depending only on the Intitucie. The limiting distance for the nee of these tables is given by t-he author 12 OOOnl for 011-01to be reli~ble. The Coast Survey Tables go an order higher in the computation of Aq, using the equiva.lent of the following four terms from Helmert7s more complete series, page 298, which, written in our b2 N= are as follows: notatioii and employing the principal radii of curvature R = n cog3(e,q)' cos (e,p)

APPENDIX NO.8-1896.

TABLE'S O F CROSS SECTIOWS ON THE NORTH SHORES O F NANTUOKET AXD MAlITHAS VINEYARD, MASSACHUSETTS.

By H. L. Maa~hmra, Assistant.

.

COASTAND GEODETXO SURVEY, Washington, D. C., February 29,1696. SIR: 1have the honor to submit tabulated cross sections of the shores of the islands of Nantucket and Marthas Vineyard, off the coast of Massachusetts, being the results from the reduction of the field notes of a party iu my charge during the summer of 1894. The comparison of the position of the shore line (high-water line) in 1887 and 1894 indicates a retreat of the shore of 0.18 m. per year for that part of the north shore of Nantucket lying betmeen the harbor of Nantucket aud the western end of the island. This large erosion was not anficipltfed, judging by the comparatively sheltered position of the northern shore, but it might have beeu inferred from the well-defined retreat of both the eastern and southern s h o r e ~ ~ t h for at the former having beeu found to have been 0.19 m. per year and for the latter 1-42 m. per gear between 18PG and 1891. The reduction of the cross sectious measured on the north shore of Marthas Vineyard between the harbor of Edgartown and the bluffs south of Oottage City indicates an advance of this sandy shore a t the rate of 0.2 m. per year betweell 1888 and 1894. This is so far the only instance where an accretion to the shore i8 uoted on either of the islands under examination. Tho observations made in 1891-92 on the south shore show a rapid wasting away of the coast line. The yearly loss has not been ascertained, as no co~.nparisonhas as yet been made with earlier surveys; but we know that the waste on the south shore is not compensated by any known accretion to the uortl~ern shore. Before closing I mould respectfully recommend tho reduction of the field notes of cross sections measured betmeell Loug Point and the entrance into the inner harbor of Nantucketthis would co~uplete the contour of the islalid-and also that a co~nparisonbe made between the results of tho reduction of the observtttious made on the south shore of the "Vineyardvin 1891-92 with earlier surveys. In asking that the accompanyir~g tables be published in tho A~lnual Report, i t may be said that two objects will be attrtined-one, tho multiplication of copies of informatiou, tlie value of which increuses as time passes; and another, by offering the l~ossibility of reproducing with accuracy the position of tho shore line at the date of the surveys compared, or, in other words, reproducing the topographical delineatioa of the shore line without recourse to the aid of the topographical sheet. Very respectfully, HEN& L. MARINDIN,
OF THE

OFFICE

I

Assistant.
Gen. W. W. DUFF~ELD, Szcperintendent United fitate8 Coast and Qeodetio Burvey. 8. Doc. 35-20
905

APPENDIX NO. 9-1896.

FIELD METHOD O F REDUCING PORTABLE TRANSIT TIME OBSERVATIOXS.

By Q. H. PUTNAM, Aeeietsnt.

These notes are intended to give an elample and brief explanation of the method of time reduction as now generally used in field computations on the Oomt and Geodetic Survey. I n the offlce computations and more rigid mork the method of least square reduction is adhered to, as explained by Aseistant Schott in Appendix No. 14, Report Coast and Geodetic Survey for 1880 (CgDetennination of time by means of the transit instrument"), and as generally given in works on practical astronomy. This field method makes use of successive approximations to determine the collimatiou ( o ) and azimuth ( a ) errors, and takes no account of weights. The method here described differs from approximate methods sometimes employed, in that all the observations are combined in deriving c and a. As by its use some saving of labor may be effected and results may be obtained not differing materially for some purposes from those derived with the Illore rigid reductions, i t will be found of value for field mork. I n the following memoranda the nomenclature and formulas used by Assistant Schott in the above-mentioned appendix are adhered to, and reference may be mado to that paper for general instructions in regard to time determinations, adjustment of instruments, arid full explanation of the various corrections. I n Form l* ore given the observations of a set of ten stars as read from a chronograph sheet, with level readings and reduction as far as the derivation of a - t ~ ;the tl here indicating the observed time of transit corrected for rate, diurnal aberration, and inclination, but not corrected for collimation or azimuth errors. The corrections for rate and diurnal aberration and the pivot inequality may often be neglected in field reductions, but are shown here for the 8ake of completeuess. In this example the level readings with telescope pointing north and south are combined separately, and the mean then taken to derive the level error of the instrument for each group of stars. This is done to avoid the unequal effect of any lack of symniutry in the pivots; and to give equal weights to the separate readings it would bo desirable that the nortli and south
-

*The couetanta of the iuetrun~elitu ~ e d in tl~ia example are ae followe: 1 tlivieioli of ~triiling level = lU.674 (=0'0279e. x 4). Pivot iiieq~~nlity =-0.010e. Band \\*'eet. Equatorial iutervale of linen, Bnnd Weet,
S.

Line

I
2

1- 15.20

3 4 5 6

+ -

readings should be equal in number, as for instance two north and t v o south (in this esample they are unequal). There is also shown a convenient method for obtaiuing the average time of transit from the eleven lines. In the column to the right of the observed times the time for the ~niddle line is written, aud below i t the sums respectively for each two lines a t nearly equal intervals from the middle. These sums should of course be approximately equal and double the middle time, thus affording a ready check on ally discordant observation or erroneous chronograph reading. A t the foot of the column the sum of the whole is written, and this divided by eleven of course gives the average time for the eleven lines, which is then written beneath the observetl timee. I n general, this average can be arrived a t by adding only the decimal part of the secoutl column and such part of the integral numbers as exceed double the middle time, as will be understood by examining the example. I n the case of two stars in this set, the observations were not complete, and the reduction is made by the equatorid intervals. Where only s few lines are missed and the lines are uniformly spaced, a fair approximation can be obtained by taking the mean of remaining lines equidistant from the middle. An approximate reductioll can also bc obtained by comparing the observed li~les with observations of the same star on another evening. The balance of the computation on this form follows customary metheds, and is explained by the marginal data*. The a - t , a t the foot of the columns represents the chronometer correction from each star, uncorrected for the collimation and azimuth errors of the instrument. I n Form 2 is shown the derivation of the collimation (c) and azimuth (a) errors of the instrufrom each star. The a - t l derived in Form 1 are ment, and the final chrouometer correction ( AT) written together in a column, grouped for the two positions of the instrument, followed by columns containing the coIlimation ( C ) and azimuth ( A ) factors of the stars, Tilo observing list is so selected that each group of stars observed in one position of the instrument shall contain a low north or azimuth star and several stars near the zenith or time stars. The latter arc preferably some north and eome south of the zenith, so that their mean azimutl~ factor shall be nearly zero. If this is impracticable i t is desirable for convenience in computatioll that the mean azimuth factors for the two groups shall be nearly equal, Such a selection of time stars as will, as far as possible, eliminate instrlimental errors is important, though it ix not always practicable, as for instance in high latitudes, where stars north of the zenith are too slow to make good time stars. In tbis computation to derive c and a, the time stars in each positior~of the instrument are combined and treated as one star, by taking t h e mear~s of their a-t,, and of their star fautors O and A, respectively, these means being written below the separtte tars in this form, together with the azimuth stars. On the assumptiorl that the means of the time stars in the two positions of the instrument are equally affected by the azimuth correction, the first al)proximation to c is found by dividing the difference between the mean a- tl, by the difference between the C. I n the

Using this approximation to c, the correction Cc i s then subtracted from the a - t , of the means of the time stars aud of the azimuth stars, and the values in col~lmn a - t , - C c obtained. Separate values for the azimuth error of the instrument are then derived for each position of the instrumellt by dividing the difference between the a-2,-Cc for the meall of the time stars and the azimuth star by the difference between their A. APPENDIX NO.10-1896.
DETERMINATION OP THE CONSTANT O F ABERRATION FROM LATITUDE OBSERVATIONS WITH THE ZENITH TELESOOPE AT HONOLULU, H. I., AND SAN FRANCISUO, UAL.
Report by E. D. PRESTON, Aeeistant.

THE CONSTANT OF ABERRATION.

The results of the work on the constant of aberration have been made public in Bulletins Nos. 28 and 32. Since their appea,rauce considerable work has been done in this direction and the observations by the methods explained in the aforesaid bulletins lead tovalues agreeing very closely wit11 the generally accepted constaut. The mean of the results from the series a t Honolulu and San Fraucisco gives the value 20."458, which differs only 01'*005 from the mean of 24 results given by Professor Newoomb* and only 01'*003from the adjusted value by Professor Harkness,t and moreovor lies between them. The contribution of the United S t a b s Coast and Qeodetic Survey to this important problem has never yet appeared i l l the Annual Report, and it is therefore inserted in the present volume with some minor changes end additions to the original matter as it; appeared in the bulletins. The amount of data utilized in the present case is considerable. The actual observations a t Honolulu extended over a period of about thirteen months, and thoso a t Sen Francisco about fifteen months, and the total number of conditional equations employed ww 9 138, of which about one-fourth contained four and the remainder two unknown quantities. The insertion in the Annual Report of these two papers combined into one appendix and somewhat amplified make8 the Report complete in its information as to the work of the office aud gives the defer~llinatiorlof the constant of aberration by the Coast and Geodetic Survey a permanent form.
DETfiIlMINA TlON OF THE CONSTANT OF ABERRATION.
HONOLULU OBSERVATIONS.

The astronomical observations made by the author a t Waikiki near Honolulu in 1801 and 1892 showed conclusively that tlie latitude of this placo had a periodic variation. I t s value o n ' ~ u l ~ 0,1801, was 210 16' 24".41 and for any subsequent time during tho period of observation it may be fouud by substitution in the formula: Latitade. =210 16' 24'/-386 +0.038 cos 8-0.297 sin 8 -0.039 cos 28-0.006 siu 28 +0.040 cos 38+0.001 sin 38 where 8 is the angular distarice of the pole from i t s assumed place on July 0, on the supposition that its daily motion is 00.925.
,

*The Elernentcl of the Four Inner Planets and t h e Fundamental Couetants of Astronomy. Waehington, Qovernrnent Printing Offlce, 1896. t The Solar P ~ ~ r a l l a and r its Related Constants. Washington, 1891. S . Doc. 35-23 353

354

UNITED STATES COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY.

The work having come under Professor Xewcomb's observation, he made the uuggestion that the individual results as already prepared for publicatiou should be discussed with a view of bringing out a correction to the c o ~ ~ s t aof n taberration. The method proposed contemplated a simultaueous determination of the constant of abcrratioil and the changes of latitude, and the solution was a11 the more desirable because recent worlr indicates that the usually accepted value for this coustant (20".445)is susceptible of improvement and also that by a combined determination me should have an independent check on the law of latitude change deduced from these same observations. The plan to be followed in the solution was outlined by Professor Nemcomb and transmitted to the Superintendent of the Coast and Geodetic Survey in letter of Jauuary 14, 1593. On accouut of other duties the work could not be taken up immediately, but during the latter part of May, while on leave of absence a t Spruce Grove, Pa., I formed more than 2 000 of tho contlitionnl equations. The remaining ones mere computed after my return and the subnormals were derived by Mr. Moss during the month of June. After several interruptions the subject mas again taken up and prepared for publication. The following extract is from Professor Newcomb's letter above referred to:
hfemorandum for determining eimultanoouely t h e variations of lntitude and tho constnnt of aberration fro111n homogeneous series of obsorv:~tionsof pairs of stare with t h e zenith telescope, t h e latitude from ench individunl pair, using assumed declinations, having first been completely deterrninod. Lot 118 R = t h a t part of t h e reduction t o apparent place which depends on the aberration

= Cot + Dd' =h cos (H+a) sin 6

+ icoe 6

.

R+R' A =----R nnd R ' being t h e reduction for t h e North an11 South stare of a pair respeotively. 2 x 20.45 N = a n angle increasing uniformly with the timo, so as t o mako a revolution in 386 days. q , = t h e lntitude derived from a einglo observation of n singlo pair of stars. q,= an approximate arbitrarily assumed value of t h e latitude to be used unchanged throughout.

Then each individual latitudo from a pair of stars will give rise t o an equntion of condition of tho form z + x cos N + y sin N - A p = d q where the significanoe of the four unknown quantities z, x, y, and p are z correction t o latitude minus correctiou of half sum of declinations of pairs of stnre, quantities mhioh need not and can not be determined ~eparately. x and y= coeffloients of periodic vnrintion of latitude p =correotion to constant nberration. The unknown quantity z will havo the same value for t h e same pair of' stars all t h e may through, but not for any two pairs. The shortest and most rigorous methode of solving the equations of condition will then be this. Divide the equations into as many groups as thore are pairs of stars, all the equations from ench pair forming a group. Form ench group from the normal equatiou for four unknown qnantities in t h e usual way. 5upl)osing all the equations t o bo of equal weight, the normal in z mill be merely t h e sum of the groups. From the normal in z thus fouucl cletermino z ua a function of tho other three nnknowna and of the sum of the values A q , which mill bo dolle by morely dividing t h e sudl by the number of equations. Substitute this value of z in the other three normals derived from t h e group, thus getting three equntione, which we may call "subuormale," involving only x, y, nnd p. Hnving done this with all the groups, the el1111 of a11 the subnormals in z will be the filial normal eqiirttion for determining x, and so on with t h e other unknown quantities. 'I'he principle of this method differs from thnt of the method ndoptod by the Germane in two points. I t sssumes t h a t during the time of any eeriee of 01)eorvntione which are combinod to attain a singlo set of rttsnlte the changes in the latitnde cnn be represented b r e, singlo periodic term of known period. It does not assume t h a t this lam is valid outaiile the pnrticular eeriee under discussion. On t h e other hand, t h e German method makes no hypothesis respecting n lam of vnriation of the latitude except t h a t the lntitude remnina constant during certain short intervals of time. Bnt t h e present methocl involves n more rigorous adjustment of the declinations of tho fltare,since prnctically each star is cousidered indeponilently ne a group by itself. I n other worils, the value of z for ench star being t s aaaumed declination, all the declinations will be reduced t o a uniform, compnrable eyste~li. applied t o i

It so happens that the period during which observrttioris mere made corre~pondsallnost precisely to time of revolution of the principal axis of inertia of the earth nbout the axis of rotation.

This tliffers so little from that adopted ill the discussion of the variations of latitilde that, for the sako of convenience in dealing with the circular functions, it mas assumed as the period, and tho initial v;lluo mas placed a t June 6. The difference of apparent and adopted period, from Chandler's mean period of about 428 days, vould arise from the addition of his annua,l term. For facility of computation, instead of using the equation in the form given by Professor This amounts to changing p into - p ; that Nemcomb on page 3, + A. mas used illstead of -A. is, taking p as the negative of the correction to the constant of aberration. I n this way an equation of condition \!-as formed for each one of the individual results for the latitude, maliing, as tabulated abovo, an aggregate of 2 370 equations, containing four unknown quantities and kuown terms. The method of dividing these equations into blocks for short intervals is shown by the following table, where all the observations on the first pair of Group I are used and the partial sum is derived from the 0rst bloclr preparatory to forming the subnormal equations. This division into blocks was made to save tho labor of forming the products of the coefficients for each separate equation. A final result is obtained which is, with only insignificailt errors, the same as if each equation had been multiplied separately.

A similar summ:Lry was made for each pair, the blocks being c l ~ o s e ~ to i conveniently fit the total number of these dates of observation. The block interval rarely exceeded ten days. T l ~ e block equations is 534. From these tables the subnormals mere formed according to the following scheme: Compartment A contains tho "block equation^,^' the flrst of which has been previously given. I n B are found the mean equatious, correspondirig line for line with A, from which they were derived. Compartment C is deduced by multiplying the coefficient of x iri B by tho corresponding equatious in A. 111 I) we have the equations resulting from multiplyillg the coeficients of y i u B by tho corresponding equation in A, and E comes from a similar use of the coefficient of p in B.

REPORT F O R 1896-PART

11.

APPENDIX NO. 10.

357

It is evident that by multiplying the coefflcients of x in B by the coefflcients of z in A we get the coefficients of x in A, so that the first column of C is the same as the second column of A, and it is therefore not written in Compartment C . Likewise by multiplying the coefflcients of y in B by the coefflcients of a in A we get the coefficients of y iu A, i. e., the third column in A, so that the first column in D ia the same as the third coluxun of A; also the coefficients of y in B by those of x in A give the coefficients of y in C, i. e., the third column of 0 (first column of C is unwritten), so that the second column of D is the same as the third column of 0, and is not put down. Tho products of the coefflcients of y in B by those of y in A give the third column in D (first written one), and the coefflcients of p in B by those of p in A give the fourth column in D. E is formed in the same way, by multiplying the coefficients of p in B by the corresponding equations in A, i t only beiug necessary to begin writing down the products derived from the coefflcients of p in B by those of p in A. I n regard to the right-hand members of the equations in the several compartments, they are derived from the right-hand members of A .by tho same process; that is to say, the multiplicatiou of tho several coefflcients of B is extended to the known members of A to got the correspouding members of C, D, and E.

As only one or, a t most, two significant figures are required in the deduced value of p, the final normal equations formed by the abridged method would appear to give the necessary a,ccuracy. The equation between mean and apparent declination of a star, employing the notation given in the American ephemeris is : 6 - 8, = IP' + ACL' + Bb' UC' + Dd' = ~ p ' + y c o s ( G+ luo) + Wcos(H+ aO)sin 60+ ioos6, The constant of aberration enters only the last two terms of these, and the periodic effect of them on the star's place and on the deduced latitude are shown graphically in Plate 2. The quantities C and D are simply periodic functions, the 0rst depending on the cosine and the second on the sine of the sun's longitude. They therefore pass through their period during the year and have their mn,ximum values a t 18.76 and 20.45, respectively. c' and (Z1 being independent of the time and depending solely on the star's place mould have the effect of changing the curves for C and D by a certain fixed ratio which mould generally be less than nnity. I n the illustration we have the value of Cc' Dd' for each of the stars a and b of pa,ir 1 i11 Group I, shown graphicelly throughout the year by a light dotted line. The sum of thefie two effects appears as a heavy dotted line and the resulting effect on the latitude of the place of observation is indicated by a full heavy line. 0 and D are each represented by a light full line. APPENDIX NO. 10.

By using a mean value for A the platted curve will never be in error more than 0.01, which may be overlooked in the co~nparison of theory and observation. As the object of this paper is primarily to bring out tho constant of aberration and the variations of latitude simultaneously, it is not thought worth while to replat the original observations for comparison with our newly determined curve. The curve is simply displaced by a constant quantity which adapts it to the adjusted values in Bulletin No. 37. . The agreement is shown equally well whether we apply tho curve to the original observatious or whether the corrected curve is t~pplied to the adjusted observations. The value8 of the latitude therefore on a scale comparable with those of page 16 of 13iilletin No. 27 are as follows:

These values correspond to'the dotted curve in fig. 1. The small circles are the results from observations on the same scale, and the lower curve is the one derived in Bulletin No. 27 displaced vertically. It appears that Newcomb's method, in addition to a determination of the aberration constant, brings out simultaneously the periodic variations of the latitude, agreeing practically with the results from Albrecht's n~ethod. The period is slightly different in the two treatments.
I'ROllABLR IERROR OF OBt3Xl1VATIO~.

Without attempting to calculate the residuals from the 2 370 conditional equations, we can arrive a t n very close approximation to the probable error of observation by selecting rs few representative groups. The time from the beginning of July, 1801, to t.he beginning of June, 1892, is almost completely covered by the work in Groups 1 1 1 , 'CT, and VILI, so that the probable orror from these groups may fairly be taken as involving t h o ~ e conditions, such ns temperature, humidity, etc., which influence errors of observation. By substituting in all the cor~ditional equation8 for 1 1 1 ,V, and VIII, we may therefore get the probable errors of observation sufficiently accurate for our purpose. W e have-.

The definitive result of the constant of aberra.tion from the latitnde observations of 1891-92, made a t Waikiki, Hawaiian Islands, on the part of the United States Ooast and Geodetic Survey,. is therefore Constant of a,berration=201'.4331.0.034. This value of the aberration constant, combined with the lategt determillations of the velocity of light (V=186,330 miles) and Clarke's value for the earth%equatorial radius (R=3,963.30 miles), gives for the sun's distance and horizontal parallax the following results: Distance=92,709,000 miles. Parallax=8"-82.
SAN FRANCISCO OBSERVATIONS.

The refined methods employed during the last few years in studying the changes of latitude have incidentally thrown light ou one of the fundamental constants of astronomy. Continuous measures of small differences of zenith distances, carried on with a view of detecting 8 suspected motion of the pole, furnish material for the determination of the effect of aberration. The long series of observations made a t Waikiki, Hawaiian Islands, in 1891 and 1892, were discussed for this purpose, and now the still longer series made by Professor Davidson, a t San Francisco, have just been subjected to the same treatment. The methods, however, mere essentially different. Both are due to Professor Newcomb, and the work of computation has been done in the Coaet and Qeodetic Survey O5ce, partly by myself and partly by Mr. 0. C. Pates, under my supervision. I n the Waikiki observations a n attempt was made to determine simultaneously the variations of latitude and a correction to the constant of aberration. This involved the formation and solution of 2 370 conditional equations of the form
z + x cos N + Y sin N + A p = n~

The result fully justified the method. The latitntle curve agreed almost precisely with that found by an independent treatment according to the German method, and a very fair value mas deducted for the correctioii p. The details of this work are given in the former part of this paper and in Bulletin No. 28, United States Coast and Geodetic Survey. In the San Francisco observations it was desirable to shorten t l ~ labor e because here we have nearly 7 000 conditional equations. To apply the method of least squares for the purpose of determining four unknown quantities, to such a rnass of data, would require great labor. The periodic variations of latitude were therefore aacepted as already deduced by Mr. C. A. Schott, and the conditional equationu were formea containing only two unknown quantities, one of which was the correction to the aberration constant. .

When the preceding vnlues are compared with those resulting from observation the outstauding differences represent tho combined effect of two iudepeudeut quautities. Oils is tho corroctiou to reduce the mean decliuntion of ench pair of stars to the muau of all the pairs, sud the other a certain function of the quantity 20i1.4451,which is tho aberration constant and which appears a s

366

UNITED STATES COAST AND GEODETIC BURVEY.

a factor in two terms of the reduction from the mean to the apparent place of the stars. The tabular values arc considered applicable for two days on each side of the date given. Each directly observed latitude mill therefore furnish an equation of the form

mhere C i s the correction to the mean declination of the pair, K is the sum of h cos (H a)sin B for both stars, x is lninr~sone-half the factor by which the a,bermtion constant nsed in the rednctions must be niultiplied in order to get the correction to this constant, arid A 9 is the difference between the observed value of the latitude and the mean latitude plus its periodic variation. Each pair will then give conditional equations of the form

+

C+Xx=A, g, C+ R X = A ~ p C+Kx=C3 g, etc., etc., mhere each equation corresponds to a separate observation. If there are n observations the normal equations for this pair mill be

[IL] C + [KK] x=[IZdq]
from which by eliminating C

91.

c + [K]x=[dy]

This is the direct method. In practice, I~omevor,as Professor Kemcomb suggested, each X was multiplied by .O4, so as to make the general mean somewhat less than unity, which procednre gave a value of x 25 times greater than its true value. Theyalue found from the normal equation is therefore to be divided by 25. In the solution by tho above scheme the declination correction disappears, and w e have finally G 768 equations containing only x and known terms. A mean equation gives the value sought. The interpretation of the result is easily made by considering the form of the conditional equations and the relation between the coefficient of x and the aberration consta~it. The quantity 2011.4451 enters as a factor into the expression 1~cos (&+n ) sin 6 + i cos 6, or in Bessel's lota at ion into Ccl+Ddl. This expression is added to tho declination of each star in finding its apparent place, and the latitnde comes from summing the declinations and dividing by two. Hence any change in the above factor affects the deduced latitude by only half as much, and since d q is ~ equal to cp-qo, or to the observed latitude minus the ~nean latitude corrected for periodic variation, the effect on dcp is equal to its effect on y and is of the same sign. Moreover, the sign of x nlust be opposite to the sign of the correction to 201'.4451, since the term +ILx represents the excess of the dq deduced with this value over that which mould come from using the new value. In general if the value of x as used in the equations comes out + a, the correction to be applied to the constant of aberration is - 1.64n, or the value of the aberration constant given by the observations is

These values weighted with the coefficients of x above give the smne value, viz: C o n s t a ~ of ~ t aberration = 201'.482.
PRORAI1LE ERROR.

The probable error of this result is estimated in the following may: The values of C, the corrections to the a~sumed declinations, were calculated for each pair through two represent;ttive gronps. These val~iesaxid the values of x substituted in all the conditional equations of the groups chosen gave residuals from which the meau error'of observation was calculated. T l ~ e number of equations being represented by 7 n and the number of unknown quantities deterrninecl being equal to JA, the mean error of observation is

l n the preseiit case the average value of e from the tn-o groul)s involying 51 pairs and 2 013 observations was 0.389. The normal equations were then solved for each pair in order to get the weight of the unknown quantity x. These normal equations were
n 0 + [K] x=O [XIC+ [XR] x=l

from which x is equal to the reciprocal of the quantity

This last written value ia therefore the weight of x or dpy and the mean error of x from each pair mould be found by dividing the mean error of observation by dE An average value for the 51 pairs of the mean error of x from 1 pair gave (0.395). The probable error is therefore 0.6745~ (0.395)=Oe2G6. The value of x as derived from the conditiona.1 equation lnust be multiplied by 1.64 in order to get the correction to the aberration constant. Hence the probable error and the probable orror of the of this correction from one pair of stars may be taken as (-436) result depending on 176 pairs mould be

This is on the assumption that the average mean error for 51 pair8 is the same as the average for 176 pairs, a'supposition which seems to be justified, within reasonable limits, by the range of tlle values calculated. The constant of aberration from the San Francisco observations may then be given as

This value used in connection with the velocity of light and the earth's radius given in the first part of the ya,per reduces the solar parallax to 8'/.797 and iucreases the sun's distance to 92 931 000 miles; so that we would have, giving equal weights to the Hollolulu and San Prallcisco observations, the following values from all the observations of the Coast and Geodetic Survey:

Newcomb's value, 30"-463, is the niea,n of 24 miscellaneous results from different observatories. The sun's distance ir, derived from this a,nd from the velocity of light, 299 SGO km., and the earth's radius, 6 378.2 km., given on page 147. The difference between the extreme values for the sun's diskmce is much less than the probable error mcribed by Professor Harkness to his result (p. 140), and the Coast and Geodetic Survey value differs from the mean of all three by about 1 per cent of this probable error. We may repeat, in conclusion, that the observations which furnish the data discussed in the preceding pages were made with an entirely different object in view. The deduction of the constant of aberration was an afterthought, and mas not undertaken until the observations had fully subserved the purpose for which they were originally and specifically made. That they ahould furnish such plausible values is a matter of satisfact,ion without, however, a.ttributing undue importance to the close accord with standard work.in this direction. Nevertheless, a new and independent determination of this quantity can not fail to be of value when we remember that one of the most accurate means of finding the sun's distance is by use of the aberration constant, which has been the subject of this paper.

0 1 1 tile easteru shore of Chathaul Strait the lnoulitains are not so abrupt or rugged as on the wester11 side. The tops :ire nearly ;ill ronudcd and bare, wit11 the oxceptiou of gi.:iss and light underbrush. Owiiig to the l>revalenceof S I I O W slides, 110 gelieral rule cau be givon for tho heigllt of tho t,iniber line. The rest of tlio couiitry is covered with n lieavy growth of cedar, fir, sl)ruce, mal,le, alder, ancl blueberry bushes, greatly impeding travel. Tho highest peak on tlio easterll shore is botweeu Cha-ilc and Wliitowater bays, :2 241 feet, and is an irregular, solitary mount;bin 1 1 the southern sllore of Wllitewater Bay, and malcilig prominent with two principal peaks. 0 landmarlr for it, is a nlountain, 9 438 feet high, called Tablo Mount:~in, peculiarly eroded near tllo top. This is the orily ~ r o m i ~ l e peak n t between Whitewater Bsy and Poiut Gardner, the country beilig composed of low, rolliug hills, hewily timbered, laclril~gintliviclunlity, and coritaining no promiuent fee. .L t ures. 011 the western shore, wit11 tlie exception of the couutry betnveen Poiut Thatcher and Poirlt Lull, t,he country is l~iuch more rugged aiid broken, many of the pealrs reaching altitudes of 4 000 feet, ;and appaltently ir~creasi~ig in height to tho southward. Theso peaks are noiwly all bare anti rocky and covered with snow until late in the sumlnor, sonie of them perpetually. A few r e n ~ u a ~ l t s of glaciers can bo seen in some of tlie upper gnlches. The tirnber line propor is much lower here than on tho onster~i siclo, and above it tlre uilderbrusll is also much lighter. Tliis is duo probably to tho later nielting of the s~iolv and the greater frequency of suom slides. Chatlia~~i Strait, the main, ie n clear, lloriest sheet of water, most of tho dangers to rlnvigation lying well inshore, nnd generally iusido of a line drawn fro111 point to point. On tho western shore from abreast Point Garci~~er to tlie southorn point of Kelp Bay there are no outlying and the roefs in the small bights aro nearly a11 visible at half tide. About two-thirds dangers, of a mile SE. g S. from Point Lull is a sunken rock, moll marked by kelp, ancl from here to Point

373

Tliatcher the shore should not be ap1)roached within half a mile, as there are several reefs extending well offshore, and the bottom is very irregular and foul. Although well marked by kelp, there may be some shoals undiscovered. Much of this kelp is attached to small rocks and bowlders, varying in size from a hen's egg to a brick, and under the in5uence of heavy seas or strong tidal currents a vessel is very liable to drag anchor. 0 1 1 the western shore are three prominent waterfalls which make excellent landmarks. The first is 4 miles below the southern point of Help Bay, very high, and visible for a considerable distance to the northward, appearing as a white line or streak against the dark background of the hills. The second is a large but not particularly high waterfall a t the head of Warm Spring Bay, which is visible from Chatham Strait for a short distance to the southward of the bay. The third is similar to the last in appearance, iu an open bight which has received the local name of Cascade Bay. This waterfall is visible from vessels bound north in mid-channel up to a point onehalf mile to the northward of a line drawn fro111 l'oint Gardner a t right angles to the general direction of the chaunel. From Point Gardner to Point Wilson, the southern point of Wilson Cove, tlie shore is low, except in one place noted on the chart, with no reefs or dangers making off to any extent. Wilson Cove, 8 miles above Point Gardner, is an open, shallow biglit, about 1lnile dcep, with rt width a t its entrance of 2 niilcs. A t its head is an extensive flat. On its southern shore are two small wooded islands, the inner one being much higher and more heavily wooded of the two. I n the entrance is an extensive reef, generally visible, but covered a t the spring high waters, extending across the mouth for a distance of half a mile. The southern shore is very foul and rocky, and full of kelp, much of i t being secured to small rocks and bo~vlders. On the northern shore are several caverns in the faces of the cliffs, which are from 75 to 100 feet in height. Wilson Cove should be avoided, as it affords no protection as an anchorage exccpt from enaterly winds, and is very foul, bottom showing in 4 or 5 fathoms in many places. Point Caution, 14 rniles above Point Gardner, and 5 miles above Wiluon Cove, is the southern point of Whitewater Bay. Two and one-half miles sout,li of i t a shoal extolids offshore one-third of a ]nil0 from a small wooded islet counected with the shore a t low water. Otherwise the shore is free from dangers between Point Caution and Wilson Cove. Directly behind I'oillt Caution is the mountain previously referred to as marking the entrance to TITlliten?ater Bay. One-sixth of n niile NW. fro111 Point Cantion is a low, rocky islet, bcariug a single dead tree, from which it derives the name of Lone Tree Island. One and three-quarter miles N. 4 W. from Point Caution is Woody Point, with a small rocky, wooded islet, one-third of a mile offshore. This is the northern point of Whitewater Bay. Whitewater Bay extends ill an easterly direction for a distance of 3 miles, terminating a t its head in sand and gravel flats, and a t high miter connecting by a narrow passage with a lagoon about 1mile in length by one.1ialf mile in width, bare a t low mator. One and one-quarter ~lliles from Point Caution, nearly in the n~iddle, but a little nearer the southern shore, is Ilealy Itock, low and bare, surrounded by rocky ledges of small extent, rnarked 1)y kelp. On the northern shore, 1mile BE. from Woody Point, is the Indian village of Neltushkin, ant1 from tlie point iminediately to the westward of the village a rocky ledge extends one-half mile in a SW. by W. direction, with a su~llten rock ono-quarter of a mile to the eastward of its seaward end, both well marked by kelp. I n other particulars the description of this bay as given hi the Pacific Coast Pilot, Alaska, P a r t I, is very good. From the rocky islet off' Woody Point, distant seven-eighths of a mile XW. by N., is liussian Reef. Tho position of this reef on the published charts is erroneous, as it has been placed much too far from shore, while in reality i t is uearly on range between l'oint Cautioii and Distant Point. This reef extends three-quarters of a mile in a general W 8 W . direction, sllowing partially is well marked by kelp. These rocks rise very abruptly from very deep water. a t low water, ar~d From MToodyI'oint 24 miles NE. 8 E. is Rocky I'oint, the shore between being co~lsiderably indented by small open bights, with ledges extending well offshore a t low water. There are also two small islands in this stretch, one close inshore, 1mile 8.4E. from Itocky Point, and the other one-half mile S. E. from Itocky l'oint. straight. From Point Caution, in Chatham Strait, a line down through the portage in the northern arm passes nearly through Broad Island, in Peril St,rait, and the head of Hooniah Sound, a clear line 55 miles in length. Immediately to the westward of Point Lull is a narrow bight extending in a northwesterly direction for three-quarters of a mile. This is full of kelp, open to the southmarcl, and affords temporary shelter for small craft only. Between Pond Island and the south shore is a narrow passage full of rocks and kelp. This is navigable by small boats, but should not be attempted by large vessels. One and one-half miles to the southward of Soutli Point a narrow inlet extends for 14 miles to tlie westward. A small, rocky, wooded islet lies close to its northern point, connecting a t low tide. Two hundred yards southeast is a bare rock with a ledge extending 150 yards to the southward. The eritraltce to the bight is from tho southward, and i t affords good sllelter for small vessels, but is too narrow to give swinging rooin for vessels of any size. For n distance of n niile below this bight the shore is straight, but from there to Ta-Kctz Bay, a distanco of 4 miles, the shore is much brolren by bights, with several wooded islands and baro rocks lying close to shore. Tlio cliffs are very precil)itous, and several large waterfalls were noticed, orie of which is very prominent and has been referred to as one of the landmarks in this vicinity. Ta-Katx Bay exteuils in a westerly direction, curving slightly to the southward for 2 miles, and then tarns abruptly to the nortliward for another mile, terminating in a flat formed by a niountain streani elnptying into it as a waterfall. The otlter two rocks are GOO yards to the \vest\vard. Between this bay and a point opposite Point Gard~ier aro two ope11 bights, both unsuited for anchorages. The southern one is called Cascntle Bay, from the very prornrnerit waterfall at; its head. The hand lead is of little use to navigators in these waters in tllick weather, 30 aud 30 fathoms beirig frequently fouud within :I fern yards of the sliore line, while a quarter of a mile from the beach deptlis of 100 to 200 fathoms nre not nt all uausual.

378

UNITED .STATES COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY.

One almost universal feature which exists in these waters is the occurrence of sand and gravel flats, with one or more small streams a t the head of all bights and inlets. The slope, from 8 to 10 fathoms to a few feet, is very abrupt, and in approaching the head of an inlet a t high water care should be exercised in anchoring Go give t&e flats sufficient berth to avoid grounding at low water. Nearly aII G o r d good holding ground, in soft or sticky bottom, within :I short distance of the head.
HOOTZNAHOO INLET.

Hootznahoo Inlet, comprisiug an area of about 15 square miles, is a group of lagoous and bays on the eastern shore of Chatham Strait, 22 miles above Killisnoo. It consists of five principal divisions, full of rocks, reefs, and shoals, connected by narrow channels through which the tide flows with great force, attaining a t times rt velocity of from 10 to 12 knots per hour. The entrance to these lagoons is between Danger Point and Hootznahoo Head, and from the entrance the Inlet extends in a general easterly direction for 3&miles, where it opens out into a small bay, called "Favorite Bay" by the Alaska Oil and Guano Uomp~any, who use i t wnsiderably as a fishing ground for herring. One and one-half miles from the entrance, on the north shore, and extendirig to the northward, are two arms, the western one being almost straight, mith the exception of a smnll bight on its westeru shore, and counecting with Mitchell Bay. The eastern arm joins tho western a t Point Pillsbury, above the end of Long Island, which lies between tho arms. On the eastern shore of this arm is a small passage opening into a lagoon that a t high water wnnects by zl passage a t its southeast end with Favorite Bay. A t its northern end i t co~iuectsby a uarrow passage with a lagoon opening illto Mitchell Bay. Mitchell Bay, the largest of the divisions of this inlet, is about 49 miles in length by an average width of 14 miles. A t its southwest end i t is connected with a lagoon so full of rocks, reefs, and shallow water that soundings were considered unnecessary. A t its southeast end i t is connected by Davis Creek to Kanalkoo Bay and Lighter Creek. At its northeril elld i t is connected by a lagoon, impassable except a t high water by small boats, which is aaid to conuect with a series of lakes in the interior of Admiralty Island. It is impossible to give more than a general description of this mixed-up mass of islands, rocks, and water, as a much better idea can be obtained from tlie charts. The general character of the cou~itry is low and rather heavily wooded, except where otherwise noted, and the absence of prominent features renders it impossible to give rangee that would ' be of much service to the navigator. The name8 have boon taken from the description of this place written by Captain Meade, U. S. N., who navigated these chanuels in 1869 in the U. S. 5 . Saginaze, and his description is apparently very full and complete. A t the present time there seems to be little to induce a vessel to enter these waters. The indications of coal, or, more properly, lignite, are numerous, but tho mines have not been worked for a number of years, and ally subserluelit development of then1 vould not depend upon these waters as n mealis of disposing of their output, since a short railway syetem of a fenr miles would lead directly to Chatham Strait abreast of Killisnoo.
SAILING DIRECITIOXS FOE HOOTZNAEOO INLET.

On the north side of Danger Point is the narrow ontrance, to an extensive system of illlets and lagoolls, called by the Indians l LI30otznahoo.~' The entrance is about one-half of a mile wide, gradually narrowing, but free from obstructions, until Village ltock is reached. This is s large low-water ledge making out from an Irldiali village on tho south shore toward Turn Point on the north shore. This ledge obstructs more than one-half the channel, and the strength of the tide causes a very stro~ig current, sunr ring a t times probably as high as 8 knots, mith large swirls where the curreqt impinges upon the larger and slower moving body of water. Beyond Village ltock, to the eastward, the channel is clear on the south side well in toward the shore line, but on the north side i t ie obstructed by a ledge marked by kelp a t slack water making out from Turn Point, terminating in a large round-top rock, which covers a t high water and upon which a spindle has been placed by the Alaska Oil and Guano Company.

One-quarter of a mile beyond this rock begins a series of rocks, uncovered a t low water, extending to the unbroken shore line on the south side of the channel leading into Favorite Bay, in a line with this shore, the spindle, and Turn Point. A t tho spindle rock the chtmnel branches which has been in three directions. One branch continues to the eastw:trd past Sullivans~Poiut, prospected for coal, and leads into Favorite Bay, a large lagoon filled with herring during the season. The other two go to the northward and eastward on eithur side of a largo wooded island. The eastern of these passages is obstructed a t the south end except for small boats, and a t the north end of tho island divides, one branch reuniting a t Poiut l'illsbury with the main passage leading into M i ~ l i c l Bay, l the other going through a very narrow channel illto a largo lagoon full of rocks and reefs, and unnavigable except for small craft. This lagoon is conuected a t its southeast corner by a high-water passage with Favorite Bay, and on its northeast side past a series of islands and broken reefs with Mitcholl Bay. From the spindle on Rose Iioclr the mesternlnost branch turns sharply to the westward along the reef making out from Turn Point, thence to the northward and eastward for 5 miles, when it opens into Mitchell Bay. One and one-quartor miles above Tnrn Point this channel runs between a ledgo of rock making off to the southward from l'oint Pillsbury and a round, bluff, high-water island; thence for one-half mile between reefs to Point Bridge, where it ruus between a reef on the west side and a bold bank on tho east side into a narrow channel with steep bold shores on either hand. Three-quarters of a milo above Point Bridge the channel broadens to a width of oue-quarter mile until near the elltrance to Mitchell Bay, when i t is again confined between tt ledge making off to the southward from North Point and a system of high-water islands to the eastward. Beyond North Poiut is Mitchell Bay, which extends to the northmard and eastward a distance of 4d miles, with a width of 1s miles a t its south side to narrow channels a t tho north, and leading over rapids into n system of lagoons fed by a large &ream, said to have its sourco in lakes near the middle of the island. A t the southeast angle of this bay is a narrow passage called Davis Creek, which, back upon itself a ~ ~ d after running in a southeast direction through a very foul channel, t u r ~ l s widens into a clear open basin, called Kanalkoo Bay, a t the head of which are two large streams. One-half mile from the north end of Davis Oreek, Lighter Creel; makes off, having from 2g fathoms to ti fathoms of mater a t high tide. The south shore of Mitchell Bay is very foul, and while there is an ebb and flow of tide from Hootznahoo Head to Mitchell Bay, to tho eastward of the main passage there is no channel for any sort of craft larger than rowboats and canoes. Near the west side of Mitchell Bay aud 14 miles from the entrance to Diamond Island is a long narrow island, sparsely woodod, with a large timber fall. To the eastward of this island, and in a line parallel with the south shore of the bay, are tnro islands, one, a small, round, high-wator island, without timber, the other larger and covered with a dense growth of timber. To tho northward of these islands there is e larger island with a confined channel to the west of it. A t the entrance to Davis Creek is e high-water island, called by Captain M e t e "Passage Islet." A large stream empties into Davis Creek a t its uorth end, near which, in Rlitcholl Bay, a good anchorage may be had in from 10 to 20 fathoms of water. The tides in this system of lagoons continuo to run from one hour to one aud one-half hours head, or oven longer. Slacli mater mill be found st Village ltock, after tho change a t llootz~~ahoo in the narrows, a t Points l'illsbury and Bridge, a t North Point, and a t tho south entrance to tho middle lagoou, from ono hour to one and one-half hours after the change of tide at Hootznahoo Head. Slack meter a t the north oud of Davis Oreek occurs half ttn hour after high or low water in Mitchell Bay. TresseIs rounding Rose ltock a t slack water would carry slack water all the way to Mitchell t s froit1 5 to 8 knots; a t Point Bridge as high as 10 knots, Bay. A t Village Rock the c u r r o ~ ~run and a t Passage Islet as high a8 7 knots. Coal has been found in small quantities about the entrance to Davis and Lighter creeks, a t the southeast corner of Hanalkoo Bay, and in the middle lagoou. Several abaudoned tunuels &d shafts appear about Davis and Lighter creeks.
