UNITED STATES COABT AND GEODETIC SURVEY.
PERIL STRAIT.

Peril Strait is one of the most important waterways in southeastern Alaska, rivaling Wrangell Narrows in the amount of its commerce, and is the only connection between the inland channels and Sitka. It is used by small sloops and schooners, by small steamers employed in the interest of various canneries, sawmills, and mines, by the regular mail steamers throughout the year, and during this last season by two steamers running in oppositiou to the Pacific Coast Steamship aompauy from Puget Sound to thcse waters. An excellent reconnaissance of the narrows from Suloia Bay to Pogibsl~i Point, including also the steamer traclc from that point to Broad Island, was rnade by the omceru of the U. S. S. Adants, under Commander J. B. Ooglau, United States Navy, in 1884, aud but few changes mere found by the present survey. Tlio north shore of Peril Strait from Point Craven to the head of t l ~ e northern arm of Ilooniah Sound is steep and bold, and after passing Lindenberg ITead is 1)ractically a straight line, mith no dangers except an occasional lint of small cntent making off the mouth of a streani. Tlio shore can bo approached with safety to within a quarter of a niile. The uloiintains are covered with a moderate growth of timber and underbrush, their tops being generally bare alld rocky except where noted on the sheet. McClellan Rock, marked by n spindle immediately 08Lindenberg Head and a snnlren rock off a small open bight 2 miles to tho eastward of Linile~lberg 11c:~d,are the only tlangers from this point to Point Craven. The principal landmarks in Peril Strait are Ii'airway Island, in the eastern entrance; Lindenberg Head; the point a t which. Peril Strait changes direction; a series of bare, rocky hills and cliffs 28 miles above Lindenberg Ilead, and Broad Island, lyi~ig three-qua1ters of a mile ORthe northern shore a t the western eud of tlie strait. Several landslides mrill be referred to later. The soutlierrl shore of Peril Strait is mucli illdented by small bights, coves, and inlets, and although the mountains back of tho slloro line are in Inany instances higher than those of the northern side, the slopes are generally less abrupt. Point Craven is the western point of a narrow inlet known as Sitkol~ Bay, about G& miles in length, that extends in a general ~riortherly direction. The point consists of an outlyil~g rock about 10 feet in height, with a larger and higher rock nearly llalfmay betmecn it and the shore, con~~ected by ledges sliowing a t low water. A small steep bluff is on the rounded point of the shore behind the rocks. Deep water can bo carried close up to theso rocks. The eastern point of Sitkoh Bay is Point Hayes, distant from Point Craven l;f miles 9. by E. 3 E., and bearing SSE. 3 E., distant 14 miles, from Peninsular Point, in Chatham Strait. This portion of the ~ h o r e is extremely foul and dangerous, the bottom is irregular, and kelp is particularly thick. From Point Hayes, extending toward Point Craven across tho mouth of Sitkoh Bay for a distance of half a mile, are numerous reefs and ledges, some of \vhicli arc visible a t low water only. Two small islands and a rock lie a short distanco off tho point. A first-class can buoy, painted black, is moored 18 miles NE. by E. & E. from Point Craven and 33 miles N. by W. 4 W. fro111Point Thatcher. Between this and Point Hayes is very foul and dangerous ground, and no vessel should attempt to pass to the northward of the buoy under any circumstances. On lino between the buoy and Peninsular Point is an extensive reef, usually woll marked by kelp, which shows partially a t low water and runs iu a generally northern direction. A line froin the outer rock of Point Craven draw11through tho small bare rock off Point Hayes passes nearly through the centre of this ledge. To avoid this ledge, in entering Ohatham Strait from Peril Strait, mith tho buoy close aboard, a KE. 4 E. course should be held until the prominent white rock to tho north\vard of Peninsular Point is well open before hauling to the northwal-d. Sitkoh Bay for the first 2 miles is about 1 mile in width, though the channel a t the erltranco is constricted to half that distanco by tho ledges and reefs making off to the westward from Point Hayes. Two miles above Point Hayes, from tlio eastern shore, projects a low, hoavily wooded point, which forms a bight, affording an anchorago in 20 fathoms, hard bottom, and excellent protection from the northerly gales, which are the severe winter winde. Behind the point is a small lagoon, bare a t low water. Extending to the southward from the point is a reef about 200 yards in length, visible a t low water. By favoring the Point Craven shore for a distance of a mile, and then heading for the middle of the bight, all danger will

be avoided. Beyond this point the bay is but one-third of a mile wide for a distance of 46 miles, the last mile of which is bare a t low tide. Seven-eighths of a mile above the point a reef extends into the channel for a distance of 300 yards from the eastern shore, with a small sand flat, and an Indian house on the western shore a little farther in. A mid-channel course clears both the reef and the flat, and should be held for 12 miles farther, when the eastern shore should be favored to avoid ail extensive flat making out from the western shore. This flat is well marked by a ion. mound 100 yards off the western shore, covered by stunted trees and bushes. A sinall stream of this mound. The anchorage is one-half mile beyond this mound, empties just to the nortl~ward in 15 fathoms, soft bottom. A small cove, with low sandy shores, 39 miles NE. 8 E. from Point Craven, does not afford good anchorage, and this fact, coupled with the sunken rock off its entrance, recommeuds that i t be not used. Lindenberg Harbor, 66 miles SW. 9 W. from Point Oraven, is formed by the projection of a point with a knoll 250 feet in height, on which is an extensive windfall. The harbor is protected from the northward and eastward, but is rather small, with indifferent holding ground. It has been used considerably in northerly weather by the regular steamers, but apparently on account of lack of informatioli regarding Sitkoh Bay. McOlellan Rock, marked by a spindle, is 360 yards off the point toward mid-channel. This rock bares for considerable area a t low water. There is a narrow passage between i t and the point, with from 5 to 7 fathoms, but nothing is gained by its use. These constitute tho only anchorages on the northern shore of Peril Strait. Point Thatcher, the southern entrance point to Peril Strait, is a low, heavily wooded point, terminating in three bare rocks, the inboard one connected with the shore. These rocks extend toward Point Craven, and a rock, baro s t low water, surrounded by kelp, lies 100 yards N.& E. from the outer one. The Colemai~Reef, described in the sailing directions as extending 1 mile northeast from Point Thatcher, with a width of one.quarter of a mile, apparently has no existence. One and one-third miles west from Point Thatcher are Traders Islands, connected a t low water, low and heavily wooded. One and one-half miles NW. W. from Point Thatcher is Midway Reef, visible except a t high water, and extending 760 yards in a general northwesterly direction. Fairway Island, the prolninent landmark for leaving or entering Peril Strait, lies 2 miles WNMT.6 W. from I'oint Thatcher and l a miles SSE. from Point Craven. It is abont 380 feet high, mucll rounded, $ud covered with a thick growtli of trees. From Point Thatcher to the eastern point of Hanus Bay the shore must be avoided by all large vessels. The bottonl is very irregular, aud there are r~umerousrocks and reefs, some of low water, while the suhkeli rocks aro but poorly indicated by kolp. which show only a t ~ x t r e m e Three-quarters of a mile SJV. by W. & IT. froin Fairway Island is a sunkeu rock marked by kelp. Two and one-half miles SW. IV. of Fairway Islalid and one-lialf wile WSW. a W. from a small rocky islot with but few trees on it, lies a su~iken rock nearly one-half mile off the souther11 shore. This is a pinnacle rock, and but 0110 or two pieces of kelp marked its locatioll a t tho time of its discovery. Small craft with local lrnowledge may find teinporary shelter closo inshore, but no anchoragcs are rocommonded. A course midmay betweeu Point Crave11and Fairway Island laid to pass the spindle off Lindenberg Head five-eighths of a mile to the southward clears all daugers, aud requires but one change for continuing up Peril Strait to Broad Island. At its western end are two coves, the southern one nearly bare a t low water, illto which e~uptics a small stream, tlie oi~tlet of a small, narrow lake. This is quito a fishing station of t l ~ e Iudiaus during the sumnler mouths, when largo quantities of salmoll aiid trout are prepared and dried for tho winter su1q)l.yof food. Tmo ledges, bare a t low tide, lie off tho points of tliese coves n t a distarlce of about 80 yards, the outer olio lying a little inslde of tlie outer point. 111 tho southeastern corlier of Hallus Bay are two low, wootleti islands, co~il~ected a t lo\v water with roefs mid sand flats oste~idiag ofl tlleir western elid for about 200 yards. fart.her to the westward on the southern shore is a small bay, known by the Indians as Sa-ook, 3 miles in length by about one-half mile in width, that affords the best anchorage between Fairway and Broad islands, especially in southeasterly weather. Its right entrance is markecl by'a point on which is a conspicuous windfa.11, ancl off this point, in Peril Strait, is a rock about 80 yards from shore 4 feet out of water a t high tide. The left entrance is low and wooded. On the eastern shore of the inlet, three-quarters of a mile from the entrance, is a low, wooded island with a small reef on the channel side, distant, 20 yards and generally visible. This is the firut of a small group of islands and roclrs which extend from i t to a low, green, grassy knoll tliree eighths of a mile into g an beyond. On the west side, 14 miles from the entrance, is a prominent ravine o p e ~ ~ i n amphitheater in the surrounding hills. From i t comes e small stream that makes a very extensive be expected, and extends sand and gravel bar. This bar is much larger than would ordii~arily fully halfway across tho inlet. Beyond i t there are no obstructions until the fla.h a t the head are reached, 1mile beyond tlie ravine. A good-sized stream, poted for large numbers of trout, empties a t the head. The anchorage is ilve-eighths of a mile beyond the bar, in the middle of the inlet, in 18 to 22 fathoms, soft green mud. Excellent water can be obtained from any of the numerous small streams that come in on each side'of the anchorage, preferably a t high wa,ter, when a better approach to them can be had. Peril Strait is entirely hidden from the anchorage. Four and one-half miles farther, on the south shore, is the entrance to an inlet, Rodman Bay, which extends to the southward for 6 miles. Its western point is high and well wooded, with reefs extending offshore for about 100 yards. The eastern point is low, and between it and a small cove on the eastern shore are several rocks, bare a t low water, but not generally visible. This inlet is 65 miles from Broad Island and 8 miles from Lindenberg Head. A t the entrance i t is about 2 miles wide, but contracts in 13 miles to five-eighths of a mile, a small wooded isla.nd lying off the eastern side, where i t narrows. The soundings in the entrance are very irregular, and although no dangers were found care should be taken in entering. On the eastern shore, close to the entrance, is a small cove with an island in the middle of the entrance connected with the southern point by a sand spit covered a t high water. The channel for entering is on the north side of the island. The cove has rocks and shoals, and affords an anchorage to small craft only. A stream empties a t its head with very extreme flats. On the western shore of the inlet, 2 miles from the entrance, s shoal e x t ~ n d offshore s for about 125 yards, but otherwise the channel is clear to the head, where extensive sand and gravel flats make off from the southwest corner. On the eastern side, near the head, are two islands, connected a t low water, and just beyond them, with a point on the eastern shore showing between, a good anchorage may be had in 10 to 12 fathoms, soft bottom. A large stream coming from the east.ward through a narrow valley empties in this corner of the head with extensive sand and gravel flats. Two miles west of Roclman Bay is Pestchani Point, low and wooded, on the eastern side of which a mountain stream empties, forming a very large sand and gravel bar. This flat extends into the channel for over a quarter of a mile, from one-half of a mile to the westward of the point to below the mouth of the stream. A close approach to the point should be avoided. Threequarters of a mile west of Pestchani Point is Nismeni Point, low, covered with a thin growth of trees, bare and rocky a t its seaboard end. Off this point are two ledges, bsre a t low water only, with a sunken rock halfway between them and the point. The first is distant 600 yards NE. E. and the second is distant 800 yards NE. 4 E. from the point. To the eastward of the point is Nismeni Oove, about three-quarters of a mile in depth by less tha.n one-half of a mile a t its entrance. This gives shelter from southerly winds, the holding ground in the middle of the cove being fair in 18 to 22 fathoms. The course for entering lies toward the eastern point to avoid the ledges off Nismeni Point. This bight affords no shelter from northerly winds. Beyond Nismeni Point and Broad Island, Peril Strait opens out into a considerably wider body of water, extending 7 miles to the southward to Point Pogibshi, the northern entrance to the narrows, and on its western side opening into three bays, the two northern ones being.the most extensive and constituting Hooniah Sound. To the southward about 34 miles, on the western shore, the third bay extends in a curve to the southward for 4 miles. Poison Cove, near Point Pogibshi, is the ouly other indentation on this shore. From Nismeni Point to Point Pogibshi the shore bends in a gentle curve to the southward,

the low-water line extending some considerable distance offshore. Several anchorages may be had along this shore, the best being noar Point Pogibshi off the entrance of a small lagoon in a small grassy flat, in 32 fathoms, sandy bottom. A close approach to the shore should be avoided in anchoring, as an extensive sand and gnwel bar makes out well into the bight. One mile SW. by W. & W. from Xismeni Point is Otstoia Island, low and thickly wooded, and connected a t low water with two bare rocks lying off its southwestern end. A sand and gravel bar, formed by mountain streams, makes off from the shore toward Otstoia Island, constricting the channel to a width of one-eighth of a mile. The outer point of the flat is marked by a secondclass red can buoy, anchored in 8 fathoms. A clear channel, carrying 4 to 10 fathoms, generally used by tho steamers, lies between the buoy and Otstoia Island. and a straight course from the buoy to Poverotni Island clears all dangers. Three-quarters of a mile W. # S. from Nismeni Point is the seaward end of Cozian Reef, a sunken ledge extending off Otstoia Island for nearly one-half rniie. Its outer end is marked by a second-class call buoy, painted black. One-half mile SW. by W. 3 W. from Nismeni Point, and lying 150 yards offshore, is a sunken rock poorly marked by kelp. Five-eighths of a mile W. by S. from the southern end of Otstoia Island are Krugloi and Elevoi islands, conr~ecteda t low water. These islands are small, low, and wooded. Betwoen them and Otstoia Island is a clear channel with from 12 to 25 fathoms, which is apparently a better one than that between Otstoia Island and the shore, as i t avoids Uozian Reef and the sunken rock between i t and the shore. from Krngloi Island atid nearly 011 range betweeu i t and the northern One and one-half l~iiles point of Ushk Bay is a reef nearly 150 yards long, baring only a t spring low water. A little inshore, but nearly on range between Point Emmons and the north point of Poison Oove, is a reef of about the same extent as the last, distant 23 miles 9.4 E. fiom Point Emmolls and 24 miles SW. 6 W. from Rrugloi Island. It is seven-eighths of a mile NE. 2 N. from the southern point of the Ushk Bay, and bares a t low \rater only. One and one-half miles SW. $ S. of Krugloi Island and 24 miles N. from Poverotni Island is the center of a group of reefs, with shallow water between, covering an area of one-half mile square. The largest of these is about 300 yards long by from 60 to 100 yards in width, composecl of sand, gravel, and bowlders. This covers only a t the highest spri~ig tides. Four hundred yards to the southward of this are two low rocks, covered a t ordinary higb water. To the westward of the sandy island about one.quarter of a mile are three ledges, covering a t about half tide. The white sandy bottom between these ledges and extending off them for a distance varying from 50 to 150 yards is visible for a considerable distrtnce on a bright day. Between these reefs and Poverotni Island there are no dangers, the water varying from 30 to 50 fathoms in depth. Poisou Cove, abreast Poverotni Island, is a small open bight, with low gravelly beaches, and flats a t the head that uncover for a quarter of a mile a t low water. It is free from dangers and affords an anchorage for small craft in 18 fathoms, soft bottom. One and one-half miles to the northward is the entrance to Ushk Bay, which extends to the westward and southward for '4 miles, with an average width of three-quarters of a mile, narrowing to one-third a t the point whero i t changes direction. It aflords an anchorage a t the head in from 18 to 20 fathoms, soft bottom. A peculiar formittion of the hills is noticeable near the entrance on the southern shore, and a solitary round-topped hill, 1,800 feet high, with several landslides, marks its northern point and the southern entrance to Hooniah Sound. Five miles N. by W. 4 W. from Poverotni Island and 4 miles WSW. from Broad Island is Emmons Island, Point Emmons being it,s eastern extremity. This island was named in honor of Lieut. George Emmons, U.S. N., who has spent many years in these waters and furnished much valuable information in regard to them and the habits and customs of the Indians in this fiection of Alaska. The island is well wooded a8ndhas a small lake on its northern side. A ridge in the center, 600 feet high a t its eastern end, h w the appearance of a cone to vessel8 coming from Ohatham Strait. Off the western end of Emmons Island, distant one-half mile, is a group of small wooded islands, connected a t low water, from which a reef, bare a t half tide, extentls to the northward for nearly one-half mile. The passage between the south shore of Hooniah LJound and Emmons Island

should not be attemphd, as the water is shallow, arid long sand spits, visible a t low water, make \\-ell into the channel from the western end of Emmons Island and the small group of islands to the westward. Two and one-half miles WNW. from Ern~nons Island a large island, 5 miles in length, 14 miles wide a t its eastern end and 1mile wide a t its western end, divides Hooniah Sound into two arms. A sand spit, one-quarter mile in length, covered a t high water with a small, wooded, high-water island near its center, conuects the large island with the shore a t its western eud. On its southf f its eastern end a ledge nlakes off for 250 yards, and ott' western end is a prominent landslide. O its southeastern point is a ledge, distant 250 yards ESE., bare nt high tide. One mile to the westward from its eastern end, and one-third mile off the northern shore, is a small bare rock, some 8 feet out of water at high tide. The northern shore is low, with sand and gravel beaches, which extend oEshore 150 to 200 yards for a mile above the bare rock. The southern shore of the island is bold and steep. Five and one-half miles beyond Emmons Island the ~011th arm of Hooniah Sound is divided into a bay, 3 miles long, extending to the southward, and a smaller arm, 2 miles long, that connects with the northern arm a t high water. 'Chree and one-half miles above Emnlons Ksland is a srnall bight, with flats a t its head, bare a t low water. O f f its eastern point is a small, round, wooded island, connected with the shore a t low water, from which a reef extends to the eastward for 200 yards. The southern shore should not be approached too closely, as the low-water line extends well out. The bay extending to the southward is clear except for the westeru shore, which is shoal, with several sand and gravel bars. The arm a t the head connecting with the northern arm, in addition to extensive mud and sand flats, has a low grassy flat, covered here and there by small bushes, extending through on the left of a small wooded knoll to a similar flat 2&miles above the junction of the north and south arms. I n this small connecting arm, one half mile NNW. & W. from the wooded island, on the saud spit, and in mid-channel, is a rock, bare a t lorn water. This rock is about 2a miles above the southern point of the arm. The northern arm of Hooniah Sound is comparatively clear, until one-eighth of a mile to the southward of the small island on the northern shore, where, in mid-channel, is a rock, bare a t low water. This rook is not quite abreast of a prominent waterfall on the north shore. A t the head of the northern arm are two streams, both small, entoring from low valleys, one extending in the same general direction as Hooniah Sound and the other having a more southel-ly trend. A wooded islaud, with a reef extending one-quarter mile to the eastward, lies off the point of the ridge dividing the tn-o valleys and is connected a t low water with the shore by the flats a t the head.

If coming up the strait from the sea, keep a luid-channel course, about NW. by N. Hootz Bay.-Fronn off Distant Point follow the shore on the south side, keeping about half a mile away to clear the sunken rock until the mouth of the inner bay opens, when steer for i t about SE. by E. 4 E., favoring the southern shore to clear an island and some sunken rocks close to it, in the middle of tho narrowest part. Cascade 13ay.-Opposito Point Gardner, requires no special directions. Stand into the middle about WSW. until you can get bottom in about 25 fathoms, then anchor. Warm Spring Bay.-Open up the mouth of the bay, when stand in about SW. by W., midway between a white high-water rock ill its center arid tho south shore, which is bold. A small vessel c:m anchor in either of the two small bays ou the south side and lrave good protection from southerly winds. The western one is preferable because of slioaler water-12 to 15 fathoms. A large vessel must go near the cascade st tho head to get 25 fathoms and yet have swinging room. This latter is not rocommonded, as the bottom is rocky and the current usually sets out, caused by the flow of water down the cascade from the large mountain lake a t tho head, making a vessel lie broadside to the south wind, which sucks in and caroms on the steep mountain side north of the bay, sheering her about very uncomfortably. Ta-Katz Bay.-This is the best protoctecl ancliorage on this part of the coast, being entirely surrounded by high, rocky walls, but might bo dificult to entor with heavy southorIy sen. This clears the low-water rock 250 yards SE. from Point Turbot and the one insido of the promo~itorypoint m a r the north shore. When past the promontory point, favor the south shoro to clear u sunken rock and kelp patch near the middle, though i t can be left on oither side. Anchor near the middle of tlio bay in its widest part in 20 fathoms, soft, sandy bottom. Or, if desired, round the second point and anchor in 10 fathoms, with plenty of swinging room. 110 riot pass a whito lump of air isl:lnd around tho second bend, for there the sand flat begins. Tho south arm is not recommended. The water is deep, and the bottom is rocky and irregular, mith occasional kelp patches. SAILING DIRECTIONS THROUGH P E R I L STBAIT FROM POVEBOTNI ISLAND TO CHATHA31 STRAIT, COMING FROM T E E SOUTHIVARD.

The sailing directious from Sergius Narrowa to Poverotni Island as give11 ill the P.wific Coast Pilot, Alaska, P a r t I, are correct. Poverotr~iIsland may be passed to the northward a t a distance of about 200 yards. There is a passage between I'ogibsbi Point and Poverotni Island, but is not recommended. When i t bears abeam, steer for Otstoia Island, course NNE. The usual stealrier track is to the eastward of the island, but there is a good passage to the westward, between it and Rnigloi and Elevoi I ~ l a n d s . If passing it to the eastward, favor the island side, leaving the red buoy on starboard hand. After passing the black buoy on Cozian Bock, steer NE. E. for the easterly one of the two big hrrtdslides on rlortlleru shore until the northeast end of Broad Island bears W. by S.; then steer E. 2 S. until False Lindenberg Head is abeam; then E. by N. until JIcClella~l Rock is abeam, and thence into Chatham Strait the course is NE. by E. This course will carry across Chnthnm Strait south of I<enasnow Island, making allomanco for tides. If going to the westward of Otxtoia Ieland, after passing the islnud do not steer to the eastward of a line joining the western side of Otstoia Island and the easteru side of Broad Island until the buoy on Cozian Rock is passed. This clears Cozian Rock and Sho:~l.
ANCHORAGES BETWEEN POVEEOTNI ISLAND AND CHATHAM STRAIT.

Poison Cove is free from dangers and affords an anchorage for small craft ill 18 to 20 fathoms. No special directious are necessary for enteri~ig. Pogibsl~i Point.-On the north side, iu broad, shallow bight, about two-thirds the distance from the point to a small stream, there is a good anchorage in about 22 fathoms, soft sandy bottom. Favorite anchorage.-As described in Coast Pilot. Nismeni Cove.-Favor the eastern shore to avoid the ledges off Nismeni Point, slid anchor in the middle of the cove in 18 to 22 fathoms. Lindenberg Harbor.-As described in Coast Pilot.

TIDES AND OURRPNTS.

In the vicinity of Killisnoo the curreuts are very irregular, but the means show that the last half of the ebb aud the first part of the flood set in through Hootz Bay and set out to the westward through the north channel. The second half of the flood and the first ha.lf of the ebb set in to the osstward through the north channel and out into Hootz Bay. The set is parallel to the axis of the channel, and the strengtli is not important, except in tlie narrow part of the north entrance. The current a t the wharf is cven more erratic than that i11 the channel, but is not so strong; sometimes, however, an eddy will be found, but not strong enough to interfere materially with makiug a landing. A t Killisnoo the following data were obtained by observation:
Avorage time of high wator after moon'e meridian passage i s . .......................... Average time of low wator aftor moon's meridian poseago ie ............................ Mean rise and fall is ...................................................................
0112 4 " ' 6 ' 1 32n1 11.5 foet.

Hootzn~hoo Inlet.-The currents are strong and various all through this place, and the uninitiated should not attempt to navigate it, except a t slack water, aud had Letter choose low slack, so t h i t in case of grounding the benefit of a rising tide mill be obtained. The fiood current a t the entrance sets in nearly parallel to the north shore and so continues until i t reaches Village lEock, where i t divides, one part going to the northward over what Xeade calls "Hell's Acre," and tho other continuing to the eastward south of Rose Rock, where i t again divides. One part continues east into Favorite Bay, while tlie other turns short around the rock and divides again, one part going north, the otlier branch passing over Hell's Acre." The rapids begin a t Village Rock and continue until well past Rose Rock. The strongest current observed in the channel was 6.2 knots, but this is not tlie strongest. It probably reaches 8 knots a t times. It is slack a t about one hour mid thirty minnteu after high aud low water a t Killisnoo. The channel connecting Mitchell Bay with the lower part of the inlet commences nt I'oint

UNITED STATES COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY.

Pillsbury. From this point to Point Bridge the current is very swift, probably reaching 10 l i ~ o t s , with much boiling and swirlii~g, the worst place being a t Point Bridge. This can only be passed a t slack water, which lasts only a few minutes and occurs about one hour and fifty mi~iutesafter high and lorn water a t Killisnoo. Through all of the narrow channels leading into the various bays the currents run wit11 great velocity, a11t1 they should not be attempted in any kind of a boat except a t slack water. Sergius Xarrows.-From the observatio~is made i t is concluded that the flood current coming in through Salisbury Sound flows up through the Narrows iintZ illto the broader part of Peril Strait, nortlr of Pogibshi Point, when i t meets tho flood that has come up throupli Chatham Strait and into the eastern end of Peril Strait. J u s t where in this broad part they meet is u~lcertain, but from the observations made it is concluded that both currel~ts spread out and lose theniselves. The tiirie of slack water in Sergius and Adalns Narrows varies from orlc hour and thirty minutes before high and low water to two hours and thirty minutes, tho avelaagu being about two hours. The slack high seems to come earlier than tlio slack low, and seldom comes less than two l~oursbefore high water, while the slack low seldoln comes more tlmn two hours before low water. The duration of slack is only a few minutes, in filct, sometimes i t ceases to run in on(. tlirection and immediately start8 in the other, and is not half an l~our as stated in the Sailing Directions. There is half an hour, however, when the current does not exceed two knots, and tho surthce is comparatively smooth, and veusels may go through wit11 safety. The strongest current observed was 8.8 knots. It is probable that it renches 10 knots a t spring tides, and boils and swirls in sucli :t, manner that navigation is unsafe from below Francis Rocks to Leisnoi Island.
COOK INLET A N D TO THE WESTWARD.

The following information concer~~ing Cook Inlet a8ndthe region to tho westward io compiled fro111the notes of Prof. IT. H. Dall, U. S. Geologicnl Survey, made by him ill the summer of 1895, and published in the March bulletill of the American Geographical Society, by whose permission it is used. The changes suggested by him, as far as possible, have been made on Co:tst Survey charts Xos. 8500 and 8651, and will be made on the next edition of No. SSOO. The uncharted harbor on the north side of Capo Douglas, the southwest point of entrance to Cook Inlet, is included between the rounded low pe~iinsula of Capo Douglas and a narrower cape on the west and north rising about 40 feet from the top of the steep beach. To the south three glaciers are visible, two coming down south of Capo Douglas, and one ending in a stream which discharges into the southern part of the bight. The southernmost glacier is the largest. The shore about Cape Douglas is defended by numerous roclrs, and should not he approacl~ed too closely. Within tho bay, anchorage may be had in 2 to 8 fathoms under tho west cape, where tho bottom appears to be clear. The south and east parts of the bay nro moro or less shoal and rocky and should be avoided. In entering, the navigator should keep the western shore aboard. Sholter may be had here in any wind except heavy northerly and nortlieasterly gales. Leaving the capo, the northern slope of the mass of mountains behind it is seen to bo snow covered, and with three very large snowy glaciers descending to tho vicinity of the sea. The easternmost appears to be tho largest, and shows an even snowy surface without lateral moraines. Northwest of the group of mountains is a space of comparatively low land crossing the peninsula behind the shoal and dangerous Kamisliak Bay. Over these plains many caribou are said to range in summer. Between Cape Douglas and Augnstin Island, and. about G or 8 miles from the latter, are the Sea Otter Rocks, a low group not definitely placed on the charts. We steamed a fitraight conrse XW. $ W. (p. c.) from tho cape in calm, clear weather, which, according to the latest charts, would

REPORT FOR 1896-PART

11.

APPENDIX NO. 11.

389

have carried us directly over the rocks, but in fact carried us about 2 miles west of them. A t low water there were two low, flat table rocks. with a smaller pointed one between them, visible a t a distance of 2 miles, the eye being 10 feet above the water. A t high water they are said to be awash. mre brought them in one with n high bluff, which we supposed to be Point Bede, on the east shore of the inlet, bearing NE. by E. Tliese rocks collstitute a serious danger to navigation. Augustin Island (otherwise Black Fox or Chernobura) is a typical volcanic peak, with low borders of talus. At present, auchorage inay be had in 33 fathoms, saud, about a rnilu offshore, witli the south point bearing SE. by S., the western point NW., and the peak NE. by E. 6 E. The soutli point is low and sandy, but tho bbat landing is best here, the beach running off very shoal nortli of it. The west point is composed of ashes and volcanic stones, forming low, bluff' banks, and running off in flats, upoil which the bowlders of volcanic rock, soxnetiliics very large, arc irrcgularly distzibuted. No chart of the island esists. Tliere was formerly an escellent harbor for small craft on tho west side, and the inner liarbor still exists, but the entrance is now dry a t low water. This change was brought about a t the time of the last eruption, less than ten years ago. The peak has tho regular volcanic form, the rim of the crator being somomhat broken away ou the west and nortli. Steam issues in illterlnittont p&s from the crater and inner cone?and when these puffs riso vertically a r ~ d spread out like a mushroom above the poak it is taken as an evidence by the natives of several days of calm weather, during which thoy do not llesitate to put out far from slloro in their frail kyaks to l ~ u n the t sea otter. The peak is about 3,000 feet in height. The upper t~vo-tllirds of the peak is largely snow covered; below, much is bare ashes and scattered lava blocks, then more or less herbage \lTithstunted spruce, sparsely scattered, and low, creeping :~lders. The borders of the island to tho south and west are low and hunimocky, wit11 niany bogs i ~ r l c lsmall pools. The south shore has bluffs of variable height; none very high. The passage west of the island is foul near the islalid shore, but has a navigable passage rather closer to the mainland shore. Tuxedui Harbor, sometiues called Snug Harbor, lies between Chisick Island : ~ n d the mainland. That n snug harbor is to bcfountl here is noted on a sketch chart of tlie United States Hydrographic Office, but that the bay is 5 or G rniles long, free from dangers, and forming a spacious auchorage, would hardly be supposed from the very imperfect indications give11 on the best charts. Chisick Island is narrow, and rises over 2,000 feet in height, with bluti shores, the water bold-to. There is a small, round, high, rocky islet outside of Chisick, which forms a convenient landmark for vessels feeling their way alougshoro in a fog, wliich sometilues conceals the entrance. The sout,hern end of Chisick is high and narrow, with no reef or rocks off it, as has bee11 erroneously stated. The strata are somewhat inclined to the south near the entrance, but in tho main are elearly horizontal, aud composed of heavy beds of saudstono and conglomerate of varying hardness, so that the upper part of tho island weathers into steps like terraces on a grand scale, off'ering a remarkable castellated appearance to the spectator. The scenery here is very fine and peculiar in its features. The splendid volcanic peak of Iliamna rises among the mountains SW. by w. fro111the harbor a t a distance of some 16 miles. I t s upper part is set with glaciers, but the conical form and scenic beauty of the peak can only be fully realized from a greater distance. The fairway of the harbor is nearly straight, with high and singularly weathered cliff's rising on either hand. Toward the head i t widens a little. Here good holding ground may be had in 18 fathoms. A t this point the vessel which carries domrl the product of the salmon canneries from the inlet is anchored for the summer. The cannecl salmon is brought to lier by small light-draft steam tenders, which can cross the shallow water ou the bars of the rivors a t Eassiloff and Nenilchik, whore the salmon are taken. From Captain Hughes we learned that the spring tido in June was 36 feet; a t ordinary times the range is about 24 feet. The xiortheni end of tho harbor is protected by reefs aud foul ground beyond Chisick Island, where there is a large open bay. There may be a channel out this may, but until i t is surveyed i t would be illiprudel~t to attempt the passage except with small craft. Illto this bay a large river falls, fed by the glaciers of Iliamila and tho drainago of the other mountains. The north end of Ohisick shows high bluffs rising lliuch above those 011 the main shore, aud above to I I magnificent castellated ~ u ~ n m of i t curiously eroded almost horizontal beds of saudand conglo~nerate, which can hardly bo less than 2,000 feet in elevation. Near stone, li~uestone,

390

the beaches the rocks are worn into caves, arches, and pillars, about which circle innumerable multitudes of sea birds. There is no' bar or obstructiou a t the entrance of the harbor, but the great range of the tides and tlle narrom form of the harbor produce well-marked rips rtt certain stages of the tide, which might lead to the supposition that rock8 or shoals exist. On the island side the shores are boltl-to; on the mainland a t the head of the harbor it is shoal for a long dista~lcefrom the beach. Notwithstanding the absence of protection a t the entrance, southerly minds do not blow home into the harbor on account of the highland on either side; but for the same reason mind from the land is often stronger in the harbor thau out in the inlet. July 23, 1895, flood tide made shortly after 3 p. m. A11 the navigation in the upper part of Cook Inlet is commonly carried on with reference to the tides; a sailing vessel can make no headway against them and it is the custom t o auchor during the unfavorable tides, which can be done almost anywhere alongshore. Off the West Foreland there is a small village of Kootena Indians, and here the shore is of bluffs, apparently about 50 feet high, of gravel and sand, wooded above, with some high rno~~ntains distant in the iuterior. It was slack water here about 10 a. m. ,July 24. Between the tmo Forelands is a wide bay with shoal water aud many scattered bowlders rising out of i t alor~gthe shore. The land behind is very low in part, all heavily wooded with spruce, and a river c:brrying very muddy water comes in here. Near the North Foreland is a series of whitish gravel blutfs of very regular height, with a broad beach and sllallow water for a mile otf it, with scattered, sometimes very large, squarish rocks of whitish color irregularly tlistributed over the flats. There are Indiar~ houses in the principal gap in this series of bluffs, but the largest settlement, Tyonek, is near the point of the Foreland, where a small gravel flat exists. Here the water off the beach for half a mile is f f the ForeIand southward, in the middle of the inlet, most chsrts show an shoal, but not foul. O area inclosed by a dotted liue connected continuously with foul ground on the southeast shore of the inlet. This is an error, as there is a clear passage on each side of the central patch, which latter trends with the i d e t and shows a t low water large bare sand banks 8 or 10 feet high. East of North Foreland and between i t and Point Possession, also in the middle of the inlet, is a flat or shoal not shown on tho charts and which constitutes a serious danger. It is believed to be 6 or G miles long and not less than 4 miles wide. I t s southern edge is about WSW. (mag.) from Point Possession. The village of Tyonek is small, without a harbor, and the spot is inaccessible by sea in winter, as this part of the inlet freezes over. Tho tido is from 25 to 35 feet in range here, mith a depth of 33 fathoms half a mile off the beach. Turnagain Bay extends to the eastward from Point Possesuion aud is the passageway to the placer mines, of which much has been said in the public press.* Xortheasterly from Point Possession, on the continent, the laud is mostly low, formed by the delta of the Sushitna ltiver. West of the river, a t some distance i n l a ~ ~rises d , a noted landmark, a low but conspicuous peak known as Sushitna Mountain. Eastward from the Snshitua, another, the Knik or Pire River, enters the inlet north of Point Campbell. West of Poirtt Campbell is a s~uall high island called Fire Island, to which sufficient water for an ordinary schoo~ler may be had a t low tide, according to local navigators. Both at Point Campbell and Point Possession the land is low and wooded, but a t about 12 miles eastward of the latter the mountains come to the water's edge, with narrow steep-sided raviues and canyons, in which are tlio streams where gold is washed. The land rises to about 2,000 feet; some of the peaks are higher, and the slopes are rather sparsely wooded. The rise and fall of the tide in Turnagain Bay is remarkable, and the ~niddleof the passage, as well as much of its margin, is occupied by extensive flats, partially dry a t low water, mith a shallow chanr~el a t each side. To enter the bay and avoid the shoals, keep Point P o s ~ e s sior~ well aboard and steer for the northern edge of the highland on the south side of the bay, keeping a little to the southward of a straight course between the two; keep the lead constantly going, as the shoals shift to some extent. Allow for a tide of 50 feet in range and select an :ltlch~rage in accordance with the circnm~tancesof the case. The northern channel i s not navigable eastward of Fire Island, and the island is nearer to Point Campbell and ratl~er more southerly in position than indicated by the existing charts. The shoal in the center of the bay is elongated,

Off the highland west of our anchorage is a small, high island, called "Haystack" by the miners. It rises out of the flats, which dry all arouud i t a t low water. ICachemak Bay, on the eastern shore of tho inlet, is interesting on account of tho presence of extensive deposits of brown coal, and because i t is the finest harbor in the inlet, never obstructed by ice, and one of the dnest on the wholo Pacific Coast. It separates tho comparatively level plateau of the Eenai Peninsula, west of its axial mountain rango, from a spur of that range which comes down to the sea a t Point Bede, in which-there are several indentations affording anchorage. These mouutains nre rtot very high, but from them descend several attractive glaciers not difficult to reach. The rocks on this side of the bay are mostly crystalline or eruptivo, forming a lnarked contrast to tho bluffs of nearly horizontal sandstone and clays, with conspicuous coal searns which border the opposite shore. The harbor is protected by a long, low apit of gravel, within close to tho shore, but the beach in front of the bluffs makes off shoal for which is good ~ucliorage 2 or, toward the head of the bay, fully 3 miles. The range of tide in the upper bay is 22 feet, but a t springs tho extreme range is said to be 30 in the upper part of the bay and somewhat less toward the entranco. Excepting a few buildings connected with the work of coal prospectors there is no fiettlement within the spit. I n the lower bay, outside of tho harbor, is a snug auchorage, Chesloknu of tlie natives, Seldovia or Herring Bay of the Russians. Here are two trading stations, and most of tlie inhabitauts from Port Graham, where the harbor is less convenient, liavo migrated to Selclovia VilIage. Thero is quite a collection of houses and a Greek chapel. No chart has been published of this anchorage, except tt small delil~eationfrom a Russian sketch which is included in the chart of Eachemak Bay, compiled by the Coast Survey, No. 8651. The bluff' a t tho southeast head of the entrance is composed of two small rocky islets united to each other and to the mainland by a low spit, so that the laud is not continuously high, as represeuted on the sketch alluded to. Tho e n t r a ~ ~ has c e rocky botto~u clear across, with kelp growing in 6# fathoms. Tlte northern head is bluff and rocky; a rounded bowlder lies off it, visible a t lovi mater. Thero are also roclia abovo and below water about tlie opposito headland. Inside there aro 7 and 8 fathoms, sandy bottom, off the village in mid-harbor, with protection from all winds except northwest, nnd a t the head of the harbor coln~leto shelter. Amalik Harbor lies behind Takhli Island, on the south side of the Alaska Peninsula. We tbnt~d excellent shelter from all winds, aud auchorage in 10 fathoms, sand. ' A long inlet penetrates t l ~ e land here, which has never bee11 snrveyed. The rocks are mostly coarse s:indstones, pierced by volcariic dike8 and contain Reains of s superior quality of brown coal. Coal 13ay is a fine sheet of mat,er, of which no charts exist and the indications on tlio general charts are very inaccurate. The entrance is partially obstructed by an area of foul ground with rocky islets and pinnacles extending to the southyest from the northeastern point of ontr;bnco for several miles. There i s no conspicuous xnountairi recognizable as the one on the charts near the village. Tho mountains resemble those of Cold Bay, but, as the strata are inclined more steeply, do not show horizontal benches. There are several visible rocks there, but no hidden dangers. The portage to tlle Ugaguk River, of the r~orthernslope of the peninsula, begins in n valley near the western e11d of the inner bay. A t the extreme southwesterl~end rises the Olai Volcano, from which, 011 its eastern flank, a large glacier descends, whilb on the seaward slope two others colne do\vu froln the same masif. Tlle moiuitains slope gradually toward the beach, covered with dense herbage. Chignilr Bay opens to the eastward, with no concealed dangers. I t s ~ 0 ~ 1poiut t h of entrance headland, sornetin~es c<illedCastle Point, which forms a 1:iudmark is Tuliurnnit Point, a ren~arlrable for navigators in this vicinity. The point is extremely narrow and composed of tertiary sandstones, forming a shallow syncline, the stratification being a conspicuous fcature. North and west of the point is a deep indentation lruowu a s Castle Bay, unsurveyed, but which is said to afford anchorage on its northwest side. Tho grassy bighlauds west of the bay afford feeding grounds at times for the wild caribou, and by driving them to the narrow point (which a t one place is only a few hundred feet wide) large ~iumbers are said to be secured by hunters. 'I'lie south shore of Chiguik Bay, west of Castle Bay, is bluff and high, with four indentations, the two to the east being closed by bars of gravel, behind which shallow lagoons exist, mllile the two farther west aflord aiicborage. The westernmost, ilalned Doris Cove, is a snug and perfectly protected harbor, and mas surveyed by the United States Coast Survey in 1874. Here the vessel which serves the associated salmon canneries is anchored during the season. The extreme southwestern coruer of the bay is marked by a, high, round-topped, vertical bluff, a t the foot of which is the entralice to Chignik Lagoon, protected by a long sand spit, with a navigable chaunel between i t and the bluff. There ie a least depth of 8 fathoms on the bar and 22 feet of water a t high tide. A light. draft stern-wheel steamer affords t,rsnsportation, and there is water enough in the river to permit the ascent of this boat several milea, to a point where a seam of brown coal is worked by the association for use in the canneries. It was high water i n the lagoon about 1.30 p. m. on August 4. The river is bordered by vertical baulrs of tortimy rocks, 30 or 40 feet in average height. Two or threo miles above the coal mine the river issues from a large lake, said to be 6 or 7 miles long, and connected with another, equally large, by a stream 5 or G miles in length. The topography is rolling, with low hills and a wide expanso of tundra, on which caribou find grazing. An important centre of trade, fisheries for cod, and gold mining, are found iu tllo Shumagin Islauds a t Delaroff Harbor, Unga, and Sand l'oint, a few miles above. Tho harbor a t Delaroff Village has not been surveyed, though a small Russian sketch was printed many years ago. It consists of an outer roadstead surrounded with rocky clifs, mheru vessels may lay to a mooring, and an inner lagoon, mllich has been statod to be silted up. It has been found, however, that good anchorage for vessels drawing not Illore than 12 feet may bo had inside the entrsnco to the 1;igoon. This is important, as the outer bay is unsafe in southeast gales, a i d several wrecks have occurrod there. APPENDIX NO. 12-1896.
LOGARITHMS, THEIR NATURE, COMPUTATION, AND USES, WITH LOGARITHMIC TABLES O F NUMBERS AND CIRCULAR FUNCTIONS TO TEN PLACES O F DEOIMALS-PART I..
By W. W.DUI'FIEI.I), Superintendent.
HISTORY.

1 . Logarithms were invented by John Napier, Baron of Marchiston, in 1614. This original system was an exceedingly complicated one and, in consequence, of little practical use., 3fost mat%-, matical writers consider the natural system of logarithms, whose base is 2.7182818284590G23636Of and whose modulus is +1, as that originally devised by Napier, and in the published tables these logarithms aro called Napierian. This is a serious error. Tlle natural system was invented by John Speidel, and his table of ';New Logarithms" was published in London in 1619. As Baron Napier died April 4,1617,he could not, by any possibility, have ever seen this system. T h e Napierian and Speidelian systems differ widely. I n the Napierian the logarithms decrease as their corresponding 0 ' or 10 000 000 is zero. The logarithms of all numbers increa'ee. The Napierian logarithm of 1 rlumbers greater than 10; are negative; those of all numbers less than lo7are positive, and the modulus of the Napierian systenl is very nearly equal to -1. I n the Speidelian system the log* rithrns increase as their corresponding nnmbers increase--tho logarithm of 1 is zero and the modulus of the system is +l. As the Speidelian system is much used in tho quadrature of the hyperbola, i t is also called A system of hyperbolic logarithms, and its modrllus being 1 i t is also called a system of natural logarithms. Baron Napier realized the complicated character of his system, and that a system of logarithms with 10 as a base would be inuch simpler and better adapted to ordinary calculations. H e began tho computation of a table of Iogarithms upon this baso, but his death prevented its cornplotion. At his request his friend, Henry Briggs, professor of mathematics a t Gresham College, completed and published in 1G18 the first table of logarithms whose base is 10. This system is called, after its inventor, the Briggsian, or, moro frequently, the cogmon system.
DESORIPTION.

2. The logarithm of any number is tho exponent of that power to which the base of the system ]nust be reiwod in order to produce the given number. Thus in the common ~ y s t e m whose base is 10 we have 10'6= = 410,which is 3.1622777. Hence 0~5000000000 is the common logarithm of the mixed number 301622777. Again 10%=lOO'WBB+ = 7 log = VlT0 = 4.6416888. Hence 0.6666666666 is the common logarithm of the mixed number 4*6415888. 3 . Hence the logarithms of the integral or whole roots of 10 are reciprocal8 with negative expo~lents. 10. The logarithlus of all numbers greater than 1and less than 10 will be greater than 0 and less than 1,that is, a proper fractiou or decimal without an iuteger; the logarithms of all numbers Imixed number greater than 1.0 and less than lob will be greater than 1aud less than 2, that is, I whose integral portion will be 1. The integral portion of a logarithm is called its characteristic, the decimal portion is called the
mantissa.

fractions are written with the negative sign placed over the characteristic, and the positive sign, preceding the mantissa, omitted. Thus : Log 3/10=i.4771312547. Log 3/100=2-4771212647. 12. Since shifting the decimal point to tho right in any combination of numbers is equivalent to multiplying such combination by 10, and since the logarithms of the integral pomers of 10 are integral or whole numbers (81, it is evident that the same combination of numbers will have the sanle mantissa and the characteristics only will change with tho nurnber of integral digits in that number. Thus: LO^ o~oi234=2.09i3i5i5~7. LO^ o.i234=-i.o9i3i6i697. Log 1.234 =O-09 13161507. Log 12.34 =1.0013161597. Log 133.4 =3.0913151697. Log 1234 =3.0013161597. Hence in logarithmic tables only the mantissm are given. The characteristics can always be readily determined by the following rules. 13. Sinco tho logarithm of 1is 0, that of 10 is 1, tllat of 100 is 2, and that of 1000 is 3, (S), it is evldeut that tho char:lcteristic of an integer or mixed number is 1 less than the number of its integral digits; henco the Rule.-To find the characteristic of any integra.1or rnixed number. Subtract unity, or 1,from the number of integral or whole digits; the difference will be tho characteristic of the given number. Example.-What is the logarithm of 1093 t Tlle mantissa for 1003 is .0386301619. There are four digits in 1093, and 4- 1=3; hence tho logarithm of 1093 is 3-03S6201619.. %'zn?,tple.-What is the logarithm of 15.031 The mantissa for 13.03 is -1149444157. There ;Ire two integral digits in 13.03 and 3-1=1; hence the logarithm of 13.03 is 1-1149444187. 14. Since the logarithm of 1/10 or 0.1 is -1, that of 1/100, or 0.01, is - 2, that of 1/1000, or 0.001, is -3, and that of 1/10000,or 0.0001, is 4, (9), it is evident that tho negative characteristic of a 'decima.1fraction is always unity or 1 greater than the number of intervening zeros between the decimal point and the &st significant figure; lienco theRule.-To find t l ~ e negativo characteristic of any decimal fraction. Add unity, or 1,to the number of interveuing zeros botmoeu tho decimal point and the first significant figure, the sum will bo the negativo characteristic of the given decimal fractiou. .Exa?)tple.-What is the logarith~nof 0.1193 8 The mantissa for 1103 is -0766404437. There aro no zeros between the decimal point and the first significant figure, and 0 1=1 ; hence the logarithm of 0.1103 is i-0766404437. DESORIPTION OF THE TABLES.

15. I n the ,accompanying logarithmic tables all tho ruantissm have been compnted to twelve places of decimals, and whenever the eleventh and twelfth places exceeded 50 tho tenth placo has been increased by unity, or 1; hnt whenever the eleventh and twelfth places were 50 or less than that number the tenth placo has not boen increased. When these compntationu mere begun, I was not aware that Baron Qe-orge von Vega had preceded me in his Thesaurus Logarit,h~norumCompletus. But my own results have been carefully compared with those of Von Vega, and whenever any difference was detected the computation was made anow. I n this way many serious errors (undoubtedly typographical) in Baron von Vegrt's tables have been discovered and corrected. The arrangement of Baron van Vega7s tables is not as convenient as that given' in more modern tables, and therefore the accompanying tables are arranged in the same manner as the admirable tables published by Messrs. W. 8 R. Chambers, London and Edinburgh, 1885. I n the following tables the mantisare are entered to ten places of decimals. I n the flrst column on tho left are entered, i n consecntive order, the natural nlirnbers beginning with 1 E a u d estanding to 9999. I n the horizontal line a t the top of the page are entered, in oonsecutive order, the numbers 0,1,2,3,4,6,6,7,S, and 9. In the second column on the left headed 0, the mantissa

are entered to the tenth place of decimals, aud whenever the eleventh and twelfth places exceed 50 tho tenth place is increased by unity, or 1. But in order to economize space and save repetition the columns headed 1,2,3, etc., contain only the last soveli figures of their respective mantissze. Hence, to complete the inantissac taken from these columl~s, the first threo figures must headed 0, either on the same horizontal line mith the required mantissa, be taken from the colu~lin or on oue or Inore of tlie lines above such horizontal line aud prefixed to the last seven figures of the mantissz foulid in tlie columns headed 1,2,3,4, etc. But wheuever a black line is drawn o w the last seven figures of any mantissa found in the columns headed 1,2,3,4, etc., the first three figures necessary to prefix to thesg seven figures of the required mantissa must be taken from the column headed 0 in the horizontal line iulmediately under or below that on which the mantiesie of the given numbers are found. 16. The ten columns on the right of the page, headed L b Differences 0, 1,2, 3, 4, etc.," are the differences between any two consecutive logarithms in the table aud wliich will be foulid on the with each other. Thus tlie difference between a logarithlu same horizontal line in juxtapositio~~ in the column headed 0 and the logarithm on the same horizontal line in the colunln lieaded 1will be found on the same horizontal line in the column of differences headed 0. And the difference between a logarithm in the column headed I and that on the same horizontal line in the columli headed 2 will be found on the sanle horizolltal line in the column of differences headoil 1. The column of differences headed 0 contains the entire differences of six digits, but those headed 1,2, 3, etc., contain only the last three figures of such differonce, and to those must bo prefixed of differelices headed 0, either on the same horithe first three figures taken from the colum~i zontal line or above that line, unless a black line is drawn above the last three figures in any column of difference, when the three figures to be prefixed to the give11 difference must be taken from the horizolital line below or under such dieerenee in the column headed 0. Example.-What is the mantissa of 10013 As this mantissa will be tho same (12) mantissa with 10010 it will be found on the same horizorital line with the number 1001, and in the vertical column headed 0. But only the last seven figures, viz, 4340775, are found ill tliis column. THE LOGARITHM O F A GIVEN NUMBER.

17. To find the logarithm of any number col~tai~liug less than four digits. Rule.-Annex the requisite number of zeros until it contains f w digits. Look in the lefthand column for tho number with zeros annexed, and on the same horizontal line in the column headed 0 the required mantissa will be found. The zeros annexed mill uot change the mantissa (18). The characteristics will be determined by rules already given (13,14). Exatnp1e.-What is tho logarithm of 44 Annexing three zeros this becomes 4000, and on the same horizontal lino with this number and 'in the vertical column headed 0 the mantissa mill be found and will be .6020599913. The given number being integral with but one digit mill have a The logarithm of 4 mil1 therefore be 0.6020599913. characteristic of 1-1=0. Exat)zple.-What is the logarithm of 0.371 Annexing two zeros this number becomos 3700, and on the aamo horizolltnl line with this number, iu the left-hand column, and in tho vertical columt~ headed 0 the,mantissa will be found and mill be .5682017241. The number being a decimal fraction \\rill have a negative characteristic of one more than the intervening zeros between the decilual poilit and the first significallt figure. There being no intervening zeros, the negative characteristic will be 0 + 1= 1. Therefore, the logarithm of 0.37 mill bo i.6682017341. Esat,cple.-What is the logarithm of 0-0483P Aunexing one zero this number becomes 4830, and on the same horizontal line with this xiumber in the vertical column headed 0 the mantissa mill be found to be -6S39471308. The number being a decimal fraction mill have a negative characteristic of one Inore than the intervening zeros between the decimal point and the first siguificant figure. Thorefore, the logarithm of 0.0483 mill be 8.6839471308. 18. To find the logarithm of any number containing four digits. Rule.-Look in the left-hand column headed "numbersv and on the samo horizontal line mith it, in the column headed 0, the required mantissa mill be found. The characteristic will be determined by the rules already given (13, 14). Exa9)tple.-What is tho logarithm of 65239 On the same horizontal.line with this number, in the vertical colurn~lheaded 0, the lnantissa mill be found to be -7576237459. There are four Therefore, the logarithm integral figures and tho characteristie will be positive and 4-1=3. of 6723 mill be 3.7576237459. l3xanqle.-What is the logarithm of 0-004732f On the same horizontal line with this number and iu the vertical column headed 0, the ~uantissa will be found to be *6750447360. The quantity is a decimal fraction and the characteristic will be negative (14). There are two intervening zeros betmeen the decimal point and the first siguificant figure, and 2+1=3. The characteristic will therefore bo 3. The 16gnrithm of 0.004738 mill be 9-N"70447380. 19. To find the logarithm of any number containing fire figures. Rule.-Tho mantissa mill be foulld on the same horizontal line mith tho first four figures of the give11 number i n the loft-hand column of the page, but in the vertical column headed with the last figure. The charactoristic mill be found by tho rules already given (13,14). E ~ a ~ j ~ ~ l e . - - Wis h athe t logarith~n of 574.321 On the same horiizontal line with the flrst four figures, 5743, in the left-hand column, but in tho vertical colum~l headed 2, tho required mantissa mill be foulld to be -7591530403. There are throe integral figures in the number. The charaoteristic will be positive and 3 1= 2. Tho logarithm of 674.33 will be 2.7591539403. E ~ a ~ n ~ ~ e . -is ~ the h a logarithm t of 0.000754631 On the same horizontal line with 7646, but in the vertical columu headed 3, the required mantissa will be found to be ~8777340664. The quantity is a decimal fraction and tlie characteristic will be negative. There are three zero8

between the decimal point and the first significant figure and 3 1= 4. The characteristic will therefore be k The logarithm of 0.00075463 will be &8777340664. 50. To find the logarithm of any number containing more than flue figures. Rule.-Find the mantissa for the firat five figures by tho rule already given (19). Consider all figures after the fifth as $-ecimals. Multiply this decimal portion of the number by the difference fonnd in the table between the mantissa of the first five figures and the next higher mantissa in the table. Point off the requisite numbers of decimals in the p'roduct and add the integral portion of tho product to the mantissa of the first five figures, and the sum will be the ~nantissa of the required number. If the figure in the first decimal place or tenths of the product exceeds five, add unity or 1to the units of such product; but if the figure in tho tent11 place is less than five reject the tlecimal portion of the product and add only the integral portion. The characteristic will be found by the rules already given (13, 14). The above rule is based upon the following principle: The differences give11 iu the table correspond with an increase of 1 in the Afth place of any number. Hence tho sixth place of any number will correspond mith the tenths of such difference, tho seventh place mith hundredths, ancl the eighth plaoo with tliousandths of such tabular differences; that is, all figures after the fifth place of any number will be decimals of tho diSference given in the table. Example.-What is the logarithm of 4573p758 The mantissa of 45732 is found in tho same horizontal line with 4673, but in the vertical column headed 2, and js .660220194d Tho last three figures of the difference between the mantissa of 45732 and 45733 are fonnd in the column of differences headed 2 aud on the same horizontal line with 4573, and will be 964, to which must be prefixed the first two figures fonnd in tho horizontal line above the last three figures, but in the vertical column of differences headed 0, and mill bo 94. The differenco mill therefore be 94964. Regarding the last three figures of the given number whose logarithni is required as clecimals, and multiplying the difference by the decimal we have 94964 x 0.275=26115.100. Then adding the integral portion, we have -6602201048 Mantissa of 4.5732~ Add integral portion of product 26116 Mantissa of 457322763 -6602228063, suln. The number contains 8 figures wholly integral; tho characteristic will tlierefore be positive Therefore tho logarithm of 45732278 will be 7.6602228063. and 8-1=7. Example,-What is the logarithm of 0*000034572325? The mantissa of 34572 will be fonnci in the same horizontal lino with tho number 3457, but in the vertical column headed 2, arld will be .6387846043. The last three figures of the diffcrenco between the mantissa of 34572 and 34573 will be fonnd in the column of differences on the same horizontal line with 3457, but in the vertical column headed 2, and will bo 619, to which must be prefixed the first threo figures taken from the vertical columrl headed 0, above the horizontal line of the last three figures, and will bo 125. The difference will be 125619. Regarding the last thrco figures of tIie given nuuiber whoso logarithm is required as decimals and multiplying tho difference by tho decimal, me have 125619 x 0.225, or a product of 28264.276. Rule.-Take from the table the next lower logarithm than the given one with its corresponding number of five places.. Subtract the less logarithm from the greater and divide the remainder by the tabular difference of the logarithm given in the table and tho next higher one, annexing zeros to the remainder for that purpose. Annex the quotient thus obtained to the number of five places taken from the table and this will be tho required 1~~1ilbf3r.

P O S I T I V E CHARACTEBLSTICS.

28. The characteristic of s decimal fraction being negative iincl the mantissa positivo 111) diEerent portions of the samo quantity are aEected by opposite signs. This leads to confusion nnd error. If some method could be devised by which positive characteristics can bo given to tho 11)garithmsof deci~nalfractions this co~lfusioil aud error would be avoided. The arithmetical co~uplement enables us to effect this change. 29. The arithnletical complbirlcnt o i any number is the diff'ereuce betmeeu that uuniber aud tlie uuit of tho llelrt higher order; that is, tho diEerence between tlie given number and nllity, or I , with as many zeros annexed ns thero aro digits in the given nnlnber. Thus the arithmetidtil co~nplement of G is 10 -G =4 ; tliat of 18 is 100 -18=82, and that of 245 is 1000- 245 ='755. 30. To find tlie digerence between two numbers the less must be subtracted from tho greaterand the remainder will be the difference. But the same result can be obtained by adding oile number to the arithlnetical complement of the other, and from their sum deducting tho unit by which tho arithmetical conlplement was obtained.

Thus, 25-6=19, also, 25+4-10=19; again, 9 2 - 1 8 ~ 7 4 , also, 92+S2-100=71; again, 350-245x105, also, 350+'755-1000=105. Hence by substituting tlle arithmetical cornplomeut of the negative characteristic of a decimal fra~tioil for tho negative characteristic of such decimal fraciioil we can .change the sign of such characteristic from negative to positive. 31. Tliis change can be effected by tho following rule: Rtlle.-S~btract the liegative cllaracteristic from 10, the difference mill be tho required arith~neticalcornplewent of such llegati\re cllnracteristic and will also be t.he positive chi~ractcristic required, or Subtract the nul~lber of inbrvening zeros betmeen tlie decimal point and the first sigllificant figure from 9 ; the differellco\\.ill be the required positive cha~.acteristic;and should such intarvening zeros exceed 9 subtract such llulnber of intervening zcros from 19. Any decimn,lfraction with 9 intervening zeros bot\vcen tho decimal point and the first significant figure, as 0~0000000001 is .rcm&b-opsa, or one tell thousand nlilliollth p:rrt of unity or 1. This quantity is 60 very sn~all that ill~~1~~cornp~tati011s with ~ogarithms of decin1a.l fractions wit11positivo cl1:iracteristics it is usual to retain only the units and reject tlle tens of such po~itive chi1r:icteristics.

404
Example.-What teristic 9

UNITED STATES .COABT h N D GEODETIC SURVEY.

is the logarithm of 0.125 with a negative and also mith a positive char:~cWith a negative characteristic i t is 1-0969100130 With a positive characteristic i t i~ 9.0969100130

In both cases the mantissa is the same, but the characteristics are each the arithmetical complement of the other. The negative cllaracteristic being (14) one nlore than the number of the intervening zeros between the decimal point and the first significant figure is 0+1=1. The positive characteristic being the arithmetical complement of the negative characteristic (31) is 10-1=9, arid also being the difference between 9 and the nurnber of the intervening zeros between (31) the decimal point ant1 the first significant figure is 9-0=9. Example.-What is the logarithm of 0.000000000345 with a negative and also wit11 a positive characteristic? With a negative chamcteristic i t is ~.5378190051 With a positive characteristic i t i~ 0.5378190951 Both mantissa? are alike, and the characteristics only difler. There being 9 intervening zeros mill be between the decimal point and the first significant figure, the negative cliaracte~.istic Q + l = l O , and the positive characteristic will be 9-9=0. 32. The arithn~etical comple~nent of the characteristic only of n logarithm, in order to char~ge such characteristic fisom negative to positive, must not be confonnded with the arithmetical cornplement of the entire logarithm. I n the first case the arithmetical complement of the c11aractel.istic only is taken, the ~nantissa remaining unchangetl, and in the second case the aritl~ineticnl coinplement of the entire logarithm, that is, of both characteristic and ~ilantissa is taken. 33. The arithn~eticalcomplement of the entire logaritl~mof any number is the logaritllm of the reciprocal of that number, or the logarithm of unity or 1 divided by the given number. If the number is integral or mixed and not fractional, unch logarithm of a reciprocal will be that of n decimal fractiou wit11 n, positive characteristic. This aritllrnetical complement of an entire logarithni is often uqed in logarithmic co~iil~ut:~tions, and is thus determined : To find the arithmetical compleme~~t of an entire logarithm. Rule.-Subtract the characteristic arltl mantissa of the given logarithm from 10; the diffi~rc~~ce mill be the required arithmetical complement; or, Bezinning on the left, subtract the characteristic and each digit of the &en logarithm, escept the last significant digit, from 9, but subtract the last, or last significant digit, fron~10; the clifference will bc the required arithmctical c o ~ ~ ~ p l o m e ~ ~ t . Example.-What is the arith~neticalcomple~nentof the logarithm c o r r e s p o ~ ~ d i with ~ ~ g the number 25 9 ' Frorn Subtract the logarithnl of 25, whicl~ is 1.397'3400087 Logarithm of 0.04 is
8.fi020598!)13tlifference.

The reciprocal of 25 ib 1/25 = 0.04, a dccim:~l fraction of 'which 8*6020590913is the logaritl~m mith a positive characteristic. E;cample.-What is the arithmetical complement of the' logarithm corresponding to the number 1259 From 10~0000000000 Subtract the logarithm of 125, mhicb is 2.0969100130 Logarithm of 0.008 is

7.9030899870 difference.

The tenth or last figure on the right of the mantissa being zero, the subtraction begin8 with the next to the last or ninth figure of the mantissa,. The reciprocal of 125 is 1/126 = 0408, a decimal fraction of which 7.9030899870 is the logaritl~m with a positive characteristic.

MULTIPLICATION BY LOGAltIl'ENS.

34. Since the addition of logaritlims is equivalent to the multiplication of their corresponding numbers (3), the product of two or more factors can be determined as follows: Rzt1e.-Find the logarithms of all factors, add these loga;rithms, aud their Sum will be the logarithm of the required product. If any of these factors are decimal fractions, and their logarithms have negative characteristics, the algebraic sum of the characteristics must be taken, aud any number carried over from the mantissa must be added to the sum of the positive or subtracted from the sum of the negative characteristics (23, 24). If any of these factors are decimal fractions, and their logaritlims ha\-e positive characteristics, the uuits only of the sum of the characteristics must be retained and the tens rejected (31). EVOLUTION B Y LOGARITHMB.

40. If the logarithm of a number is divided by any number tho quotient will be the logarithm of that root of the corresponding number of which the divisor is the index (6). Hence evolution can be performed by the followillg: Rule.-Divide the logarithm of the given n p b e r by the index of the root; the quotient mill be the logarithm of the required root. If the given ~irimber is a decimal fraction and its logarithm ha8 a negative characteristic not divisible by the iridex of the required root, add to the negative characteristic such a number as will make it a multiple of the given iridex of the root, and prefix to the mantissa a like positive number to that added to the negative characteristic, and divide the negative characteristic and the mantissa with the positive number prefixed by the index of the required root; the quotient will be the logarithm of the required root. If the given number is a decimal fraction and its logarithm has a positive characteristic, subtract unity or 1 from the given index of the root and prefix the difference to the positive characteristic and divide by the index of the required root. The quotient mill be tho logarithm of tho required root (27). . Exump1e.-What is the cube root of 3269811 5.3559895050 - 1.7s53,,95350. The logaritlini of 226981 is 5.3550895050. The index of the root is 3. ----3 The logarithni of G 1 is 1.785329S350. INTERPOLATION OF SERIES.

44. W h e i ~ numbers are calculated by formula and arranged in regular series (as they are in a table of logarithms of nnmbers) the logarithm of any intermediate number may be found by interpolation of series. This method is as follows: Take from the logarithmic table the logarithrus of four consecutive numbers in regulir series, the two which precede and the two which follow that of the required number. From these logarithms find the three first differences, the two second differelrces, and the mean of the second difl'erences as shown in the subjoined table. Tlle required logarith~ll can be determined hy the following formula, in which L= the required logarithm, I= the logarithm of the nearest less number in the table, f= the fractional interval exceeding the nearest less uumber, d= the second or central one of the three first differences, and dl= the meall of the two second differences. Then

CIROULAB FUNCTIONS.

48. Angles are measured by the arc of a circle inclosed betmeeu their sides, the angular point being a t the center of the circle. Thus (Fig. 1 j the angle D C E is measured by the arc A B, mho~e center is a t the angular point C. 1 For the measurement of angles the entire circumference of the circle is divided into 360 degrees, each degree illto GO ~ni~lutes, aud each lni~illte into GO fieconds. If t v o diameters of a circle are drawn a t right angles to each other they mill divide the circle into four equal parts, each of which mill be

c(

I

49. The comple?neltt of any angle is the difference between that angle and 900. Thus the complenlent of 350 is 900 - 35O = 550, and that of 250 is 900 - 5 0 = 650, and that of 750 is 900 - 750 = 150. 30. The suppleme?tt of any angle is the difference betweon that angle and 1800. Thus the supplement of 480 iu 1800 - 450 = 1330, and that of 760 is fig. 1. 1800 - 760 = 1040. 51. The sides of plane triangles are straight lines, aud are therefore determined and compared by Iinear measure whose unit is tho foot or metre. The ar~gles of such tris~lgles are measured by arcs of circles, and therefore compared by circular ~neasuro whose unit is the degree. There is no comlnon standard to mhich the foot or metre and degree H call be referred and by which they can be compared. Mathematicians are therefore compelled to refer the angles of plane triangles to certain straight lines mhich ore functions of circular arcs by mhich angles are measured, and are hence called circular junctions, A s these are absolutely necessary in the computations of triangle^, they are also called trigonometrical functions. There are six circular or trigonometrical functions, namely: The eine, the cosine, the tangent, the cotangent, the secant, and the cosecant. The cosine, cotangent, and cosecant are complements (49)of the aine, tangent,and secant, the piefix Fig. 2. co being an abbreviation of the word con~plement. 62. From D (0g. 2) let fall the perpe~idicula?DC upon the line AE, and from the point of intersection C describe the semicircumference ABDE. Then the arc ABDE mill be one of 1800, the arcs DE: and AD will each be a quadrant or quarter of a circle, and the angles ACD aud ECD mill each be a right angle. Also the arc AB will be the coplplernent of the arc BD (49). The arc AB will also be the supplement (50) of the arc BDE. 53. The sine of all arc or an angle is the perpendicular let fall frou~ one extrenlity of that arc upon the diameter drawn through the other extremity. Thus BF (fig. 3), is the sine of the arc AB or of the angle BCA. 64. The cosine of an arc is the sine of its complement; therefore, as BD (fig. 8) is the complement of AB (49), BK the sine of BD is the cosine of the arc AB or of the angle ACB. But BK = CF. Herice the cosine of an arc is the liue drawn from the center of the circle to the foot of the sine or CP. 55. The tangent of an arc or angle is a line dram11 from one extremity of an arc a t right drawn through such extremity, and couti~iued thence until i t iutersec1;s the angles to the dis~neter
