Thus CH (fig. 9 ) is the secant of AB and CL is the secant of Bl). 68. The cosecant of an arc is the secant of the colnplement of that arc. Thus CL (fig. 2), which is the sccant of the arc BD, is the cosecant of the arc AB. 59.. Prom the preceding tlefiriitions me deduce tlie following obvious results, viz: (a) Between 00 and 900 the sine, tailgent, and Recant increase as the arcs illcrease, and the cosine, cotangent, aud cosecaut decrease as the arcs increase. (b) When tlie aye is one-eight11of i t circle or 450, the sine and cosix~e are eqnal, tho taligent aud cotangent are equal, and the secant and coseca~~t are also equal. Tlie tangent aud cotangent of 460 are also each equal to tlie radius. (c) Wlien tho arc is 00, its cosecant aud cotangent are each infinite, its sine :md tangeut are each zero, nild its secant and cosi~ie are each cqual to tlie radius. ( d ) Wlien the arc is a quadrant or 903, its sine :lntl cosecant are each eqnal tc) the radius, its tangent and secant are infinite, ; ~ u d its cosine and cotangent are each zero. GO. DESCRIPTION OF TAIXLlS OF CIROULAR FTJNOTIONS.

05. In most tables of logarithlnic circular functions the radius of the measnring circle is assnmed a t 1 0 ~or " 10 000 000 000, for the purpose of dispensing with uegative characteristics. But 'as ill all otller'formuloe relative to the circle, the radius is assullied as uuity or 1, and as in

414

UNITED STATES COAST AND GXOL)ETIC SURVEY."

deteruliiling the naturai circular functious the radius of the measnring circle is also unity or 1, this new value of t l ~ c radius is apt to mislead. Nor is this new value of radius necessary, si~lcethe radius of the ruewuring circle can be assuu~ed as unity or 1, provided all iiittural f'unetions less than unity or 1are regarded as deci~usl fractions whose logarithms have positive cl~aracteristics (31). Tlris table contains tho logn~.ithmic ~ n l n c .of :\I1 tlie natural fhnctious froul 03 to 900,t.he radills of the measuring circle being unity or 1, ant1 for eve1.g rlatural fi~nction less t1r:ln unity 01. CONVERSION O F LOGARITHMS.

73. Since the logarithms of the same number in two different systems arc to each other as the moduli of those systems (dl, c) the logarithm of any number in one system o:m be convorted into tliat of any other. NATURAL FUNCTIONS.

76. Wheu the radius of the measuring circle is uuit,y or 1,tho functions are called natural functions. Tho radius of the tablo of logarithmic circular functions annesed heroto being also unity or 1(Cis), the various quantities given in that table are the logarithlus of the natural functions. Hence the natural functions of ally arc call be found by tho.folloming Rzcle.-Take from the table the logarithmic circulal- function for the given arc by tho rules already given (68,69). Find the uumber corresponding to such logarithm by the rule already given (21), and such number will be the natural function of the given arc. 77. I n tlie application of the role it must be remembered t h a t (a) When t,he arc is 900, its siue, being equal to radius, (59 d) is ullity or 1,and the si~ies of all arcs less than 900 are less than unity or 1slid aro, thereforo, decimal fractions. (b) Whon the arc is 00, its cosine, being equal to radius (50 c), is unity or 1, and the cosines of a11 arcs greater than 00 are less than unity or 1 and are, therefore, decimal fractions. (c) When the arc is 450, its tangent, being equal to radius (59b), is unity or 1,and tho tallgelits of dl arcs greater than 450 aro greater than unity or 1,or mixed numbers, and tho tangeuts of all arcs less than 450 are less than uuity or 1and are, therefore, decimal fractions. (d) When the arc is 450, its cotangent, being equal to radius (69 b), is unity or 1,and tlle cotangellts of all arcs less than 450 are greater than unity or 1,or mixed numbers, and the cotange~~ts of all arcs greater than 450 are less than unity or 1and are, therefore, tlecimal fractions. (6)When the arc is 00, its secant, being equal to radius (59 c), is unity or 1,aiid the secants of all arcs greater than 00 are greater than unity or 1,or mixed numbers. (f) Wlien the arc is 900, its cosecant, being equal to radius (50 d), is unity or 1,and the cosecants of all arcs less than 903 are greater than unity or 1,or mixed numbers. UNITED STATES COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY.

NOTE.-The tabular difference between the m a n t i s s ~ of any twcv consecutive numbers should decrease as the numbers increase, but in tlle foregoing table there are occasioual exceptions to this rule, due to the fact that wherever the eleventh and twelfth places of suy mantissa exceed . 50, the tenth place is iucreased by unity or 1 Sometimes wheu a rnautissa whose tenth place has been increased by unity or 1is followed by a mantissa whose tenth placc is not so increased, the tabular diEerence of such mantissa will exceed the tabular difference of the preceding mantissz. Thus iu the table the difference between the mantisss corresponding to the numbers 90005 and 90051 is 48227, while that between the mantissle corresponding to tlle numbers 90051 aud 90052 is 48228. Here the greater numbers have the greater difference, which is theoretically incorrect. As given in the table-Numbors. Mantiesm.

90050 90051 Tabular difference
Numbers.

.9544837172 .9544885399 48227
hlantisere.

!I0051 90052 Tabular diflerence As given with r n a n t i s a ~ to thirteen placesNumbers.

.!I544885399 ,9544933627 48228

Mantissm.

90050 90051 Tabular difference

.9544837171655< .955;1885399437 48227882

As the eleventh and twelfth places i n tlle mantissa difference exceed 50, unity or 1shonld be added to the tenth place, aud tlie difference then becomes 48228 and not 48227, as given in the table.
Numbers.
I).irtntissio.

90051 90052 Tabular d ifforenee

.9544885390437 .9544033626782 48227345

difference aro less than 50, nothing is added As the eleventh and twelfth placos in the ~uautissa to the teuth plaoo, ant1 t*.diEerence theu will ba 48227 and not 48228, as given ill the table. I n selecting the ledit of two evile it has been deemed prudent to choose t,he differences between the col~secutive mantissz actually given in the table iu preference to those which would result were the mantissa givon fo thirteen places.
